There was and still is mixed feelings with Fallout 3 in the Fallout community. Fans saying that it doesn't have as much depth as Fallout New Vegas or it swayed too far from Interplay's Original portrayal of Fallout (Fallout 1&2). 
All I can say is play it before making a final judgement. From my personal first hand experience with Fallout 3, I was stunned by how good it is, and even that is an understatement. The first time playing it (in 2018 to add), I was hooked for hours and days on end like a Wastelander addicted to Chems, Fallout 3 is a game you can't live without. 
It left me wholely satisfied with my time and money invested, it gave me pure joy blasting Raider's and Super Mutant's heads off!
Provided below is an unbiased list of my pros and cons.

Pros
-There is a variety of unique characters, locations, and quests
-All official DLCs are whole other experiences in themselves
-Locations are well designed that offer a lot of fun in exploring everywhere
-Some really unique and qwerky characters wander the Capital Wastes that tease your intrigue
-There is a lot of freedom of choice, you can be the Hero of the wastes, a Cold-blooded Tyrant who everyone fears, or something in between, it all falls to you
-A nice variety of weapons
Cons
-It can randomly crash in-game sometimes if you play it for too long in one sitting
-Some guns and lasers can be a total pain when it comes to reloading, I suggest to time your reloading well
-There are no steam achievements which is a let down for me personally

Final Verdict 9/10
With a few minor issues aside, Fallout 3 will get you hooked for a good long time! It's worth playing and I recommend it to any Fallout fan! I can't believe the amount of pure enjoyment I have had from playing this game, and hey, fun is what playing a game is all about!

Fallout 3 is one of those well-loved games that I feel hasn’t really aged the best, and sometimes doesn’t feel intuitive when navigating through its world. It might take some getting used to especially for newcomers, but sticking it out is rewarding and can be fun after a while when you’ve gotten a good foothold with the right amount of resources you need to fare well against the bad elements and harsh environments (especially since repairing weapons is a necessity). 

From my understanding, this game is known for its bugs and hiccups. On my end, the game would crash at times (ran it on Windows 10 OS). Nevertheless, I was able to play through the entire game plus the DLCs with this being the only issue. Aside from that, there was also one side quest (Head of the State) that I ran problems with completing due to it having its own issues. The quest can be completed but I had to make use of a discussion thread which confirmed that it was indeed bugged.

The main story itself is fairly short, which makes the Broken Steel DLC included in the GOTY edition make the entire thing more satisfying to complete. Without it, the original ending feels anticlimactic. Fallout 3 is very open world which makes exploring fun as you get more experience and more used to the combat system. However, it can be somewhat confusing if you simply want to go straight for the main story since progressing isn’t simply going from Point A to Point B, what with the several areas of the DC ruins you have to explore both on the surface and underground (interconnected railway system) to reach your desired destinations.

What the game does completely right though is its apocalyptic atmosphere. I’ve come across discussions on how Fallout games have changed for every release and how well or badly it has captured this supposed dark or bleak feel/atmosphere that a post-apocalyptic world is supposed to possess. Fallout 3’s feels right to me. The places I’ve visited, the humans and non-humans I’ve encountered and interacted with, and the side quests and main story I’ve played through, captures the definition of a “post-apocalyptic wasteland” well.

Fallout 3 is worth purchasing only on sale, preferably the GOTY edition. With the DLC, there are hours more of content and equipment that can be accessed and different side stories to explore. Broken Steel is a definite must play while the rest are optional. The Pitt for its intriguing story with one of the more morally ambiguous choices to choose from, and the other three which are only mostly worth if for some loot or added world-building lore bits (Operation: Anchorage and Mothership: Zeta mostly for its items, and Point Lookout being the least significant one for me, especially as you enter the late stage of the game).

Abysmal writing, terrible gameplay, black and white morality, and severe lack of depth makes this into one of the weakest entries in the Fallout franchise. The story is awful and has almost no involvement from the player himself, since your dad is the actual protagonist of the game making all the decisions. Almost all characters are extremely one-dimensional and forgettable. Factions are also very one-dimensional, the BoS is presented as the Hollywood good guys trying to help everyone out while the Enclave are the generic bad guys. There's no nuance whatsoever.

Something that frustrates me about this game is the worldbuilding, or lack thereof. It's absolute garbage. Even basic things like how there are no farms, no trade routes, no explanations to how people get electricity, nothing. Why would they build a town around a f*cking nuke? I can understand religious fanatics doing that, but why are normal people going along with it despite perfectly understanding how utterly retarded that is? Two-century old food scavenged from a pre-war supermarket is still edible, and seems to be the main source of sustenance for people. The game feels like it takes place 20 years after the war, not 200. Why is the east coast so undeveloped after all this time? Fallout 1 is set about 84 years after the war and its world was leaps and bounds more developed than what we can see in Fallout 3, and then you look at Fallout 2 with places like Vault City and you can't help but be entirely confused at how everyone in FO3 is a scavenger living in absolute misery. Are the residents of D.C. just imbeciles? Where the hell is civilization? 

Still on the topic of worldbuilding, it's extremely disappointing to see just how creatively bankrupt Bethesda was when developing their take on the universe. Moving the setting to the east coast could have been one of the most interesting things about this game, but of course, it ended up being completely wasted potential. Bethesda does almost nothing to expand or advance the lore of the universe, and everything just feels stale, recycled, and uninspired as a result. [url=youtu.be/M8U4k2Ik6yk][u]This video[/u][/url] explains what I mean pretty well.

The game also holds your hand as much as it can, assuring that none of your actions can have any long-lasting consequences, which is one of the many things that make this game lack depth. I absolutely hate the concept of essential NPCs and quest markers. I'm not sure if Bethesda did this in an effort to appeal to its bottom-feeder fanbase or if it was because of sheer incompetence to develop an RPG. Probably a mixture of both. And holy f*ck, don't get me started on the wretched hellspawn that is the Gamebryo engine and Bethesda's ineptitude to optimize and work with it.

Credit where credit is due, though: the game has a pretty decent atmosphere. It's not hard to get lost in its world, since it has somewhat of a stark beauty to it (well, at least if you use mods to remove the disgusting puke-green filter). The sound design is also pretty nice for the most part (minus the guns, which sound like garbage), and I really like both the ambient tracks and the music selections on the radio. And, as much as I hate how the game holds the player's hand by leveling everything alongside them (ensuring that there is a very weak sense of progression throughout), I have to admit I really like the overall game world and design, and the game definitely rewards exploration. Also, and this is the best thing about Fallout 3 by far: New Vegas wouldn't exist without it. Of course, it's a double-edged sword since Obsidian was forced to use its god-awful engine to develop NV, but it's better to have a great game on a crappy engine than to not have that game at all. That's pretty much it, though.

Fallout 3 isn't the worst game ever made, nor is it the worst entry in the franchise (that title would probably go to Fallout 4. FO76 doesn't really count since it's just some worthless spin-off developed by a B-team with no effort put into it). I think it has some redeemable qualities like the game world and atmosphere, but I don't think those are nearly enough to make up for the great number of faults the game has. Overall, I think it fails as a shooter, as an RPG, and as a Fallout game. [b]4/10.[/b]

"Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition," developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released in 2009, enriches the original "Fallout 3" experience with all five downloadable content packs. Set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland near Washington, D.C., now known as the Capital Wasteland, the game blends open-world exploration with a compelling narrative, set against the backdrop of a society struggling to rebuild. This review evaluates the Game of the Year Edition of "Fallout 3" based on its gameplay mechanics, story and character development, graphical and audio presentation, replayability, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" offers a vast, open-world experience combining first-person shooter elements with traditional RPG mechanics. The game's V.A.T.S. (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) allows players to pause the action and target specific enemy body parts, adding a strategic layer to combat. The inclusion of all DLCs introduces new weapons, areas, and quests, significantly expanding the gameplay options and exploration potential. While the game mechanics are robust, some players may find the combat and movement slightly clunky by today's standards.

Story and Character Development
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The narrative of "Fallout 3" is engaging and immersive, with the player's journey beginning as they search for their father in the vast wasteland. The game's story is enriched by its well-developed characters and moral choices that impact the world and its inhabitants. The additional content from the DLCs further deepens the lore and player's understanding of the game's universe, offering new perspectives and challenges that enhance the main storyline.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 8/10 - Very Good
At the time of its release, "Fallout 3" was praised for its atmospheric depiction of a post-nuclear war landscape, featuring dilapidated buildings, desolate landscapes, and a hauntingly beautiful sky. The Game of the Year Edition maintains these visuals while also introducing varied environments through its DLCs. The audio, from the eerie soundscapes to the iconic 1940s and 50s soundtrack, complements the game's setting perfectly. However, the graphics may appear dated to new players, with some textures and character models showing their age.

Replayability
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The sheer scale of "Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition," combined with its branching narrative paths, multiple endings, and extensive side quests, ensures a high level of replayability. Each DLC pack offers unique stories and locations, encouraging players to explore every corner of the game's world. The variety of play styles supported, from stealth to brute force, allows for different approaches in subsequent playthroughs.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
With its expansive world, deep narrative, and the addition of substantial DLC content, "Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" provides exceptional entertainment value. It's a game that invites players to immerse themselves fully in its post-apocalyptic universe, offering dozens, if not hundreds, of hours of exploration, questing, and character development.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.8/10 - Excellent
"Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" is a definitive version of one of the most iconic open-world RPGs, offering an unparalleled blend of storytelling, exploration, and player choice. Its impact on the genre and the enduring appeal of its wasteland setting make it a must-play title for fans of RPGs and post-apocalyptic narratives.

A all-time masterpiece and a must-play game for RPG enthusiasts and those seeking a rich, open-world experience with deep narrative layers and extensive content. "Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" stands as a testament to Bethesda's ability to craft immersive worlds that captivate and engage players for countless hours.

"Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" remains a landmark in the RPG genre, offering a post-apocalyptic world that is as fascinating to explore as it is harrowing. Its blend of compelling storytelling, player-driven choices, and a vast, explorable world ensures its place in the annals of gaming history as a classic that continues to be celebrated and enjoyed by new and returning players alike.

It's a very solid and somewhat beginner-friendly Western, post-apocalyptic sci-fi open world RPG. Much easier to control than a typical CRPG due to the Fallout series shifting genres from top-down tactical game to streamlined first person shooter with an optional third person mode and a percentage-based auto-aiming system, VATS. 

Gameplay consists of wandering around the ruins in and around Washington D.C., scavenging for weapons, ammo and bottle caps and hidden caches of goodies while fighting off hordes of mutated critters and hostile raiders.

There are a lot of skills you can play around with such as low-tech firearms (small guns), locking and computer hacking for extra goodies, stealth, melee weapons, rocket launchers and energy rifles, bartering with and persuading NPCs, etc.

The game does show its age in regard to gameplay and graphics (much like the sister Bethesda game, Elder Scrolls Oblivion), but the roleplaying experience is solid, as this was before Fallout 4 vastly trimmed down the dialouge options after Fallout 3 and Fallout NV.

Fallout 3 is an interesting mixed-bag of a game. When I went into this, I expected to dislike it based on my initial impressions when trying to get the game to actually work. Once i had managed to get past that, however, I Truly managed to see what Fallout 3 is.

Mediocre

It's not a terrible game, and it's assuredly a Fallout game. Unlike 4, 3 feels right, and really conveys that post-apocalypse well. But It's sorely lacking in a few areas and it leaves a lot to be desired. Level design is mostly stagnant, and the metro system seems awesome at first but then quickly becomes exceptionally frustrating, your progress to other areas limited by arbitrary walls of rubble but yet somehow perfectly functioning underground tunnels. Characters are... a mixed bag. Autumn was extremelly shallow and underwhelming, but Eden was pretty interesting. Your Dad is a reasonably complex character, and people like Doctor Madison Li take away from the slew of side characters that make no impact.

The companion system is horrendous. There's no bonus to using a companion, as they burn through ammo, have ZERO death protection, get in the way constantly, have inconsistently tagged skills, and have almost no depth to them. There are almost zero companions that are actually interesting with a good story of ANY sort behind them, and Dogmeat is the most useless mutt i've ever met.

The main story is at first, exceptionally boring, but it does get better except right at the end where the game slaps you in the face with it's abysmal ending, and before Broken Steel the game flat-out REFUSED to let you make the smartest choice because "you have to be a martyr for no reason other than story closure". Side quests can be quite fun, such as the superhero quest, but some are extremelly tedious - like the Wasteland Survival Guide.

Combat is standard Bethesda-Fare Open-World combat, and it's of no suprise the best weapons are the ones that DON'T use ammo (Specifically the Shishkebab). Levelling is slow, but actually very well-paced. I Hit level 30 just before the end of the game, so in that sense, good job. The Karma system can take a hike, especially on morally ambiguous quests like Tenpenny Tower - where the best option has that god-damn radio announcer calling you a scumbag because it was "the wrong thing". The karma system would be less of a joke if it wasn't for the fact I could murder, steal, and pillage the ENTIRE of Rivet City, eating corpses, picking locks, hacking terminals, everything - and then just... donate a few caps to make myself a messiah again.

DLC-Wise, here's a quick rundown.

Operation Anchorage: Probably my favorite. Well-paced, self-contained, excellent and powerful rewards that are reasonably balanced by the repair system, decent story and never outstayed it's welcome.

Mothership Zeta: A little too bulky in places, almost felt padded at times, but otherwise was a refreshing change of pace. Self-Contained, fun and light-hearted story witha bunch of interesting and fun items.

The Pitt: Very mediocore until the very last choice of the DLC regarding the "cure", which goes down as the single most interesting and hard-to-make choice in the entire game. Otherwise, extremelly passable (although it does have some AWESOME weapons)

Point Lookout: If it wasn't for the disembodied brain, this would be a steaming pile of crap. Luckily for Point Lookout, the brain reminded me of Old World Blues from New Vegas. But yeah, don't waste your time.

Broken Steel: I'm a really big fan of the BoS. Seeing the story evolve past that travesty of an ending was really nice, and the stuff it added put a nice bit of flavor into the world. It wasn't amazing though.

The problem with Fallout 3 is that it's shockingly bland and safe, in a lot of ways. UNlike Vegas, which pushed the stories and quests to their limit, Fallout 3 carries a very strong "meh" vibe. IN Vegas, you could overlook the shoddy combat because of the awesome story. You could ovelook clumsy mechanics and bugs because of interesting characters and fascinating locales. In truth, Fallout 3's biggest crime is playing it safe.

When it tries, and it takes a risk, Fallout 3 can be really fun. When it doesn't, it's the gaming equivelant of white rice. Bland, filling, and overall - not very good.

I originally played this game to its ending on the xbox 360, so the hours played here are not indicative of my full experience with the game. That said, I should definitely mention that the PC version here can seem to be hit or miss with some people depending on their system. I haven't had too many major problems, but its potential technical problems are definitely worth keeping mind, especially due to it being an open world Bethesda game. 

Actual Review:
I love the mood of Fallout 3 much more than that of Fallout: New Vegas. The dreary tones with a grayer palette overlaying desecrated major US landmarks create beautiful storytelling through simple visuals without the need to rely on dialogue or strong plot writing to substantiate it.

This mood is important because much of the writing--at least when moderately scrutinized--is too milquetoast to be compelling on its own.

Fallout 3 began Bethesda's reign over the Fallout franchise and saw it grow progressively more estranged from its satirical origins. While I haven't played much of Fallout 1 or 2 due to them lacking a user-friendly interface, I know enough of them to recognize the dark humor behind their writing which sought to emphasize the devastation of nuclear war while satirizing the pro-corporate and nationalistic culture which led to such an apocalypse.

By contrast, Fallout 3 feels like an opportunity for a fun power trip through a post-apocalypse which happens to contain some haunting visuals and some franchise-inherited social commentary. This might seem like a criticism, but it's actually the game's strongest suit and what makes it worth playing. 

Exploring the wasteland with the knowledge that you'll be able to handle almost whatever situation you come across with some classic radio music playing in the background is straightforwardly fun, which is an element the original two Fallouts comparatively struggle with--at least for most mainstream or modern players. Fallout 3 is able to combine that straightforward fun with the tragic yet sardonic tone that the Fallout series is built upon. It's a game whose gameplay doesn't get it in its own way.

That said, Fallout: New Vegas offers a vastly more interesting depiction of the wasteland with stronger roleplaying options which encourage more replays as compared to its predecessor. New Vegas is the better game in many ways, but the hard hitting mood feels more impactful in Fallout 3 thanks to 3's drearier setting and visuals.

The last thing to note is definitely the most important and the most open to debate as of recent years: Bethesda's writing ability.

I will play devil's advocate and say that Bethesda's writing is technically very strong, but only in that technical sense due to how it accomplishes its goal of being fun and player-empowering without offering much else. Its comparative shallowness (at least when compared to New Vegas) is a boon in some ways since it allows the player to pick and choose what they want to become involved with and shirk off anything that disinterests them due to no individual quest demanding it be treated like it's important through either its high quality of writing or requirement for main narrative completion (save for mainline quests, of course).

Disregarding that boon of encouraging player agency over their play experience, the Bethesda approach to writing has rightful received more scrutiny over the years and this game hasn't broken this highly-criticized mold in any major way. That said, if you can embrace a form of compelling storytelling that is based more on mood and atmosphere, Fallout 3 won't disappoint.

Recommendation:
This game receives a mild recommendation from me. Fallout: New Vegas is the better option in most ways and other open world games have learned from Fallout 3 and implemented both enrapturing atmospheres and interesting stories with accompanying solid gameplay. That said, Fallout 3 still retains a unique mood and feeling which many of these later games have not yet captured--not even the largely better New Vegas. It's a worthwhile Fallout game if only for a single playthrough. Newer Fallout fans seeking to check out older games in the franchise would be remiss to skip over this one due to accusations of lackluster writing. Those accusations aren't wholly wrong--the writing here can often tend toward being fairly milquetoast--but the comparatively better written Fallout 1 and 2 are less player friendly than this ps3/360 era rpg, so I would sooner recommend it over them. Ultimately, it probably won't keep you coming back the same way other Fallout games can, but the single playthrough it can offer is definitely worthwhile for those who are curious.

This game feels more rushed than New Vegas. Everywhere you go, there's hints of a sprawling, interconnected, reactive wasteland. There's a ghoul who explicitly asks for human flesh, a request you can only refuse, despite the many gore bags around super mutant hideouts, and the cannibal perk you can acquire yourself. There's a woman who asks you -not- to free their enslaved son in another city for fear of repercussions. If you return to the son, there's no new dialogue options. There're kids who will run away if you call one of them a brat. Their mother will go drink at the bar; the kids will get captured by mercenaries. If you rescue them, nothing happens. Over and again, the wasteland presents organically unfolding stories that go nowhere.

I keep playing because the glimpses of what Fallout 3 could have been are mesmerising. There's a museum where the "present" exhibit is blocked off by rubble. Corpses and meth lie scattered around displays of technological wonder. There's a nuclear family that espouses democracy and voting, while cannibalising any foreigners who stumble onto their property. After helping a man out of a coma, you can tell him you merely wanted him conscious before killing him. People say Fallout 3 failed to capture the black humour of its predecessors, but it seems pretty wry to me.

The main story is dreadful, unfortunately. The factions involved in it have been thoroughly simplified from Fallout 1 and 2. For example, the Brotherhood of Steel were once a faction of tech-hoarding isolationists, driven by the belief that tech in the hands of the masses will end in bloodshed. In other words, they were reactionary, elitist, and self-serving. In Fallout 3, they're humanitarians, who serve to protect the masses. They're still elitists, but now technology is something to help others with, rather than to hide from others. It's just . . . far less interesting a take.

As an old-school fan of the original Interplay games, I was cautiously optimistic when I heard about Fallout 3 all those years ago.  I liked the Elder Scrolls series, but turning Fallout into a first-person 3D game sounded like it could end very poorly.  I still prefer the old isometric, turn-based games in many respects, but this turned out to be pretty fun.

If you're not into Bethesda's open world games, the writing and role-playing will likely seem shallow.  It recycles some plot elements of the older games, which is both good and not-so-good.  It's familiar and comforting to step into a world where so little has changed.  However, it's also kind of like reading fanfic written by someone who is worried that if they don't constantly rehash every major franchise element, people will hate their story.

The combat is fun.  There's a pseudo-turn-based mechanic called VATS, which is a nice bone to throw to us old-school fans.  Most of the game mechanics were also kept.  You've got your attributes, skills, perks, and so on.  It's a bit streamlined, but it's still recognizably Fallout.  Character creation itself is a bit long and involved due to it being a bit of a heavily scripted tutorial.  It leads you to the main quest, which is reasonably interesting, but in typical Bethesda style, it's totally optional to follow it.

The series' black humor is retained.  It's a lot wackier than the first game, but I kind of blame the second game for this tonal shift -- it was already starting to get a bit wacky back then.  Bethesda just ran with it and cranked it up a few notches higher.  If meeting someone named Dave who leads the Republic of Dave sounds amusing to you, you'll probably quite enjoy the humor.  I thought it was amusing.

If you like the Elder Scrolls series or the early Fallout games, it's worth checking out.  If you're coming here after playing a hardcore RPG, you may be disappointed.

Fallout 3 is a game that contains disturbing imagery. One of the primary villain groups, referred to as 'Raiders' in the game, are surrounded by mutilated bodies tied to beds, heads and bodies hung on hooks, or viscera scattered on the floor. A villain group called 'Super mutants' have gore bags containing mutilated body parts also in their occupied areas. A particularly unsettling villain group called 'Deathclaws' can elicit a traumatic gaming experience if one is not prepared.

The quests and locations is Fallout 3 present an amalgamation of good ideas from Science fiction, Futurism, and Post Apocalyptic books, film, and games. Concepts from sources like Logan's Run (Little Lamplight), The City and the Stars (Oasis), The Twilight Zone (Vault 112), are inspiration for memorable quests. Locations called 'Vaults' explore human experimentation, and the world map, set in Washington D.C in the USA, weaves in American history tidbits into the experience.

A rather clever gameplay mechanic called 'VATS', allows one to freeze time during an attack and display a Matrix (the film) style, slow motion, camera panning view of the attack you choose. Their are villainous gameplay elements, such as pickpocketing items from people, a "perk" that allows for cannibalism, a weapon and collar for enslavement, among others. There are also empathetic gameplay elements like escorting friends to safety, donation, and encouragement that provide small counterbalances to a very harsh game world.

Despite the extreme violence, the classic toys called 'Crash Dummies' are more reminiscent during gunplay, than say, a wartime torture film. The Crash Dummy toys, had buttons to eject the head and arms, and to eject the legs. The villain class known as 'Raiders' make for enjoyable Crash Dummies.

Applying external modifications to the game, through a website like Nexus may be necessary to have an optimal experience.

I want to put you in a scenario, really quick. You're ten years old, and just a few years prior, your parents split up. You loved both of them so much growing up, and now you're supposed to be seeing your father during visits, meeting at restaurants to talk, the such.

But when you get to the restaurant, when you get to the visit, he isn't there. He lied about meeting you there, and you and your brother bawl your eyes out. It puts a sense of longing in your life for someone you thought loved you, wondering why the only father you ever had would just abandon you.

And then you find a game about a character that's going through the same stuff you are. The main character is in a foreign world that they had never known, trying to find a dad that's been missing for an unknown amount of time. It brings you shelter.
It brings you comfort.

In a way, Fallout 3 could have been one of the sole reasons I got through those years. The sting of losing my father was horrible, and yes, I cried a lot when I realized he wasn't coming to meet us when he said he would. But seeing how the Fallout 3 main character could get through anything, even when he felt betrayed, lost, and forgotten by someone he just wanted to love, it made me strong enough to stand on my legs and be my own person.

I've heard there's going to be a Fallout 3 remake in the future. And the day it releases, I'm going to cry again. But this time, it'll be for a different reason.

[h1]Although not the same as the older titles, it’s still unique and it’s still the good old Fallout universe which the game expands upon, even if it’s a bit less dark and serious.[/h1]

Fallout 3 is the first installment of the series, reimagined in 3D by Bethesda. Although much different from its predecessors it still managed to get many fans. 

This one takes place mainly in the year 2277 in the Capital Wasteland. You grow up in Vault 101 raised by your father named James. One day for some reason he decides to leave the Vault and you behind, creating a big ruckus in the isolationist underground community. This forces you to also abandon the safe walls of the Vault and embark on a wild chase throughout the Wasteland in search of your dad. 
That’s all of your character’s established lore. The rest is up to you. Will you become the Wasteland’s messiah or its ruin? 
Main story is alright. The game is filled with quests and different stories for you to experience. Problems have many solutions. Reason with somebody or gun him down? Pickpocket the key item or get it off a corpse? Open a door by picking its lock or maybe by using a terminal? 
Quests offer moral choices which not always are simple and different endings award unique awards. Some side missions are better, some worse. 
The world has its highlights, but not every random shack found in the Wasteland is going to be equally interesting as is The Oasis or Tenpenny Tower. 
F3 vibe is different than the previous games. It seems far less serious and dark. I don’t know if it’s because of Bethesda’s new take on the game, tons of memes that I’ve seen in their engine or the fact that the NPCs look and behave in utterly goofy ahh way (like Sarah, the proud and upstanding brotherhood knight, gunning down this one unlucky merchant that just happened to be walking by during the Liberty Prime escort for no apparent reason). 

The biggest flaw of this game in my opinion is its terrible combat system. I’m not sure if they wanted the shooting to be more RPG like or whatever, but it just doesn’t work. Sure, this wasn’t supposed to be a shooter, but it became one anyway so why make it so bad? Your guns don’t shoot straight, sometimes they even straight up refuse to shoot even if you click the d.amn button. Opponents’ movements are either completely chaotic which sometimes defeats the point of even trying to aim or they just stand still waiting to get blasted (or for you to shoot and then they move away at the last moment). Later parts of the game, especially DLC content, becomes the real pain though. Enemies are bullet sponges. Try shooting this one high-level ghoul. Half the shots you are going to miss and the other half it will just absorb somehow. Sure, the iconic V.A.T.S. system makes a comeback, but you can’t use it all the time. 
The leveling system is very cool. After the initial distribution of SPECIAL points which establish your character’s main strengths and weaknesses, each level up lets you upgrade skills you want to invest in and pick a perk. All those things you can later use to solve problems and quests by playing to your strengths. Not good in a fight? Sneak past a guy or reason with him. 
One of the best things about modern Fallout games is the exploration and gathering junk. Learning what is valuable and worth taking and what is not. What will come in handy and what is worth selling for caps. Stuff you can find in various containers or just lying around. Actual locations are cool to explore and scavenge in, but after a while the environments start to feel very repetitive. DLC locations spice it up a little though. The only thing that was sort of annoying is trying to move around the actual city. It’s hard to get to some location on your own when you are constantly being blocked by some debris. Now [b]IF[/b] you figure out you have to use the metro system to get to some specific places you still must look at metro maps to not get lost. This normally wouldn’t be a problem, maybe a fun puzzle of sorts, if it wasn’t so different than the rest of the game when you just pick a direction and walk towards it. 
The additional content of this game is interesting and worth playing through at least for the new gear. Main game doesn’t really have a big selection of weaponry, there is only one actual shotgun really if you don’t count the sawed-off. But man, again, the amount of health enemies have in DLCs is just a step too much. It doesn’t make the game harder, I had like 300 stimpaks on a hotkey, but it just makes the game tiresome as hell. 

Music fits the vibe and it’s alright, although it kind of gets repetitive after a while. What is a lot better though are various radio stations you can listen to while exploring the Wasteland. Some real bangers out there. You can also listen to the good old Lady Agatha. 
Graphically the game did get quite old, but you can’t say it doesn’t have its unique aesthetic. The world is dirty, dark and full of junk (da.mn, that’s a nice rhyme). 

Fallout 3 started a new era for the franchise. It took a step towards a more modern approach. Was it a step in a good or bad direction? I don’t know, but it was sure in a different one. Although not the same as the older titles, it’s still unique and it’s still the good old Fallout universe which the game expands upon, even if it’s a bit less dark and serious.

I could power through but hey, hey it's 2024 and there are so many quality games to play and given my limited time, I'll enjoy those.

I have wasted so many hours trying to mod this game, it sometimes works but for whatever stupid reason it just randomly stops functioning properly and crash. If all you do is play the vanilla version of this game then its a great experience and the 2021 update has made it as stable as the console version. But if you're like me and want to mod it making it better I do not recommend this game at all. It's a total nightmare and it will die on you even if your mods work perfectly fine starting off, the more you play it you'll see things start getting weird and break on you.

The gameplay through the first 10ish hours is a real challenge (I played through on Normal difficulty), until you're around level 15 you will almost always be running low on healing items, barely making loot from combat encounters worth the health cost to kill the enemies. The doctor merchants never seem to have more than 10 stimpaks at a time making it a struggle to keep on top of damage. Also companions straight up dying was a BIG adjustment coming from NV and 4, it made certain companions (cough, Cross, cough) more of a hindrance in combat as you're just constantly loading quicksaves whenever they fall over. 

The story is good but the pacing is kinda strange, for example:
In one line you can convince Eden to k"ll himself, same with Autumn but he just leaves
The main quest is given such a sense of urgency that on your first playthrough you likely won't see much outside of the main quest and a few areas on the way between main quest areas
The ending feels kinda out of nowhere, you're looking through vault 87 and then boom you're talking to Robobama and the game is almost over :/
All the content in the main quest is fairly enjoyable but if you play the way the game wants you to, practically just bum rushing the main quest it's extremely shallow compared to all the content that the game offers.

Coming from the newer games it's definitely an odd experience, if you've ever gone back to an old console and just felt weird playing it's similar to that. Definitely similar to the console you love and probably an enjoyable experience but BE PREPARED FOR JANK and also a lack of polish compared to newer games.

Also IDK if it's just the steam port having issues but I had way more crashes and freezes in 3 than the other games, even more than NV and even the classic games whenever I tried running them.

I have a weird relationship with Fallout 3.

One the one hand, this is an at best tolerably written watered-down version of the Black Isle's Fallout universe, full of the worst of Bethesda's trademark tropes. Bland and rushed main story, critical lack of memorable quest-lines, locations, or characters, two out of the five DLCs absolutely awful, while the other three are alright at most. But the worst is, of course, the glaring black hole in place of the exquisite dark humor and post-apocalyptic fatalism that the Fallout universe (the most unique video game universe, in my opinion) was so good at.

On the other hand, this is one of the first [mature] games that I have played, way back in 2007 or 2008, and, what the heck, I absolutely loved it back then. Even today, I cannot be completely objective with Fallout 3 because it is full of nostalgia and childhood memories.

Furthermore, I see it as essentially a prequel (gameplay and worldbuilding wise, not story wise) to my absolute favorite Fallout New Vegas, which, I swear, becomes even more enjoyable if you first complete Fallout 3 and then move on to New Vegas.

It would be dishonest to give thumbs down to a game that I had so much fun with, BUT, let me be clear, it could have been so much better if not for the good-old "Bethesda treatment." But hey, at least the franchise is not dead. So, anyway, thanks, Todd!

P.S. Ignore "hours played" here, as I have sunk hundreds of hours into this thing long before I had a Steam account.

Some people hate this game, some people love it. I think it's a weaker Fallout title, but it's still fun, which is a key distinction from objectively good.

Story: The story and role-playing options are abysmal. You are allowed to be good or evil, with no real depth to your choices. The dialogue options also feel extremely limiting for role-playing, so it's hard to be a different character than what was predetermined form the devs. You also can't greatly change the ending, which is and was a staple in most other Fallout games. Watch a video from Cretosis on YouTube as to why the story itself sucks, I agree with around 90% of his points.

Game-play:  The game play is janky, however, I think some things add to the fun of the game. The amount of variety in ways you can play (Not role-play) are really fun, you can pick between multiple different combat styles, how you dress up, different SPECIAL stats and perks, all the basic stuff like that is really fun. Even though the shooting isn't the best, I still think it's fun, especially since VATS really helps with this. The gore, gun sounds, all of it is really arcade-y but still suitable enough. It's not a hard game, but it sure is entertaining imo. I really like the act of finding and then completing quests, collecting, well, collectibles, etc., which is what Fallout 3 was designed to do, and does really well. Even though not every quest is perfect, I still think it's amusing.

Graphics: Horrible FOR THE TIME, which is important since it would be unfair to judge it's graphics to today's games.

Art direction+Atmosphere: Easily the best part of this game. The choices of both ambient and radio music to listen to while walking across the map IMMENSELY elevate the Fallout experience. That with the world design and art direction make the game good to look at. The green filter hurts the experience, but I feel like that's kind of the point, to make the world look like shit.

Overall, while the game on the surface should be absolutely horrible, it still manages to be FUN. Sometimes it's a fun bad, sometimes it's actually good, and sometimes it's just plain old stupid in a fun way. Overall, a 6.75/10

[h2]Disclaimer[/h2]
This review is mixed of retrospective and overall thought from me on Fallout 3.

Fallout 3... The first 3D Fallout that I experience back in 2014-ish. To be truth Fallout 3 was my first entry to this series. At first I thought Fallout game is "Post Nuclear-Apocalypse RPG game" but once I stepped in more into classic Fallout (after Fallout 3, I played Fallout 1 & 2) it felt like tonal shift of the "Post Apocaypse" stuff. Bethesda did a good job bringing this IP from dead as Bethesda bought Fallout IP when Black Isle studio went bankrupt (while also making Fallout 3 Van Buren). Fallout 3 expands Fallout lore into East Coast as most Interplay/Black Isle canon are taking place on West coast and mid west.

My steam playtime hour is not accurate as back then I played Fallout 3 on pirated copy before I bought one on Steam.

Let's take a dive on review shall we?

[h2]Setting:[/h2]
Fallout 3 sets in Capital Wasteland, once Washington DC that now ridden with Super Mutant and infested ghouls, FO3 differs in setting compared to previous where the story take place on West Coast. By making the story on new location, Bethesda can make the lore as much as they can while also give some reference on previous Fallout entry. In my opinion Fallout 3 did great job capturing the bleakness Post Apocalyptic of Capital Wasteland especially when you play it without companion. While on West Coast everyone is already on Post-Post-Apocalyptic world where society is formed and Nations shaping up, on here it feels like the bomb dropped several dozens year ago.

The faction also felt like more "black and white" compared to classic Fallout where some Faction are more well written and morally ambiguous. In Fallout 3 you can summarise faction like "Enclave bad, BoS good, Super Mutant dumb" that feels really 2 dimensional meanwhile on classic Fallout, BoS is xenophobic faction that would not even share their stuff with towner or wastelander around them, NCR which developed from being band of raiders group into Nation, Enclave which motivated by pursuing Old World America by seeking Old World tech from Vault Tec (hence why they seek Vault 13 inhabitant and your tribal village Arroyo [b]not making everyone become miserable[/b] like on Fallout 3), Inter-state caravan link and much more. Honestly I'm not annoyed on the scope of Fallout 3 but on the whole view of Fallout lore, it bits irk of me.

The DLC portion is interesting.
(a) Point Lookout give us a view of what Southern looks like, the swampy world make the exploration bit interesting but the inhabitant are bullet spongy.
(b) Ops. Anchorage gives you VR mission that gave very overpowered equipment from get go.
(c) The Pitt. the more I see it more it looks like Dead Money of New Vegas but not so "Dead Money". The Industrial landscape is step up of the setting which inline with established lore.
(d) Mothersip Zeta... everytime I played Fallout 3, I never tried this DLC.

[h2]Story:[/h2]
You need to find your dad, and your dad want to help everyone, so you help everyone and then died. Suddenly you wake up because DLC installed.

Lone Wanderer felt like to take picnic trip to Southern, ended up getting violated by random Ferryboat captain, and for some reason you get a little bit of "espionage" mission and random ghoul want revenge for what happend centuries ago.

Lone Wanderer stumbled upon random Outcast BoS, decided to take a play on them, and raided their bunker.

Lone Wanderer going north but only to find they get enslaved. In process making revolt against the faction in control and free the slave in the Pitt.

I do not know Mothersip Zeta.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
For me the character building seems overpowered, this even more apparent when all DLC installed where each DLC adds +5 level cap (so in tally it is 50), another one is the perk system where you would get perk each time you leveled up. Perhaps this decision to make Fallout 3 more "console friendly" as previously Fallout is exlusive for PC.

Combat system also differ from previous fallout where you have Damage Threshold (DT) and Damage Resistance (DR) stats, somehow dumbed down than previous games.

While on classic Fallout you can approach (almost) every quest with every possible character build, in this one is bit limited.

Companion on this game require karma check for you to recruit them.

[h2]Graphics:[/h2]
The Graphics holds up perhaps due to the color selection and filter (back in this era games notoriously have those "Color Palette" as the game identity.

I cannot say if you think the game graphics is bad if you're coming from modern spoiled gamers who starts playing from 2010s era.

[h2]Control Design:[/h2]
Control layout holds up pretty well although some movement can be a bit buggy. If you want to play Fallout 3 you can just skip base game and use TTW to get better support of New Vegas engine fixes, and mod support.

[h2]Difficulty:[/h2]
I can say the Difficulty is pretty fair on early to mid game, but once you understand the game mechanics, the combat can be pretty "trivial" if you can cheese encounters.

Perk system and leveling is butchered in this game.

[h2]Personal Note:[/h2]
I recommend Fallout 3 in sense if you want to understand what happend on East Coast. However as every classic Fallout fans pointing out, Bethesda Fallout games are breaking some established lore.

In case you want to play Fallout 3 in Definitive way, get New Vegas too and install TTW. You can thank me later.

Pros: Excellent play-through that's completely different for every player, complicated missions force the user to stretch mentally, the graphics have aged well, lock picking and computer hacking are at their greatest difficulty of the entire franchise, the system that aids the user's aiming, V.A.T.S. is quick, and efficient but lacks a means of canceling 3rd person visuals that are currently in progress, i.e. the kill cam.

Cons: The maps are not designed to be viewed at maximum settings, and visually retain a sense of smallness characterized by landscapes with no aesthetic organization. If you walk through a well designed park, one see views that open and close. Fallout 4 has this characteristic, while Fallout 3 does not. In other words, there are no grand vistas, just many small experiences, many small views. This is probably due to the limitations of graphics at the time of creation. With a crappy video card the player experiences the game more through the lens of the quest guide and mini map, than actual graphics.

[h1]Fallout 3 - A Post-Apocalyptic Masterpiece That Defines Open-World RPGs[/h1]

[h2]Introduction:[/h2]
Fallout 3, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, stands as a landmark in the realm of open-world RPGs, transporting players to a desolate, post-apocalyptic wasteland filled with danger, intrigue, and moral ambiguity. Released in 2008, the game has endured as a classic, setting the bar for narrative depth, player agency, and atmospheric storytelling in the gaming industry.

[h2]Immersive World and Atmospheric Design:[/h2]
Fallout 3 introduces players to the Capital Wasteland, a sprawling, irradiated landscape that teems with both despair and hidden wonders. The game's atmospheric design is a testament to Bethesda's attention to detail, capturing the eerie beauty of decay. From iconic locations like the dilapidated ruins of Washington, D.C., to the irradiated glow of the landscape at sunset, every visual element contributes to the immersive world-building.

[h2]Narrative Depth and Player Agency:[/h2]
At the heart of Fallout 3 lies a narrative of personal discovery and moral complexity. The protagonist's journey, from emerging in Vault 101 to navigating the harsh realities of the wasteland, is a captivating odyssey. The game's commitment to player agency allows for a variety of choices, shaping the narrative and leading to multiple endings. The moral dilemmas presented force players to confront the consequences of their actions, adding layers of depth to the storytelling.

[h2]Memorable Characters and Factions:[/h2]
Fallout 3 introduces a cast of memorable characters, each with their own stories, motivations, and quirks. From the mysterious Three Dog, the charismatic radio DJ, to companions like Fawkes and Dogmeat, the wasteland is populated with personalities that leave a lasting impression. The inclusion of distinct factions, such as the Brotherhood of Steel and the Enclave, adds political intrigue and dynamic conflicts to the narrative.

[h2]Open-World Exploration and Discovery:[/h2]
The vastness of the Capital Wasteland invites players to embark on a journey of exploration and discovery. Abandoned buildings, hidden bunkers, and underground vaults hold secrets and lore, rewarding those who venture off the beaten path. The sense of freedom to chart one's course through the wasteland fosters a connection between the player and the game world, creating a truly open-ended and non-linear experience.

[h2]S.P.E.C.I.A.L. System and Character Progression:[/h2]
Fallout 3's character progression is rooted in the iconic S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system, allowing players to customize their skills and attributes. The choices made during character creation and level-up decisions significantly impact gameplay, fostering a sense of individuality and strategy. The variety of perks and abilities ensures that each playthrough can offer a distinct and tailored experience.

[h2]Dynamic Combat and V.A.T.S. System:[/h2]
The real-time combat in Fallout 3 is complemented by the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System (V.A.T.S.), adding a strategic layer to engagements. Players can pause the action, target specific body parts, and unleash a barrage of calculated attacks. The balance between real-time and turn-based combat allows for dynamic and satisfying encounters, catering to different playstyles.

[h2]Sound Design and Iconic Music:[/h2]
Fallout 3's sound design contributes significantly to its immersive atmosphere. The ambient sounds of the wasteland, from distant gunfire to the howling wind, enhance the sense of desolation. The inclusion of iconic '40s and '50s music on the in-game radio stations, including tracks like "I Don't Want to Set the World on Fire" and "Butcher Pete," adds a layer of nostalgic charm to the post-apocalyptic setting.

[h2]Technical Stability and Performance:[/h2]
While Fallout 3 has faced technical issues, especially upon its initial release, subsequent updates and patches have improved stability. The community's dedication to modding has also played a role in addressing performance concerns and enhancing the overall experience. Despite these challenges, the game's enduring popularity attests to its capacity to captivate players.

[h2]Legacy and Lasting Impact:[/h2]
Fallout 3's legacy extends beyond its initial release, influencing the design and narrative approach of subsequent open-world RPGs. Its success paved the way for the revitalization of the Fallout franchise and solidified Bethesda's reputation as a powerhouse in the genre. The game's enduring popularity and critical acclaim underscore its lasting impact on the gaming landscape.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Fallout 3 stands as a masterpiece in the open-world RPG genre, seamlessly blending narrative depth, player agency, and atmospheric design. Bethesda's commitment to crafting a rich, immersive world has resulted in a game that transcends its post-apocalyptic setting, leaving an indelible mark on the gaming industry. A decade after its release, Fallout 3 remains a shining example of storytelling and world-building in video games, inviting new generations of players to explore the unforgiving beauty of the Capital Wasteland.

Fallout 3, released in the same year as many other highly regarded games in the 360/PS3 era such as GTAIV, GoW2, and AC2, falls short in several crucial aspects. The writing, often hailed as a strong suit of the Fallout series, disappoints with a lackluster narrative and unengaging dialogue. Traversing the vast open world feels tedious and empty, lacking the immersive qualities seen in contemporaneous titles.

The gunplay, a pivotal element in any FPS game, is subpar, leaving players frustrated with clunky mechanics and unsatisfying combat encounters. Comparatively, Dead Space, released in the same year, showcases superior shooting mechanics, dismemberment that incorporates itself into the gameplay, and stunning graphics that immerse players in its haunting atmosphere.

Final Fantasy XIII, while a different genre, introduces the paradigm shift mechanic, showcasing innovative gameplay. While Fallout 3 struggles with antiquated combat, FF13's dynamic system offers a refreshing and strategic approach to battles, highlighting the stark contrast in game design evolution during that era.

Looking at other contemporaneous releases like MGS4 and Mass Effect, Fallout 3's shortcomings become even more apparent. Both games offer superior narrative depth, engaging gameplay mechanics, and graphical prowess, making Fallout 3 feel like a relic of its time.

In hindsight, Fallout 3 struggles to hold up against its peers and has been overshadowed by titles that have aged far more gracefully. While nostalgia may cast a favorable light on this title, objectively assessing it alongside its 2008 counterparts reveals a game that falls short in the face of evolving industry standards.

Fallout 3 was my first game in the Fallout universe, and I enjoyed it so much that I wanted to go back and play Fallout and Fallout 2 to see where it all began.  Those are very different games, but worth playing in their own right, especially if you want to experience the history of the series.

Unlike previous titles in the series, you play the game from a first-person perspective (or an "over-the-shoulder" third-person perspective once you complete the tutorial).  Your early life in Vault 101 acts as a tutorial and character creator, as you configure attributes using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system (Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck).  You also learn how to use your Pip-Boy 3000.

Finally, you come of age and emerge from Vault 101 into the Capital Wasteland where your adventure begins.  Lots of quests and many, many side quests later (this is a Bethesda game, remember), you will achieve your goals.

This Game of the Year edition also includes all the DLC: Operation: Anchorage, The Pitt, Broken Steel, Point Lookout, and Mothership Zeta, which are all worth playing through.  Grab a Nuka-Cola and start exploring!

[h1] An Epic Adventure in the Wasteland Makes for an Unforgettable Experience [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition is an absolute must-play if you're a fan of post-apocalyptic role-playing games. This game takes you on an unforgettable journey through the ruins of Washington D.C. and showcases why the Fallout series is hailed as one of the best in the genre.

The open-world environment of Fallout 3 is truly a masterpiece. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny is astonishing, and exploring different locations never fails to be exciting. From abandoned subway tunnels to crumbling buildings, every area has a unique story to tell, making the wasteland feel alive and immersive.

The story is gripping and full of twists and turns. As the Lone Wanderer, your quest to find your missing father leads to uncovering a larger conspiracy that threatens the very existence of humanity. The choices you make can have lasting consequences, affecting the inhabitants of the wasteland and shaping the outcome of the game.

The gameplay mechanics are perfect for both newcomers and veterans of the series. The VATS system, which allows you to target specific body parts in combat, adds a tactical element to battles. Whether I chose to engage in intense firefights or stealthily take out enemies, the gameplay was always satisfying.

The Game of the Year Edition includes all the additional DLCs, which further enhance the gameplay experience. The extra missions, weapons, and armor provide more variety and extend the content, ensuring that you'll be engaged for countless hours.

Graphically, Fallout 3 may not match the standards of today's games, but the art style and the overall atmosphere make up for it. The desolate wasteland, accompanied by its eerie soundtrack, creates a sense of despair and survival that perfectly fits the post-apocalyptic theme.

Furthermore, the community's support and modding capabilities have allowed the game to age like fine wine.

Fallout 3 is a really good game - I've seen the first two games in videos, and I can say that Bethesda's takeover of the franchise was a good call. The GotY edition does well to incorporate all the DLC expansions made for the game; I found the post-game situation after the story's ending a good touch of keeping the title open-ended.

The game world offers a good lot to explore, the main characters and companions you meet are nicely made - I love the dog you get, along with one other you get later in the main story. The opening stages you go through are nicely setup as a tutorial and character customisation section, and I like the variety of side quests and small factions you encounter; I also like the choices you get to make and how they impact the ending of the game.

I'm glad you can play this well with a controller - the button layout is the same for the Xbox version, and its a lot nicer setup than the attempt for Elder Scrolls IV. My only gripe is the lack of achievements that I could get in the console version had.

Fallout 3 wasn't an awful start for the IP's new owners, but it didn't wow the way it should have. Some of that is because of the technology of the time, but most of it still revolves around Bethesda's poor writing and baffling design decisions. The intro is very good and the world design is mostly compelling. There are few moments in gaming that equal stepping out of the vault for the first time and seeing DC in the distance. Yet that's also immediately where the problems start. Combat in this game is awful. The concept of VATS is brilliant and was a great bridge between the older games and the new ones, but it's also basically easy mode and not so much a tactical option the way it should have been. There's surprisingly little content in the vanilla game compared to the Elder Scrolls series despite similar dev times and so much of what is there alternates between bad and silly. Did they really think things like collecting bottle caps for a lady in a shack was compelling content? There are a few great quests and some of the DLC is very good, but mostly it feels like filler. The main story is fun to go through and the ending is iconic, but it's also one of the worst overall storylines in gaming if you even have a middle school level grasp of science. You don't need a magical fusion machine to clean water of radioactivity, you just need a few feet of dirt. That and it's not likely there would still be radiation like that in the area after all that time in the way they portray it. I'm not looking for ultra realism, but I am looking for something of the most basic quality and intelligence. I got the game at release and despite what Steam shows, I have probably three full playthroughs of this game. One vanilla, and a couple with all the DLC. I admit that on release, this would have probably gotten a positive review from me, but time and experience have soured me on just how small and badly done this game was and is today. If you're a fan of the IP then yeah it's probably worth a few bucks with all the DLC, but I could never be convinced this is a great game.

Game requires xlive.dll, but it's not shipped with that DLL (and to add to the fun, the error message is suppressed when launched by the launcher).

Then, the game crashes all the time in buildings, e.g. Megaton. This can be fixed by setting

bUseThreadedAI=1
iNumHWThreads=2

in fallout.ini.

I kinda expect Bethesda to make those (ultimately simple) fixes to the stock game. While the later might be hardware-dependent, there is no excuse for not shipping that DLL.

Dived into fixing this pos again and got it run in the end. Here is what I did. Results may vary.

I re-downloaded the whole thing and no surprise it didn't work. Plus most online tips are the same lazy generic 2000-ish copy paste compatibility and driver bs that does nothing on it's own.

BUT:
After some poking around I found a tip that the Fallout.ini in documents\my games\fallout 3 may be or is broken and if replaced with renamed Fallout_default.ini from steam\steamapps\common\fallout 3 goty and setting the Fallout.exe to run in compatibility mode for Win Vista SP2 it could work. AND IT DID WORK! Now the game runs. At least for me.

BROKEN AUDIO:
Sametimes the game stops or from the start won't play some sounds like reloads or footsteps. These are directed to the center speaker so you need a 2.1 (or more) capable speakers. W11 is very good at detecting what you use like basic headphones or speakers and sets them to 2.0. I haven't found a way to change that setting like the old sound cards could. Only option is the software simulated surround sound but those suck.

Now to get mods running:
The base game has been patched to 1704 which removed GFWL but added some new encryption or something. W/e. It broke mods. Most importantly FOSE which needs 1703 to run. Now there is a a Fallout Anniversary Patcher mod that downgrades the exe to 03 but I had no luck with it as FOSE didn't recognised the patched exe.
BUT!
I found a video on YT: watch?v=1CwW03B8Mr8&ab_channel=StayRetro (MVP!) This guy uploaded the original 1703 exe so if "FAP" ain't doin' it fo' ya' get those! FOSE will also want to be ran as admin. It's a Vista thing. It'll tell you if you forget.
Now the not-so-fun part. Mix mods to make the game not look like a smeared poop while having it run at least semi-stable.
Good luck.

Bethesda's first entry in the Fallout series! My history with this game was interesting, as New Vegas was my first Fallout game and after loving that, I got this game and was a little disappointed by it at first. In comparison to NV, I didn't like how the metro tunnels were the main way to travel around the city, the repair skill being tied to weapon degradation, is logical to me now but back then I was so used to the streamlined nature of NV. But playing through it recently to get the platinum made me appreciate it more. 

To start with the good, the story while straight forward is very enjoyable to play through, with Liam Neeson voicing your characters father to add that extra zing. The go where you want, do whatever you want mentality from Bethesda works well here, as you have a vast world to explore and fantastic side characters to meet along the way! The side quests are where the game shines, as that is really where the roleplaying aspect comes in (something Bethesda would sadly slowly move away from), as you can be good or evil, it really is up to you! The combat is basic but I don't really play these types of games for super-smooth combat, rather for satisfying roleplaying gameplay. VATS helps a lot in combat though as using it to blow enemies limbs off never gets old! Overall this game is a good balance of streamlined RPG mechanics but still feeling like a good roleplaying experience compared to later entries in this series. 

As for the bad: the main story while enjoyable is very black & white and is probably the most linear aspect of this game. While there are multiple ways to approach and end side quests, the main questline forces you to be the good guy and doesn't allow for any real choice and consequence. The Brotherhood of Steel are the good guys and the Enclave are the bad guys, that's it, you have no say in the matter. The open endness of this game also works against it sometimes, as in my original playthrough, while I was exploring the wastes, I found an area where one of the later main quests takes place, I entered and ended up starting the main questline there essentially, missing out on some of the earlier main missions (and their achievements). The game is also very buggy, especially on PS3, where you will run into multiple crashes and bugs the more you play. My copy of the game is pretty much broken as no matter what I do (uninstalling the game, starting a new game, deleting my save data etc..) I can't play the game at all for 2 minutes without it crashing completely. I had to end up borrowing a friends copy of the game so that I could continue to pursue the platinum. Also, the other main issue, is how OP your character can get; from having more skill points whenever you level up (in comparison to NV); the ability to increase those skill points to over 20 and the fact that you can get a perk point every level, makes your character really overpowered and playing a specialised role difficult. I understand Bethesda wants you to be able to be a jack of all trades in their games, but I personally prefer a system where I have to make tough choices when building my character, which gives the game more replay value in my opinion. The Karama system is also weak as no matter how evil you be, you can always fix it by giving water bottles to hobos in the wasteland. Overall, though despite my gripes this is still a solid entry in the fallout series and I can definitely recommend it to fans; just be aware of buggy performance going in.

Lots of people say Fallout 3 isn't as good as New Vegas, and... they're not wrong. But Fallout 3 has some great moments, even if the story is somewhat lacking and there's not enough side quests. The biggest difference between this, and the original Fallout games (and New Vegas) to me is that choices in this game are pretty obviously good/evil, there's no morally "grey" choices (even one of the DLC, The Pitt, which advertised itself as a return to morally grey choices, really ends with a choice between freedom and chaos versus tyranny and order, which is pretty common video game theme).

That first step out of the vault is really something and still holds up today, the tutorial is neat (but tedious on a second play-through). The game looks its age of almost 15 years old, but because the wasteland is supposed to be desolate, it's not too bad, really. Exploring the desolated Washington DC area and sneaking through ruined metro stations to get around to see some devastated landmarks is really cool. 

The DLC is... fine. I had never bothered with it before and had to force myself to do it this time, and it was enjoyable but nothing special. But the game itself is fun, even if the gun play outside of VATS is basic (VATS is still cool though), and at high levels the enemies have a tedious amount of health. 

But man, some of those side quests and levels are still a lot of fun. And the most iconic quest ([spoiler]nuking Megaton[/spoiler]) is a top-ten evil play-through moment in ANY game. It's good to see the American dream of [spoiler]being such a NIMBY that you need to get rid of an entire settlement of people just because it ruins your view of the post-apocalyptic wasteland[/spoiler]is still alive and well.

So while Fallout 3 walked so that New Vegas could run, it's still an enjoyable walk, if not as good as its successor or the originals.

It starts off strong, but boils down to a shooting gallery with few compelling side quests and the linear main quest that retcons your character's moral compass which is already a linear binary good or evil. There's some fun to be had traveling these dark and harsh environments. The atmosphere is fantastic. And although deeply flawed, the main quest isn't all too boring. This game isn't void of some enjoyment and immersion, but what it is void of, is all the deep complex roleplaying, decision making, story telling, writing, and moral ambiguity of Fallout 1, 2 and New Vegas. What used to be my favorite Fallout in the series, I've come to criticize it for the same issues I had with Fallout 4.

Reminder that the Fallout community can be/are rather elitist, especially online. ALL Fallout games are good. This one is no exception.

Yes, it may have not aged as great as New Vegas, such as having a lack of side quests, a rather polarizing plot, or not having refined the mechanics yet (its the first 3D Fallout, i mean). It's also glitchier than New Vegas, and may or may not even run on modern systems.

But this game feels very... humanitarian in a way.

Yes, the world is ruined, there are still sketchy people around, slavery is somehow back (it never left, unfortunately) and people that will outright kill you, but the main objective is finding your father, then choosing to purify the entire water supply of the Capital Wasteland (or not). I don't know, this game kind of gives me hope in humanity the same way Half-Life 2 does, maybe i am too emotional.

The atmosphere is amazing, while the Mojave Wasteland feels like a very glamourized view of the post-apocalypse, the Capital Wasteland feels so depressing, while also giving you that sensation of dread and fear, which kind of adds to the humanitarian touch of it, because the people there are still living or trying to, and it's rather beautiful. 

I feel like out of all DLCs, Mothership Zeta is the best one, as i wasn't too fond of Point Lookout and The Pitt. They were okay. Broken Steel is a nice welcome given how the vanilla sequence goes.

Maybe i am too biased, as i first played this in 2013, and i sucked at it, honestly, then i truly beat it at 2016, and it was fun. It was also my first Fallout game, maybe that explains it.

Revisiting it in 2022, i re-bought it in December at a somehow rather low point of my life, and i felt really happy playing it, to the point the radio songs feel so awfully nostalgic.

This game is an absolute classic. Even if you don't want to mod it, be sure to pick up the latest version of FOSE, along with some plugins for it, such as command extender, custom heap size, stutter remover, memory fix, and weapon lag fix. Installation is as simple as dragging and dropping some files. Also, the 4Gb VRAM patch with support for multi-core threading made this game run silky smooth for me. Normally, it doesn't like to run on more than one core without crashing. While you're at it, right click the .exe of the game, click properties, click the compatibility tab, and check the boxes for "run as administrator", "disable full-screen optimizations", and "run in compatibility mode for Windows XP Service Pack 3", then click apply and ok. It's also worth noting that Reshade works for this title when set to DirectX 9, which allows you to set up a custom ENB, thus greatly increasing graphical quality. Happy scaving, wanderers!

92/100 Initially, I wasn't sure if I would like this game or not. However, I was pleasantly suprised at how fun it was. It's just amazing how much detail went into creating Washington D.C. and the surrounding areas. Granted, the terrain and scaling may not be realistic, but as far as the cities, buildings, and monuments it's nearly identical. On another note, I've enjoyed the fact that the npc's / ai are fully voiced and actually talk to you compared to a wall of text (example: Morrowind). Story wise (as an alternate history / timeline, that's set in the future), it's very enjoyable and immersive. Because of this, you'll feel like you're actually there. As such, be prepared to easily lose track of time and spend 50 if not 100+ hrs in-game.

Cons: One may be disapointed with the poor performance of the fps targetting. So either use VATs, or download mods that fixes it. Mods are what make this game even more awesome. That being said, I recommend Fallout 3 nexus for mods.

This game is extremely buggy and borderline unplayable, even by Bethesda standards.  That alone warrants a negative review in my opinion.  This game is worth playing but the only real way to play it without a huge headache is through the TTW mod for New Vegas, it makes it stable and brings a bunch of much needed changes and features from NV.

Once you get into the actual game it's a pretty mixed bag.  There's so much about this game that clashes itself and contradicts itself.  It takes place 200 years after the nukes drops but it feels and looks like only a few decades have passed.  The atmosphere is probably the most praised thing about this game, and I do think it's really good but it doesn't feel earned by the game.  So many of the game's problems would be fixed if it took place sooner to the nukes, and it would actually make the atmosphere fit well.

The main story and quest line is horrible and by far the worst in the series.  The intro is slow, boring, and really accomplishes nothing.  The ending is even worse and insultingly stupid in my opinion.  They then locked the real ending behind a dlc.  It's astonishing they got away with this with so little controversy, if Fallout 4 did something like that you'd never hear the end of it.  The middle chunk of the main quest doesn't get nearly as bad but also isn't interesting, nor does it do anything special.  The Broken Steel stuff is mainly just combat but the quests are slightly more interesting than the base game ones, still nothing great.  There's only 1 ending for the game, 2 if you're being generous so there's really no replay value as far as the main quest is concerned.  You also never really feel like the main character but more like an apprentice to James and the Brotherhood.

The side content is the best part of the game, and from what I understand, is the reason Fallout 3 fans love the game.  There is actually quite a lot of interesting side content, most notably Harold's quest, which is probably the best and deepest in storytelling in the whole game.  A good chunk of the side quests are pretty generic but overall unoffensive.  I'll lump in the dlc here and say that the Pitt is the only good one.  Mothership Zeta and Operation Anchorage are terrible given this games combat (Anchorage might be bearable in TTW with NV's iron sights).  Point Lookout is fine but pretty generic and nothing special, I really don't get why people praise this dlc so much.  Broken Steel is also fine but it's a scam that it's a dlc in the first place. 

Another thing about the side content is that the poor world design really clashes with it.  The best content in the game is super easy to miss, and most people will never see it in their first, and likely only, playthrough.

My last big gripe is the rp opportunities.  Your story is set in stone and is very boring.  You can either be a saint or cartoonishly evil, with not much in between.  There's really not much room to make a morally grey character, which is one of the most interesting ways to play rpgs in my opinion. 

I have huge issues with the factions as well but this review is already unnecessarily long.

Title: A Post-Apocalyptic Masterpiece

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition (GOTY) stands as a testament to timeless gaming experiences. As a longtime fan of the Fallout series, I was absolutely blown away by the immersive world, captivating storytelling, and endless exploration this game offers.

The desolate wasteland of post-apocalyptic Washington, D.C. is beautifully crafted, showcasing a hauntingly gorgeous blend of destruction and rebirth. The attention to detail is astonishing, from the crumbling ruins of iconic landmarks to the eerie, irradiated landscapes that beg to be explored. Each location tells its own tragic story, painting a vivid picture of the world before and after the nuclear devastation.

One of the game's strongest suits is its narrative depth. From the moment you emerge from Vault 101 into the unforgiving wasteland, you're thrown into a whirlwind of personal discovery and moral choices. The characters you encounter are memorable, each with their own unique stories, motives, and flaws. The choices you make ripple through the wasteland, affecting the world and its inhabitants in profound ways. Whether you choose to be a selfless savior or a ruthless mercenary, every decision feels impactful.

The inclusion of all the expansion packs in the Game of the Year Edition adds tremendous value to the experience. Broken Steel, Operation: Anchorage, The Pitt, Point Lookout, and Mothership Zeta each bring new areas to explore, quests to complete, and challenges to overcome. These expansions seamlessly integrate with the base game, enriching the overall narrative and providing hours of additional gameplay.

The gameplay mechanics strike a balance between role-playing and action, allowing you to tailor your character's skills, attributes, and playstyle. The V.A.T.S. system, which lets you target specific body parts in a turn-based manner, adds a strategic layer to the combat and gives you a cinematic view of your actions. Whether you prefer engaging in intense firefights or negotiating your way through conflicts, Fallout 3 caters to a variety of playstyles.

While Fallout 3: GOTY is a masterpiece, it's not without its quirks. Some technical issues and occasional crashes can disrupt the experience, but the sheer brilliance of the game overshadows these minor hiccups.

In conclusion, Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition remains a crowning achievement in the world of gaming. Its rich storytelling, immersive world, and endless opportunities for exploration make it an essential addition to any gamer's library. Whether you're a fan of RPGs, post-apocalyptic settings, or simply outstanding storytelling, this game is an absolute must-play.
