The only knock I ever had against Fallout 3 was the original, pre-DLC ending, which had to rank in the Top 5 worst endings in gaming history.  Such a bummer! I still remember it like it was yesterday, as my young son (who sat through most of the game while I played it) and I just stared at the screen in shock and horror.  

Well thankfully, those days are long gone, and since the advent of Broken Steel, that atrocious ending is no longer an issue.  Now we can just concentrate on the game as it was first designed, and it was a beauty.  Although I am still partial to FNV as the #1 Fallout game, Fallout 3 does not rank all that far behind.  There are loads of quests, places to explore, decisions to make, and beasties to kill, to keep you occupied for hundreds of hours. And with the addition of Broken Steel, the level cap got jacked up to 30, making the experience even better and longer lasting.  

Not to say that F3 is a perfect game.  It does have some shortfalls that were greatly improved in FNV.  The biggest for me is the economy.   Quite frankly, though you can make a ton of money if you set your mind to it, there is simply nothing worth buying.  All those thousand of caps are mostly used simply to keep stocked up on ammo, stimpaks and drugs.  There are no elaborate, super expensive weapons such as you can save up for in FNV.  The merchants just carry the same old gear and weapons, which you really don't need, since you can get all you need from drops.  

The Main Quest line is also a bit too linear in F3, particularly as compared to FNV.  Without giving anything away as spoilers, your basic choice is to be evil or good.  There are no factions per se in F3, not like there is in FNV, only your karma as either a goodie two-shoes, a neutral onlooker, or an evil psychopath,and everything plays off of that.  Once you choose the Karma path you are going to take, the Main Quest just falls into place.   This is not to say that the game doesn't have depth. As I said earlier, you can spend dozens, if not hundreds of hours exploring the depth of this game, and you still may find something you'd never discovered before on your next playthrough.  

One of the best games ever produced, Fallout 3 is still well worth playing in 2023.

[h1]Finally got it working[/h1] 


[b]Important note[/b]
 
For some reason the game crashes on my solid state drive, but not on my hard drive.  


[u][b]What liked about the game[/b][/u]
[list] 
[*]	I loved exploring the Capital Wasteland. I really like the retro-futuristic look. I enjoyed seeing all the robots, nuclear powered cars, power-armor and etc. Throughout the game you will be exploring abandoned Factories, military bases, hotels, museums and etc.  There are so many places to visit and secrets to find. I really enjoyed finding and reading notes, emails, and also listening to recordings.

[*]	The combat is a lot of fun. I like how you can turn enemies into big chunks of gore. The Vats system is a nice addition when in combat.

[*]	A nice selection of weapons. I really like the Davy Crockett inspired nuke launcher. 

[*]	I enjoyed the story for what it was. The main story quest has some really cool memorable moments. Fallout 3 has some awesome side-quests like Oasis, The Superhuman Gambit, Blood ties, and the Wasteland Survival Guide. 

[*]	The game has some really cool enemies, like the Deathclaws.

[*]	 I love the games 1950s sci-fi references, for example, the Protectron being based off Robby the robot from Forbidden planet or the Mirelurk king being based of The Creature from the Black Lagoon.

[*]	Brilliant soundtrack.  When I’m exploring the wasteland, I will play Galaxy News Radio in the background.

[*]	I like the games leveling-up and perk system. The game has some really cool perks, like Bloody Mess, Mysterious stranger, and Animal Friend.  

[*]	I like that you can own a property and also customize it. I also think it’s really cool that you can make weapons out of junk. 

[*]	Fallout 3 also has some kickass DLC, like Point Lookout and The Pitt. 

[u][b]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/b][/u] 

[*]	Fallout 3 is very rough around the edges. You will find textures missing, objects clipping through each other, Galaxy news reporting news that hasn’t happened. 

[*]	The main quest line is a bit short. The game could have done with a few more side-quests, especially ones tailored for evil players. 

[*]	I feel that some parts of fallout 3 could have done with a bit more content, like energy weapons, workbench, dialogue and etc. It’s also a shame that unique weapons look the same as the normal versions. 
[/list]
[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]
 
In my opinion, Bethesda has done a fantastic job making the third Fallout game into a 1st/3rd person shooter. Unfortunately I could never get into Fallout 1 and 2, because I am not a big fan of turn-base games.  I really enjoyed exploring the retro-futuristic wasteland and the combat is a lot of fun. It’s a shame that some people to this day are still having trouble getting this game working and like I said before the game is very rough around the edges. If you enjoy games like Borderlands, Mad Max or Rage, then I highly recommend you buy this game.   

[h1]9/10[/h1]

I recently revisited this game after a few years. I originally gave a negative review, mainly because I thought that it was an okay game but overrated. I decided to give it another chance and came to the conclusion that it's worse than I remember in many aspects. My main gripes are with the gameplay, the main story, and atmosphere.

The gunplay is way worse than I remembered. Massive, uncontrollable spread and little to no feedback on hits makes shooting feel impotent. I can't count the number of times that I line up the sights (metaphorically, since there is no aim down sights) at an enemy at medium range, only to see the bullets miss by a few feet. Very unsatisfying, save the occasions in which the enemy gibs.

The story is pretty simple and lacks meaningful choice and nuance. Without spoiling anything, the main story only really comes down to doing helpful thing to wasteland or doing harmful thing to wasteland. All other choices essentially lead to the same outcome. I'm not complaining that there are multiple ways of completing the main quests, more that a lot of the choices are framed in a way that it makes you think you're making a difference, when in reality, you aren’t, and the outcome is the same.

Finally, I'm not a fan of the game's atmosphere. A lot of the locations of the game just seem contrived. They have no reason exist and are just there for the sake of "wouldn't it be cool/funny if...". As such, the outlandish premise of many of the locations seems to matter more than their believability. I don't mind that a place has an unusual premise, but it would be for the place to also be somewhat grounded in reality. This is more of an opinion, but it's just too wacky and zany for what I'd like to see in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. 

I also think its bad for more reasons than I have already listed, but I am not trying to write a massive analytic essay, just my main issues.

If you like the game, more power to you, but I think the game has some big, objective flaws that shouldn't be overlooked and shouldn't deserve apologetics to explain them away.

Played this game a great deal on Xbox 360. On PC (Steam Deck), it is a steaming pile of goat feces. Why? My game saves randomly disappear and stop working. I never know when I will log in to play and the only option is to start a new game. I go into the game files on desktop and I see my saves in the folder, but they do not read. BUYERS BEWARE. This game does NOT have cloud saves, like New Vegas, 4, and 76. I have searched online for a fix and no one knows. Just beware or find a valid way to back up your saves manually.

FYI this game works right out of the box on Steam Deck, just remember to back up your save before uninstalling the game.

When playing on PC, if the game doesn't launch when you press Play, type "graphics settings" in your search bar on Windows, and add Fallout 3 as well as the Fallout 3 Launcher to the program list. Then change them to high performance, then it should launch. When modding, I highly recommend Mod Organizer 2. Install the Anniversary Patcher. Make sure you make the MO2 instance portable so you can add this command in the Fallout 3 launch options on Steam:

"<path to MO2 here>\ModOrganizer.exe" "moshortcut://:Fallout 3" %command%

With this command, you will be able to launch Fallout 3 via steam but the game will still start on MO2, meaning that you can both play with mods as well as have your playtime recorded. In that part that says <path to MO2 here>, just copy the path from wherever you MO2 is installed. It's installed on my D drive which is not the default location so I didn't put my path.

Finally, if you are having any miscellaneous problems (such as lip syncing audio issues), you have to cap the FPS to 60. You can do this in Nvidia Control Panel.

For context - I’ve beaten every quest, cleared every location, collected every unique item, and so feel pretty confident in saying I’ve completed this game 100%. This game has aged, but it’s still great. Now that I’ve played the Interplay Fallout games as well, it’s impressive how this manages to translate the feel of those games into a 3D, first person style. The world is massive, especially for the time, though unfortunately a lot of it feels empty - which does fit for a nuclear wasteland, but isn’t great to play. The gunplay is really not great (you can’t even aim down the sights on most guns) but it’s serviceable, and I feel like the quests and exploration are the main appeal here, and they’re great! This is a classic RPG, super influential to the series and, despite these caveats, I recommend it. Especially now it’s excised the tumour that is Games for Windows Live. Also, the DLCs are worth getting. I wouldn’t say any of them are amazing, but none of them are dreadful either.

[i]Italics[/i] contain all of the original content of this review I've added.

[b]ADDED [08/02/23]:[/b] [i]IF YOU HAVE NOT BOUGHT NEW VEGAS, COMPLETE THIS GAME FIRST AND THEN NEW VEGAS! I've seen many people say that playing Fallout 3 before New Vegas made them appreciate both games more.[/i]

Just like Fallout New Vegas minus a few features and some different tweaks to the game. [i]A lot of things are the same, but a lot of things are different. If you've played New Vegas, you'll be aware of how different the game's mechanics are is from the jump.[/i]

[b]EDITED [08/02/23]:[/b] For example, you can't make Stimpaks or drugs at Chemistry stations. The workbench is different (can't recycle stuff/craft bullets/etc.) It's a weapons only crafting bench [i](you can only craft certain special weapons here)[/i]. The story of the game is different, but the mechanics are still there. [i]It does connect to New Vegas' story, and if you play Fallout 4, you'll see some references to some of the people in this story. Different perks/skills than F:NV. Compared to New Vegas, there aren't as many secrets to look around for, nor does this game have the amount of missions that New Vegas has. The karma system is vastly different here, and it affects the companions you travel with. You don't have reputations from factions, but you do have karma based on what you do. Some companions will only travel with you if you have negative karma and vice versa.[/i]

Still a good game, though. I know some of these reviewers have had issues with crashing, which put me off of the game for a while (because what if it just crashed after I bought it? There's no purpose there.) But, it hasn't crashed on me once, so I don't know what the difference is there. A good buy. I like it. [i]I know Fallout 3 and NV have issues with crashing, but both of them behave fairly well for me.[/i]

[b]ADDED [08/02/23]:[/b] [i]For New Vegas, which is very prone to crashing like Fallout 3 is, I run it under Viva New Vegas modifications. The same modders who put that together also have something that combines Fallout 3 and NV called Tale of Two Wastelands! They also have made a Skyrim mod set and a Fallout 4 moderation set. Moderation in the Fallout community is HUGE. If it doesn't work for you, please go hunting for some mods to increase the quality and try those out before you refund this game. Same goes for NV. These modders often have very active Discord servers and simply require a crash log to tell you what happened with your game.[/i]

[b]ADDED [09/19/22]:[/b] Another thing I forgot to mention! Steam DOES NOT have achievements for this game. This is kind of a bummer, but it's okay. It wasn't a deal-breaker for me personally, but I do know people love achievements. 

[b]ADDED [09/21/22]:[/b] If you complete the the downloadable content that adds The Pitt to the game, you get access to a way to craft more ammo, so not all is lost, I guess.

When Bethesda inherited the Fallout franchise from Interplay, a lot of people were like, "Oh, cool. I guess I'll bury my love for yet another venerable gaming franchise in the same shallow grave I've been using to dispose of Electronic Arts' innumerable victims." As gamers, we expect the worst because that's what we've been conditioned to expect. But every so often, we're wrong, and a new developer/publisher violently disgorges from their money-stuffed orifices a glittering gem rather than a reeking turd. Fallout 3 might look a bit like a turd (no one's going to be winning any awards for graphical fidelity here), but the joy to be found in exploring its countless nooks and crannies remains very real, even in 2023.

After the mandatory intro cinematic, during which Ron Perlman once again growls his way through a "War... war never changes!" monologue, you're introduced to the sphincter-clenching horrors of first-person childbirth. Worse, you're forced to listen to Liam Neeson's profoundly disturbing performance as your father. I've played this game several times since it was first released, and every time I'm compelled to listen to Neeson dribble his way through "Hey there, little guy! I'm your Daddy!", it makes me want to hurt myself. However, it's a necessary evil as during these birth/childhood/adolescence montages you create your character, selecting from a limited variety of unattractive faces and hilariously bad hairstyles, assigning your SPECIAL attributes (Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck), picking three favoured skills (anything from energy weapons to hacking computer terminals), after which you're shown how to use a weapon.

All of this takes place inside a Vault-Tec nuclear fallout shelter, or 'vault' as they're commonly known. Safe from the predations of raiders, feral ghouls, slavers, mutated wildlife, and supermutants, you grow to adulthood in blissful ignorance of the numberless horrors that await you in... the Capital Wasteland. Until one day, when you wake up to discover the entire vault has gone insane and your dear old dad has done a runner. (That's some stellar parenting there, Neeson, you deadbeat.) Anyway, after a bit of radroach murdering, police brutality at the hands of vault security, sneaking, thieving, and an awkward conversation with the Vault Overseer's daughter, Amala, during which you essentially say, "Your father is a horrible fascist, and I'm leaving you here to deal with the blood-soaked aftermath of the collapse of his tyrannical regime!", you leg it to the exit and emerge into the radioactive glare of Washington DC circa 2277. And Christ on a bike, has this place seen better days, or what?!

No, really, both graphically and given you're dealing with the aftermath of global nuclear war, the whole place looks... bad. First, the snot-green filter Bethesda smeared across the proceedings like a fistful of Vaseline -- it's not a good look. I get they were going for post-apocalyptic ruin with a dash of atmosphere-clogging radioactive fallout, but all it really does is make the game look like someone's been messing with the RGB slider. Everything looks dreary and oppressive. DO. NOT. LIKE. You will get used to it and it doesn't detract from the gameplay, but the colour palette is nowhere near as vibrant as either New Vegas or Fallout 4.

The wasteland itself, with its shattered houses, burned-out cars, stagnant pools of noxious water, and charred and blackened trees, still holds up fairly well considering the game was released in 2008. As you might expect, there are some fairly primitive 3D models and some of the textures look as though someone has up-ended a bowl of porridge all over your screen, but taken as a whole the game won't make your eyes bleed or induce nausea and vomiting. (Although, you may want to tweak the HDR lighting and bloom settings because it likes to stab you in the corneas during sunrise and sunset, and whenever you use the torch on your Pip-Boy.) Temper your expectations. You're dealing with an old-timer here, and back in his day there was none of that new-fangled graphical wizardry with which you kids are so enamoured. Ray-tracing? Hahahahaha... get out of here.

Right, so you're out of the vault and off you trudge to look for your absentee parent. First stop; Megaton -- a rickety settlement erected around a live nuclear bomb because, you know, who needs scenic coastal views when you could instead live with the ever-present risk of being vapourised whenever someone sneezes.  It's here the game opens up and allows you to go wherever you like, whenever you like, interacting with whomever you like along the way. There are some introductory quests to pick up as a way of easing you into the core gameplay loop, but you're largely left to your own devices. Which is as it should be because if Bethesda do anything well (apart from hilarious physics glitches), it's environmental storytelling.

The Capital Wasteland is vast and fairly teeming with caves, ruins, bunkers, settlements, abandoned factories and ghoul-infested subway tunnels. There's always somewhere new to explore and something interesting to find. You'll encounter hastily-scrawled notes from long-dead residents, dust-covered terminals detailing secret military projects and shocking corporate malfeasance, and grisly scenes illustrated only through the use of props -- the skeletons of children in the ruins of Springdale Elementary, or a family who sat down to breakfast seconds before the atomic shockwave stripped the flesh from their bones. The world of Fallout might be full of robot butlers and retro-futuristic satire, but it's also a relentlessly bleak and often cruel place. (And genuinely unnerving. Stay away from the Dunwich Building. You have been warned.)

If you're used to the fast, responsive combat of Fallout 4, brace yourself for some clunky old-world jank. No iron sights for you, young man, although VATS does freeze enemies completely while you line up a shot, which is something Fallout 4 "improved". Enemies will explode into red mist and juicy gobbets of viscera when you drop the hammer, and all your favourites are here -- powerfists, supersledges, lasers, plasmas, missile launchers, flamers, a host of ballistic weapons, and of course the trusty Fatman for when a scorched earth policy is the order of the day. Also, power armour... but you need a special perk in order to use it.

Speaking of perks, whenever you level up you earn a perk and a bunch of skill points. The higher your intelligence score, the more skill points you'll have to distribute each time you gain a level, so if you're going to favour any of your SPECIAL attributes from the beginning, make it intelligence. Because this is the GOTY version of Fallout 3 which includes all of the DLC, your level caps out at 30. You will likely hit the level cap long before you exhaust everything on offer here. From memory, I completed three of the DLCs and about half of the main quest line prior to hitting the cap, and I still had vast swathes of the map to explore.

Once character progression is a thing of the past, your incentive to keep playing is basically down to how much you enjoy the exploration and narrative. If your sole reason for playing is the acquisition of "MOAR POWER!", then you're going to be a little disheartened and your interest may wane. What doesn't wane is the level of challenge even at higher levels. Those hillbilly mutants in the Point Lookout DLC will mess you up.

Fallout 3 in 2023 may look like something your dog regurgitated onto the living room carpet, but it tells a compelling story in an enthralling world where what you do genuinely matters. It doesn't have all the quality of life features of its successors, but this in no way detracts from the countless hours you'll spend trundling about the Capital Wasteland gibbing supermutants and radscorpions. Recommended.

[h1]Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition[/h1]
Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is the first game in the series in 3D, taking us to Washington D.C. and the surrounding area. The game of the year edition, includes all DLCs and minor improvements. Don't pay attention to my play counter, because for some reason, the game only counts hours when the launcher is active, not the game itself.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
We start the game as a resident of Vault 101, and we get used to it by jumping between events from our childhood; first steps and conversations with dad, our tenth birthday and receiving the Pip-Boy, and the exam to determine our role in the Vault. Each of these segments is full of optional conversations with Dad, our peers, and other residents. It's a short and at first glance boring intro, but it makes us more attached to the people around us (mainly dad), and our character is much more believable. Our dad is also played by Liam Neeson, so he automatically becomes the best character in the game. Leaving the Vault, story-wise, we don't have many options, and it's quite linear and predictable, but in its simplicity, it's effective, and it's enjoyable to experience it along with the interactions with the main characters. And to expand on my earlier thought about the linearity of the plot, there is no faction system here like in Fallout: New Vegas, so the game specifically draws us to one faction, the plot of which will be continued in Fallout 4.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Starting from the beginning, the game definitely focuses on the destructiveness of war. Compared to Washington, New Vegas is heaven on earth. The capital city is completely destroyed, full of rubble, destroyed buildings, vehicles, craters, etc., which I really liked. You can really feel the brutality and destruction that a nuclear war can cause. The map is large, apart from Washington itself (full of interesting buildings with unique interiors), it also gives us a large part of the surrounding area, which is full of dilapidated smaller towns, factories, roads, etc. Each of these locations is interesting to explore, so it's hard to get bored. Coming to the quests, they're solid, they're not brilliant, but they're not bad either, they're okay, short, and fun. Our arsenal of weapons and armor is impressive, but it does not overwhelm us. Well, it may sometimes feel that more of them would be useful, but it's not bad, each piece of equipment can be used in different ways when fighting the large number of potential opponents that the game presents us with. However, there is one thing that is bugging me, and that is the subway system. Possibly due to technical issues, the developers figured out, that Washington would be divided into a lot of separate sections (due to suspiciously stable walls of rubble), so we have to use the subway tunnels every now and then, which are terribly large, monotonous and boring. In addition to the fact that it slows down our progress, it's also, tiring, and sometimes even the game doesn't know what to do with it, so the markers stop working, and we cuddle up to every wall in the whole city, praying to find a way to our goal. Finally, I want to describe the character skills/perks system, which is solid, but it has its problems. There are many skills in the game that, apart from the usual bonuses, also give us new dialogue options. However, it seems to me that the perks were done by force, a large number of them are boring numerical bonuses to statistics and skills, and unlocking them through level ups does not give us any satisfaction.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
The reason why this game broke me a little bit. Starting with the graphics, they're okay, nothing special, and the greenish filter makes everything look like vomit, but it could have been worse, and it adds a bit of vibe and charm. The voice actors did a solid job, but as I said before, Liam Neeson blew away the competition. Moving on to the music, as usual, I'm very positively surprised here, exploration without the radio is full of dark grunts and sounds, but when it comes to the radio, it has a great range of music from around the 60s, and it's great to listen to, although personally I prefer Fallout: New Vegas music anyway. But let's end with the worst, i.e. stability and bugs. During gameplay, quests often break irreversibly, due to the fact that the game simply doesn't know what to do when we do things in our order, and the stupid AI certainly doesn't help when the quests finally work anyway. Basically everything is twisted and buggy here, once on the radio I even heard the main presenter talk about events that haven't happened yet, so it really broke my immersion. And ending with stability, the game crashes very often. While playing the game, it would freeze at least three times within an hour, and it's not a typical crash where it throws you to the desktop and you can quickly go back, but it's a complete computer freeze, so I had to restart the whole PC every time. These crashes, apart from frequency, are also completely random so at some point I just gave up.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
Great game, but it's barely keeping up with the time pressure and definitely needs a Remaster or Remake. Despite the lazy efforts of the developers, the game barely works without mods, and unfortunately I don't have the strength to go through all the DLCs, accompanied by constant crashes. I will say this; if you're ready to install mods or spend hours on YT and in game files to make everything work, then I'd definitely recommend buying it, but if for whatever reason you don't want to mess around with all of this, then you'd better not waste your money. It's a real shame, that this game gave me so much trouble, because Fallout in Washington D.C. is my dream location for a game in the series (although to this day I'm most interested in what New York looks like in this universe, but with Bethesda working on their games at the speed of a lobotomy patient, I doubt that the next Fallout will be made in my lifetime, so I probably won't know).

In Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition, you emerge from Vault 101 into the desolate Capital Wasteland. As the Lone Wanderer, you embark on a perilous journey to find your missing father and uncover the secrets of the post-apocalyptic world. Along the way, you encounter various factions, mutated creatures, and moral dilemmas. Your choices shape the outcome of the story, as you navigate a treacherous wasteland, confront the remnants of society, and ultimately determine the fate of the Capital Wasteland.

Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is an exceptional gaming experience that transports players into a post-apocalyptic wasteland like no other. While it does have its share of technical challenges, the game's incredible story, immersive gameplay, and vast world make it a must-play for any fan of the genre.

Let's address the elephant in the room first: the installation issues. Some players may encounter difficulties during the installation process. However, with a little persistence and a quick online search for fixes, you can overcome this hurdle and enter a world that will undoubtedly captivate you for hours on end.

One area where Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition shows its age is in the graphics department. Released in 2008, the visuals may not be as polished or detailed as modern titles. Nevertheless, it's important to remember that this is a remastered version of the original game, and despite the slightly dated graphics, the art direction and attention to detail still shine through. The desolate wasteland of Washington, D.C., and the crumbling ruins of iconic landmarks are eerily atmospheric, drawing you deeper into the post-apocalyptic world.

What truly sets Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition apart is its gripping storyline. From the moment you step out of Vault 101 and enter the vast Capital Wasteland, you're thrown into a struggle for survival, discovery, and the search for your character's purpose. The game excels in delivering an emotionally charged narrative, filled with moral dilemmas, memorable characters, and unexpected twists. The choices you make throughout the game have lasting consequences, adding layers of depth and meaning to your journey.

The gameplay mechanics in Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition offer a seamless blend of first-person shooting, role-playing elements, and exploration. The V.A.T.S. (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) adds a tactical element to combat, allowing you to target specific body parts with calculated precision. The variety of weapons, armor, and perks available ensure that you can tailor your character to fit your preferred playstyle, be it a stealthy sniper or a brawling powerhouse.

The open-world environment of Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition is a joy to explore. There's always something to discover, whether it's hidden underground vaults, long-forgotten military bases, or a settlement in need of your help. The sense of exploration and the thrill of stumbling upon a hidden treasure or uncovering a dark secret make every step forward an exciting and rewarding endeavor.

In addition to the main questline, the Game of the Year Edition includes all five expansion packs, providing hours of additional content. From the eerie atmosphere of Point Lookout to the high-tech escapades of Operation: Anchorage, each expansion offers a unique and immersive experience that expands upon the already rich world of Fallout 3.

While Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition may have its technical shortcomings and slightly dated graphics, its masterfully crafted story, engaging gameplay, and captivating world make it an unforgettable gaming experience. It's a testament to the timeless appeal of this post-apocalyptic RPG and an absolute must-play for fans of the genre. So, grab your Pip-Boy, step out into the wasteland, and prepare for an adventure that will leave a lasting impression.

Fallout 3, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, is an exceptional post-apocalyptic role-playing game that immerses players in a rich and sprawling world filled with danger, intrigue, and limitless possibilities. With its immersive storytelling, open-world exploration, and deep character progression, Fallout 3 stands as a true masterpiece that captures the essence of the beloved Fallout franchise while introducing captivating new elements.

The narrative of Fallout 3 is a triumph, setting players on an unforgettable journey through the desolate wasteland of post-nuclear Washington, D.C. The game excels in crafting a richly detailed and atmospheric world, teeming with morally ambiguous factions, intriguing side quests, and memorable characters. The main storyline presents a compelling quest for the player's character, known as the Lone Wanderer, as they navigate a treacherous landscape and uncover the secrets of their past. The choices you make along the way have significant consequences, allowing for a personalized and deeply immersive narrative experience.

Fallout 3's open-world exploration is a delight, presenting players with a vast and varied wasteland to discover. From the ruined remains of iconic landmarks to the hidden underground vaults and settlements, every location has a story to tell and secrets to uncover. The game strikes a perfect balance between a sense of desolation and discovery, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path and uncover hidden treasures, unique weapons, and memorable encounters. The sense of freedom and exploration in Fallout 3 is unparalleled, creating a sense of immersion and adventure that keeps players engaged for hours on end.

The character progression system in Fallout 3 is deep and rewarding, allowing players to customize their skills, attributes, and perks to suit their playstyle. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system, which governs character attributes such as Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck, adds depth and variety to character development. The choices you make in leveling up your character have a significant impact on gameplay, providing meaningful choices and allowing for diverse playstyles. Whether you prefer a charismatic smooth talker, a stealthy sniper, or a brute force powerhouse, Fallout 3 accommodates a wide range of approaches.

Visually, Fallout 3 presents a distinct and gritty art style that perfectly captures the post-apocalyptic setting. The wasteland is filled with desolate landscapes, dilapidated structures, and hauntingly beautiful vistas. The attention to detail is exceptional, with weather effects, radioactive zones, and the remnants of a once-thriving civilization adding to the immersive atmosphere. The musical score, featuring a mix of haunting melodies and iconic 1950s-inspired tunes, perfectly complements the game's tone and enhances the overall experience.

In conclusion, Fallout 3 is a true masterpiece that exemplifies the best of post-apocalyptic role-playing games. Its immersive storytelling, open-world exploration, deep character progression, and atmospheric world-building create an unforgettable experience. Bethesda Game Studios' commitment to crafting a rich and engaging world shines through in every aspect of the game. Whether you're a fan of the Fallout franchise or new to the series, Fallout 3 is a must-play title that offers countless hours of captivating gameplay and a world begging to be explored. Step into the wasteland and embark on an adventure that will leave a lasting impression.

Now while looks may be decieving, being only listed as 25 hours, i bought the game of the year edition when it first came out, and wore the disks out, so i bought it on Steam because i did not want to spend the time trying to hunt down new disks, but i degress...

Fallout 3 in of itself, when i started it, ran slow and was difficult for me, it was frustrating at first, but once i got a better computer, and monitor, the difference was amazing! Yes, this was not my old Fallout and Fallout 2, and in one case, i was as glad as fuck it was not Fallout Tactics. Eventually it grew on me, the story not as much, but the wasteland enviroment, the action, the having to look out for enemies as i least expected it, radiation around every corner, even the random enounters and respawning encounters always had me on my toes. It got to the point where i had to put the difficulty up to very hard everytime to have a good challenge, but i loved it as DC became a death trap of Feral Ghouls, Super Mutants, and Mirelurks. The DLC's were wonderful, some were weaker than the others, I will admit my favorite DLC's between this and New Vegas was in New Vegas, but each had their own unique fun, irregardless if they were good or not.

So to sum it up, for a first attempt, Bethesda really did good. Yes, they could have done better, a lot better. Story needs work, accurate map more based on real life road system would be nice, more variety in weapons, and mods for weapons without using mods, but it was a far better attempt at bring Fallout to a new audience, Better than New Vegas in my humble opinion, but not by much only because of the bugs, and how it can still be more difficult to survive here than in New Vegas. It was a good way to wait as well until i could catch a ride on the Prydwin to the Commonwealth, it was a lot closer to there.

Before i end this, i want to address one more thing, we need to stop this petty infighting in our Fallout community, and come together as one community. Yes, i love all the games, period, end of story, no one game is superior to another, and each game is flawed in their own way. So are humans, if i must remind you all, and if we cannot stop this pointless bickering, one day, we may not have another chance to go back to the wasteland, because our own great war destroyed it.

Alright then, I have been playing this game for 40 hours. I have played the main story line, as well as the DLCs for the brotherhood, Operation Anchorage, as well as The Pitt.

And my honest opinion is that it just isn't good. There are MANY reasons why, but they range from the voice acting being mid, the story just being very meh, as well as the mess that is the open world. There's a lot I could say, but in comparing it to New Vegas I'd say that NV was far more accessible.
The layout of New Vegas' open world meant that it was easy to find everything, as it was all centred around the main highways and the city of New Vegas itself. Exploring the Capital Wasteland is, at best, a disjointed maze. There are SO MANY LOCATIONS that are nowhere near the main quest line of the game, that unless you have the Explorer perk at level 20 I found that actually finding all the other locations in the game that weren't Megaton, Project Purity, the Museum of History or Rivet City it was all just WAY OUT THERE.

I'm not even sure if I'm explaining it right... but playing New Vegas came easy to me. Just by playing the main story I was completing most of the side quests along side, playing Fallout 3 I have had to actually go looking for all the side content. Which, for me, is bizarre.
Instead of completing the base game 100% like NV and then starting the DLCs, I've been playing the DLCs for Fallout 3 when most of the Capital Wasteland has been left undiscovered.

Not matter what though, I'm just not interested in the story behind Fallout 3. Exploring the Vaults, abandoned buildings and completing side quests just isn't interesting for me. I'm the kind of guy who played New Vegas for two months straight gathering HUNDREDS of hours, meanwhile I'm 40 hours into Fallout 3 and I already want to stop.

Not sure what else to say, but 3 isn't the worst game ever. It's just not interesting, the story is not compelling.. there's a reason why The Pitt DLC is talked more than anything else as it's the most compelling Fallout 3 has been with its stories.
I'm 40 hours in, but I just don't see myself returning when I've completed Point Lookout and Mothership Zeta.

This isn't hard to run anymore, as many reviews complain about. Bethesda patched out the GFWL nonsense and added compatibility with OSes that are actually supported by Microsoft. That's a hell of a lot more than most developers will do for a 15 year old game. All you need to do is install the unofficial patch and maybe limit the framerate to 72fps via your graphics drivers if you have a high refresh monitor. It's really not rocket science, and it's not like it's a fast game that would benefit from a high framerate, although there is something to be said against Bethesda games always requiring the user to essentially finish making the game that they purchased.

I really enjoyed this game but it is not perfect: 
Pros: 
I loved many of the side quests which really made the game worth playing, because without them the game feels much shorter. I'll just say a few I really enjoyed: Trouble on the Homefront (You return to the Vault to a civil war there), Oasis Quest (You meet the only green part of the world and decide the future of it which is stop it from growing, don't do anything, allow it to continue growing and maybe faster I think), Agatha's Guitar (You find this Grandma a Guitar and she plays you tones on the radio), GNR stuff (pretty much main story but whatever), GARYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY!!! 

The Tone of this game is crazy scary I felt genuinely fearful at the start with such low stimpaks and protection against what lurks there. Without the GNR radio station this game has an entirely different tone, one that is much more serious and scary while Three Dog got me jumping up and down to Jolly Days. 

Since this is game of the year I might as well talk about the DLCS: They are incredibly fun besides the alien ship one and im pretty mixed about the Anchorage Mission. But the Pitt, Broken Steel, and Point Lookout are very fun additions to the game.

Cons:

I did thoroughly enjoy this game but it does have it's caveats that I'll list out first. I've seen and read so many issues stemming from Windows 10/11 not running this properly. This game does have crashes, even on the Steam Deck, so do be prepared and have saves going regularly. It's nothing new, per say, but it is something to be prepared for when it comes to most Bethesda games. Additionally, I wish that Bethesda would've added the achievements from the old Games for Windows LIVE service that was deprecated.

Bugs and issues aside the game was absolutely great. It's a tough pick between this and New Vegas as my favorites. I didn't like the direction that Fallout 4 took where it's geared more towards base building, random weapon generation, and some other key elements that has slowly been stripping away the RPG elements in favor for more streamlined experiences. 

The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stat tree is a key element in the game relating to the RPG mechanics. If you've played previous Fallouts, you'll know what I mean. This game is a lot more bleak than the other titles that have came afterwards. Personally, feel this is more bleak than New Vegas, even if that game gets pretty heavy at times. This game feels a lot more isolated and alone than the others. The DC Wasteland is barren which is good or bad depending on who you are. There are a bevy of secrets littered about that you can find but they are scarce. Some may find it boring and tedious to do so but it's the exploration that makes it shine above the other titles.

The DC ruins has a lot more content packed in it compared to the Wasteland. The major cities, factions, and choices you make only make an impact at the end credits - for the most part. There are some choices that does effect the overall game but, for the most part, is minimal. Since this is the GoTY edition the end isn't as bad as the original was/is. That being said, I can't review the individual DLC as this is an all-in-one so here's my review of the DLC's I played in order:

[h2]Operation Anchorage:[/h2]
I really enjoyed this one. It was quick and linear. It never outlasted it's stay and had a decent storyline. The gear you obtained afterwards was spectacular and could be considered overpowered if you did this DLC at the suggested level of 10. I didn't run into any bugs throughout the playthrough.

[h2]Broken Steel:[/h2]
You pair up with the Brotherhood of Steel in this one to take out the remaining remnants of the Enclave. The suggested level to do this is somewhere in the range of 20+. You'll be around there by the time you beat the game, which is where you'd start this one up at. It's got great unique weapons, unique armor sets, unique location (and revisits old locations), and a storyline that is linear but does a good job at keeping things consistent and concise. It also upps the level cap to 30. Great DLC in terms of quality of life improvements.

[h2]Mothership Zeta:[/h2]
Hated this one. I recommend to not even go through this broken mess. I've had multitudes of bugs that made the game crash, teleporters that stopped working, corrupted a game save, and more. There is hardly a story. The weapons are cool, admittedly, but that's about it. The DLC outstays it's welcome and has so many repeating corridors that look exactly the same. It does have tougher enemy types but it's just a buggy shooting gallery.

[h2]The Pitt:[/h2]
From the onset it's a darker themed DLC. Personally, the darker themes are what draws me in so this was a fun one for me. There is a large amount of content in here. Custom armor sets, good main storyline, custom weapons, and varied new enemy/friendly types. Overall a great DLC that's worth your time. It is a depressing setting though but honestly if you've completed Fallout 3 I don't think that will bother you. I didn't like the steel ingot fetch quest for all of them but it's not required. The choices you make don't necessarily matter at the end either, which is neither good or bad

[h2]Point Lookout:[/h2]
This isn't as dark as The Pitt was and is by far the best DLC. This is truly an extension of Fallout 3, from my perspective. There are additional zones, varied new enemy types, new items, tons of new assets, custom weapons, armor, and multiple branching storylines throughout. It's clear this is the most worked on DLC out of all of them - or at least the one that has/had the most direction. Depending on who you are, this might not be for you. It's open world akin to Fallout 3 unlike the other DLC's which were more streamlined experiences (think Point A -> Point B). Some people prefer the DLC to be more focused and this one isn't but that's what makes this one my favorite.

[h2]DLC ranked:[/h2]
Point Lookout
The Pitt
Operation Anchorage
Broken Steel
Mothership Zeta

The third installment in the RPG based post-apocalyptic Fallout franchise developed by Bethesda, Fallout 3 takes place within Washington D.C. also known as the Capital Wasteland, 200 years after Fallout, and 36 years after Fallout 2, in the role of the Lone Wanderer, a vault dweller raised within Vault 101 before escaping to pursue his father. Fallout 3 is the first of the fallout franchise to become apart of the First-Person shooter genre, including an alternative Third-Person, adjustable camera capable of flying and rotating several feet around the player to get a better grasp of their surroundings, and a karma system that effects the outcome of character interactions, conversations, dialogue, in game choices, perks, and ending. Actions effect gameplay, resulting in either negative, or positive outcomes. There is very rarely ever one way approach to any given situation or scenario that is unavoidable, safe for the death of Liberty Prime in the DLC Broken Steel, and the death of James in the Washington Monument. Even with leveling up the maximum level cap of 20 to 30 in the DLC Broken Steel, it is impossible to gain every perk in the game, reinforcing the strategic value and priority of the players choice, further adding to the experience and replayability of the vast, barren and cruel wasteland of DC. Counting the abundance of content offered by the games several DLCs, Mothership Zeta, Broken Steel, The Pitt, Operation: Anchorage, and Point Lookout, the wasteland is full of hours worth of discoveries, whether it be discovering one of the six vaults hidden within the wasteland and their secret Vault-tec experiments, hidden unmarked caves, or even finding bobble heads hidden throughout Washington D.C. My only complaints of the game would have to be that the environments and atmosphere of Fallout 3 can become rather drab and dull at points. There is never enough Fallout 3, even with its replayabilty and discovery. I thoroughly enjoy my experiences of Fallout 3 on Xbox 360, PS3 and PC, (Despite its flawed launcher that requires personal patching) it is by far one of my favorite games I've ever played, and I would recommend this game for both new, and returning audiences of the Fallout franchise.

I think the base game is as good as the FNV base game, but for different reasons. I feel like the gameplay is much better and the capital wasteland is a more interesting location than the Mojave, the game does a great job at making the wasteland a big space, using the starting vault to do this. However in terms of story, this is what I find FNV does better than this game. There is actual factions and choice, unlike this game. That is why I feel that these games are equals, FNV has a better story, but Fallout 3 is better in terms of atmosphere and some gameplay aspects, but the lack of choice affects this game way too much. I give the base game a 8/10.

[h1] Operation Anchorage: [/h1]
A Frankenstein monster of Call of Duty and Fallout, this DLC is hard to judge. It isn't a fallout game because it is a linear shooter. The concept is interesting, being in a simulation playing one of the most important events in the Fallout timeline. However it just doesn't work because, well, they tried to do Call of Duty in, not Call of Duty. Great gear, though. 6/10.

[h1] Broken Steel: [/h1]
DLC is worth having for the after-game content, but the little story it adds is also adds is pretty good. Basically when trying to take out a group of Enclave, spoilers, Liberty Prime is killed. You spend the DLC trying to find what killed Prime, and then destroying what it was, or blowing up the citadel. The missions are pretty good, however there are only three. 7/10.

[h1] The Pitt: [/h1]
I struggle to see why The Pitt is held in such high regard. Although it has a fantastic premise, the execution is horrible. Nothing happens hear, there is nothing to talk about here. The moral dilemma, the characters act like it isn't one. Neat environment, neat premise, bad execution. I won't say it's bad and the gameplay can be good, but just prepare for something that you likely won't want to replay. 4/10.

[h1] Point Lookout: [/h1]
Easily the best DLC of Fallout 3, the atmosphere, the story, the main quest, gameplay, it's all great. You head to an island, and meet up with a ghoul named Desmond, before trying to find out why these tribals are attacking Desmond. The few problems this DLC has are the swampfolk being bullet sponges, and the fact that it still falls into the Fallout 3 trap of a lack of choice. 10/10.

[h1] Mothership Zeta: [/h1]
I might not be the person who should talk about this, but I actually really like Mothership Zeta. In all reality it has the same linear gameplay of Operation Anchorage, and little challenge, but I still find it fun. The characters aren't horrible, overall it's a middle of the road DLC with great gear. 7/10.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]
In all honesty, I think the base game, with Broken Steel, is the best of Fallout 3, it just works, as one man said.
Here's all the ratings:
[b] Base game: 8/10 [/b]
[b] Operation Anchorage: 6/10 [/b]
 [b] Broken Steel: 7/10 [/b]
[b] The Pitt: 4/10 [/b]
[b] Point Lookout: 10/10 [/b]
[b] Mothership Zeta: 7/10 [/b]

This game has not aged well. Firstly we must talk about the technical problems with installation, because in all likelyhood this hunk of junk will crash on start-up until you download a third party social program from Microsoft that is completely obsolete and no longer supported. There aren't even mods to circumvent this, some exist that graphically remove any trace of it from the menus, but if you want to play the game you have to install unrelated bloatware, that's the bottom line. 

As for the gameplay, there are MMO's with more interconnected questlines than this. Sure you can travel wherever you want from the start of the game but every location is like an independent universe. They have no impact on the wider world, save for what is said on the in-game radio. The locations themselves are cool, killing slavers with Abraham Lincoln's lever-action rifle is endlessly fun, but there are rarely any choices to be made outside being good or evil, there are very few grey areas to ponder. It is incredibly hard to acquire an evil rating on the in-game morality slider without actively murdering people in the street or doing one particular quest that bottoms out the scale, because you can gain "good" points for simply killing enemies. The attitude of the general populace will swing wildly if you ever switch between a good and evil reputation. Kill a few monsters and your the paradigm of all that's good with the world. Murder a civilian and the other civilians won't be afraid or even permanently hostile, they'll just make snide remarks around you. Do a good deed for someone on the opposite side of the map and suddenly your a saint again like nothing ever happened. The number of memorable characters in this game is less than five. 

Then there's the combat which wasn't good at the time and still feels like throwing broken pens in the vicinity of your enemies with a rubber band until they give up. Without DLC everything is stupidly easy past the first dozen or so hours and with DLC everything is brokenly hard by the endgame, forcing you to change the difficulty slider to the opposite end of the spectrum by three quarters through the game. 

Here's the most disappointing part, the world, which is usually the highlight of a Bethesda game, is terribly boring. Save for some small mountainous sections in the far northwest corner, the map is largely flat and featureless outside specific points of interest. Sure there are small knolls and gentle hills about the place, but none of it is memorable, save for the raised railway line, or impedes you ability to travel in a straight line from one place to the next. If someone asked me to draw a map of Skyrim or Fallout New Vegas, I'd have something to work with because those games have biomes and mountain ranges and lakes. The one feature Fallout 3 has is the city in the southeast which is a nightmare to traverse as its split into many small sections requiring you to travel through endlessly boring subway tunnels to reach them. This was done due to hardware limitations of the time, but it still isn't fun to play.

IF you like the Fallout series or are interested in a really good RPG,  this is a must. It doesn't have the settlement builds of FO4 but does have available living quarters that can be renovated in many different styles with all you will need to succeed with the proper amount of caps.  All in all a really good addition to the Fallout series.

Having played this game both on xbox and pc, with and without mods, I can honestly say that this game is not worth your time. Fallout 3 is marketed as a post-apocalyptic first person role playing game, but player choice is minimal, and Bethesda's idea of the post apocalypse is making everything tinted green. The writing for this game is abysmal, with a main story line that is deeply uninteresting and filled with plot holes wider than a nuclear crater. Almost all of the side content is completely unrelated to the main conflict and is more interested in making a zany, "wouldn't it be so cool if [insert half-baked, poorly written idea here]" scenario than providing a compelling issue or introducing a difficult choice for the player. Bethesda seems to think that the Fallout franchise's themes are confined to over the top satire of stereotypical 1950's Americana. This game has enough interesting moments and flashing lights that could be enjoyed while you zone out and watch videos or something else alongside it, but there are hundreds of similar games that would be a much better use of your time.

Fallout 3, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, is an open-world action role-playing game (RPG) and the third main installment in the iconic Fallout series. Set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland of Washington, D.C., the game offers a compelling and immersive experience that has captivated players since its release.

One of the standout aspects of Fallout 3 is its atmospheric and detailed world. The game presents a desolate and decaying landscape filled with ruins, mutants, and morally ambiguous factions. The attention to detail in the game's environment, from the devastated cityscape to the eerie underground vaults, creates a sense of immersion and exploration.

The main storyline in Fallout 3 follows the protagonist's search for their missing father in the wasteland. Along the way, players encounter various factions, make choices that affect the game world, and uncover the dark secrets of post-apocalyptic society. The narrative is engaging and filled with memorable characters, providing players with a sense of purpose and driving them to uncover the mysteries of the wasteland.

The gameplay mechanics of Fallout 3 combine first-person shooting with RPG elements, allowing players to engage in intense combat while also making choices that shape their character's development. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system, which governs the player's attributes, skills, and perks, offers a deep and customizable progression system. The ability to make choices and face consequences adds depth and replayability to the game, allowing players to have unique experiences and explore different paths.

Fallout 3 is also known for its rich side quests and exploration opportunities. The wasteland is filled with hidden locations, unique items, and interesting characters, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path and discover the game's secrets. The vast array of weapons, armor, and other items further enhance the sense of exploration and customization, as players can tailor their character to fit their preferred playstyle.

However, it's worth noting that Fallout 3 does have some technical issues, especially on older systems. Some players have experienced occasional crashes or performance problems. Additionally, the game's graphics, while atmospheric and immersive, may feel outdated compared to more recent titles.

Despite these minor shortcomings, Fallout 3 is widely regarded as a modern classic and a seminal entry in the Fallout series. Its gripping narrative, immersive world, and compelling gameplay mechanics have left a lasting impact on the gaming community. Whether you are a fan of RPGs or post-apocalyptic settings, Fallout 3 offers a thrilling and memorable experience that shouldn't be missed.

Overall, I found the game to be very enjoyable, and I would play it again.

I have been playing this game a ton since I got it on April 14. At the time I was looking for a game that either just had a great story or a sandbox type game where the player had the control and could do whatever they wanted. I have always considered playing the fallout series but never got into it since I have never been a fan of dystopian atmospheres. I really always enjoyed the opposite; Modern futuristic Utopias and Bustling Cities. But I decided to anyway since it was cheap and it had character creation. The game starts with the intro stating "War... war never changes" and describes the backstory of this wasted world. It all stemmed from the great war. After World War 2, nuclear power became trending and that trend carried on forever. It lead into a total nuclear warfare that everyone lives the aftermath of 200 years later in this game. You live in vault 101. Many vaults were created before the great war to survive for as long as possible. SOMETHING NEAT: Every Vault is different. The premise of this game is finding your father who left the vault (that which is not allowed) and you leave the vault to find him. This game has decent combat, great story, decent visuals, great customization, great characters, great open world, and best of all you are in control. You can kill a main character, good or bad, even if it is crucial to the story. You control your adventure for the most part and I love it. Also the music in this game is amazing. You get a ton of music from the 20s-late 50s and it really fits the atmosphere. The game can also be scary at points (Scariest fallout game by far) and some of the creatures in the game are truly diabolical. Sorry this review is kind of all over the place, but I am telling you, if you like elder scrolls or you like open-ended open world rpgs this game is just great and I think you will love it.

I am honestly surprised I haven't reviewed Fallout 3: GOTY yet.

The year is 2008. I have just begun 10th grade. Upon getting the opportunity to take a game design elective at a sister high school I ran into a classmate who'd just bought the collector's edition complete with Vault-Tec lunchbox. I'd had vague recollections about how popular the franchise was and what it generally was about but had never had the opportunity to look into the game prior due to us not having the means.

At the time I was big up on piracy and decided to acquire a copy of the game. This and GTA IV as I recall would end up being some of the first games I'd purchase on my Steam account after entering the workforce.

The good:

- Along with FO:NV basically the reason for Nexus Mods' initial growth and entrenchment as a centralized modding scene resource
- Story, environments and replayability are pretty incredible as they stand and is tangibly expanded with each DLC, props to Bethsoft for Broken Steel retconning the hard-ending, this fundamentally made the game a sandbox to live in (in partial opposition to FO:NV which has a final showdown at the end of the main story arc that needs to be prioritized dead last, but is the only major consideration)
- Helped to repopularize 50's popular music, Googie/Atomic Design for mainstream science fiction fans
- Possibly the only time I've seen the National Mall represented in first-person in a video game
- Every single damn DLC is a banger, Bethsoft really busted their butts on making expansions for the Oblivion/FO3 era
- Weapons, armor, player homes and collectibles are all timeless and arrive at a steady pace
- Characters are well-enough written and are mostly there to paint an aesthetic picture as opposed to FO4's character design which is primarily (with some exceptions): here's some generic emotional appeals as to why you need to go here and accomplish this task, okay bye~

The different:
- In contrast with Fallout 4 and later, power armor is differentiated from regular armor only by a prerequisite "Power Armor Training" skill provided only mid-game. Upshot is that no supplementary items such as fusion cores are required for usage - this is in line with long-established franchise canon stating that the fusion cores integrated into standard-issue power armors have such longevity relative to power consumption in active use that they effectively retain a charge indefinitely as opposed to like 20-30mins realtime in FO4+
-In contrast with FO4+, there is no settlement system or native item modification/crafting outside of inventory system-based stat mods. This is an upshot in that the uniqueness of unique items is preserved from user modification to the point where the gun's unrecognizable, and a downshot in that it limits user customization. Certain mods will expand this to an extent, and FO:NV does incorporate an expanded ammo/weapon modification mechanic.

The bad:

- Games for Windows Live requirement - kind of not their fault as it was an attempt to provide feature parity with the Xbox 360 version (cheevos) but Microsoft really just didn't know what they were doing then. It really blows chunks that we now have to mod the game immediately after installation to get it to avoid immediate CTDs related to the missing xlive.dll dependency. I do wish Bethsoft would return to patch this out of the game at this point as the primary feature is deprecated, it's kind of a failure to support their own product.
- Classic Gamebryo Engine bugs - worst offenders: CTDs, issues with Alt+Tab/focus hijack/black screen, save corruption, multicore/4GB+
- For as much as I love the survivalist journey of traveling through the DC Metro to get into the oasis of infrastructural integrity amidst collapsed hi-rises that is southeast D.C. it can be a real slog to go through again. Really atmospheric but pretty strenuous, kind of like replaying GTA IV
- The game is helped somewhat by the gritty subject matter and environmental storytelling but the graphics of the Gamebryo Engine have not aged terribly well. That said, mods can help immensely
- Engine support for mods is more of a known quantity without internal Beth.net mod marketplace -- however, the content package system was clearly not designed for stability in supporting extensive changes to the game, especially when it comes to mod order, Archive Invalidation, texture/asset changes or save dependencies. This is also kind of a mixed bag in that it's partially as a result of the amazing ambition and creativity of the modding community.

This game is the first hands-on impression I had with Fallout beyond I think maybe 5 minutes of playing a FO1 port to Mac OS and watching my brother play about the first hour of FO1 on his PC as a kid, in relation to the beginning of this review. So as a primary exposure point, and as a diehard fan today, I'd say mission accomplished.

If you're interested in a combined experience with Fallout: New Vegas, I'd seriously consider checking out Tale of Two Wastelands. It's an effort to get installed but once you're done you literally have a modified FO:NV engine supporting all content for FO3 and NV in a single character's game session. It's absolutely incredible.

Really doesn't hold up as well as one would hope and can only really be recommended to existing fans of the series at this point. Muddy graphics and stiff animation can be somewhat overlooked given it's 14 years old, though I feel Dragon Age: Origins did a significantly better job in these regards despite only coming out a month later. My main issues however are that the gunplay and open world are absolutely pitiful by modern standards; the Capital Wasteland is often totally barren for large stretches, and has random massive rubble piles in the city that severely limits the amount of space actually available to explore. Gunplay feels really bad, especially with no iron sights (or scopes at all except on snipers), meaning that your options are to either hipfire or hipfire but zoomed in, basically. Shots are clunky, weapon variety is lacking, some weapons feel utterly useless (hunting rifle and lower calibre pistols especially), and bullet spread is too wild without enough indication of where a player's shots will land relative to their crosshair.

Main story and side quests are usually okay and around a 7/10. Very obviously doesn't come anywhere close to New Vegas, but it's serviceable for a Fallout game. Main story has its highlights and lowlights (running errands for Little Lamplight utterly killed the pacing in my opinion) but it's alright; side quests however can often be pretty annoying and tedious. Do not talk to Moira Brown, worst mistake I ever made. Do talk to Mr. Burke, best mistake I ever made.

I'd imagine there are probably mods that resolve a lot of the problems I had with this game, but by its own merits I think there's plenty out there I'd recommend over this. More recent Metro games come to mind if you're itching for post-apocalyptic shooters.

From the immediate beginning, when the child player looks up towards their father just after being born, it's clear that Fallout 3 demands curiosity. A wee babe, wailing desperately for the player to pay attention, to look here. A hapless parent, dangling shiny objects in front of your face, hoping that one of them in a long sequence of unconnected and brief experiences will resonate, and stick to your mentality. Over and over, Fallout 3 rams home the theme of the child - both in thematics, and in narrative. The expansive open world is an exciting and certainly interesting romp, but it's weakened at the knees by juvenile writing, a surprisingly barren variety of weapons and customization, and a supreme lack of logic and nuance, things that it professes as necessary in the rhetoric, but fails to deliver within its own confines. Quests will frequently end without conclusive resolutions, character questions will routinely skip what you actually wanted to or needed to know, and dialogue options within conversations seemingly forget about the existence of each other, creating a disassociative mess of an experience without strong personalities or ideologies. Built-up moments of glory are quickly shuffled to the side once their snapshot moment has been reached, and a persisent abruptness to just about everything leaves a "well, that's that" taste in the mouth until the very end. The foundations of the worldspace are what makes this an interesting idea, but the execution of the morality and of the heart of the game, so decayed and wimpy, forced the vast majority of my engagement out and away. Truly, a wasteland in essence.

Fallout 3 opens with the birth of your character, you go through a relatively long prologue through the years upto the point where you're forced to get out of the secluded protection of the vault. It grounds your character in the setting in an organic way, more so than any other Bethesda in my opinion. Which is why I find it funny that I felt least connected to the setting and my character of this game than any other.
These games have always have always had a theme-park design to them, sandbox with toys to play around for you. But if you decide to meet the games half way, acknowledge the limitation and roleplay within the confines of the sandbox, they can be some of the most immersive experiences in gaming. But here I felt really hard to connect myself to the world. The writing and the quest design lacked the extra oomph for me to get immersed in the characters and their struggles. The main story is supposed to be deeply personal to the PC, but the none of the main characters have enough depth to make you care. It felt more like playing an outside observer briefly looking into the stories of the people in this worlds and way too happy to kill some mutants and raiders. It really was like being in a theme park.

This is not to say I didn't have fun with it, the labyrinth of DC metro aside exploration is a lot of fun like all Bethesda games. There are a lot of attractions in this theme park, both quantity and variety. The comically evil choices also makes more sense with that perspective. I even got used to the janky gunplay after a while, it's oddly satisfying blowing up meat bags with bullets. That's why the positive rating here. Still, this is probably my least favorite Bethesda game.

Despite the fact, that Fallout 3 doesn't like modern PC's, it's one of my favourite games in terms of Exploration and Atmosphere. You really feel the aftermath of the Apocalypse and you're free to travel wherever you wish to. As the story falls short and mediocre (except for the exceptional "Tranquility Lane" plot twist) you probably can get the most joy out of it, If you take it as a Sandbox game: Explore the Capital Wasteland and enjoy 100+ hours. I got Fallout 3 on my old PC and once per year it is still a fantastic experience.

I remember sitting on an ottoman 5 feet from my tiny tv watching the Fallout 3 coverage at E3. The gameplay absolutely blew me away.

I didn’t have my own money or a modern console so there was a no chance I’d get it at launch.

However, a couple years later my friend told me at lunch that he purchased Fallout 3: GOTY Edition, but his computer wouldn’t play it. GameStop wouldn’t let him return it either. I immediately offered to trade him a PC copy of Oblivion I had, since he might be able to play that on his older pc. He accepted.

God only knows how many hours I played Fallout 3 at like 15fps because my computer sucked too.

After a couple years I got a job and bought a ps3 and another copy of Fallout 3 for that. I remember one of my files has 300+ hours on it.

All these years later I got a steam deck and decided to play through Fallout 3 once again. It still stands as one of my top favorite games ever made. It ran like crap on Windows 10, but crashes were so minimal on the Steam Deck, it is definitely the way to go.

Installing the Fellout mod to remove the green filter is a must have. I also like the essential companions and merchants mod. I added the zero degradation mod this time around so I wouldn’t spend half my time taping things together.

TLDR: I really like this game, and will probably play it until I die.

Fallout 3 is a game that can be appreciated for its bold attempt at reimagining the classic RPG series with a new, first-person perspective. The graphics are top-notch and the post-apocalyptic world is fully realized with its vast open world, complete with various factions and creatures that give the game a unique flavor.

However, while the game's FPS combat mechanics are a significant improvement, Fallout 3 falls short on story detail. The plot is somewhat predictable, and there are very few memorable characters to keep the player engaged. The game's dialogue options, while varied, can often feel flat and uninspired.

Despite these flaws, Fallout 3 remains an enjoyable experience with its vast open world, thrilling combat, and exploration opportunities. The game's post-apocalyptic atmosphere is genuinely haunting, and the ability to make choices that shape the outcome of the story is a welcome addition.

I wish there was a way to vote "mixed" on Steam. This game is deeply flawed (mechanically and story-wise). It's worth playing, but at the same time, it's not worth playing. This is by no means a Fallout game, despite the name. Your choices feel as if they have no impact on the wasteland. The worst that can really happen is Liam Neeson being disappointed in you, Three Dog talking sh*t about you on the radio, or you just losing some karma.

Basically, no one cares about the water crisis, which is what the whole story is about! There are three water beggars in the wasteland, and they are really the only ones that seem to care about the lack of water (besides the scientists and your father, duh), and like one or two scripted events where people fight over purified water, everyone else seems like they could careless about the hopeless situation they live in.

The story is extremely disjointed, bland, and poorly written, along with the side quests (with what little there are), and the world that it takes place in doesn't really make any sense from a realistic standpoint. The food chain should literally be broken; there is no vegetation growing in the wasteland besides in Oasis, and even then, Oasis isn't even known to the rest of the wasteland, and the labs in Rivet City are just experimental. And if you're a person who is thinking, "Who cares about what they eat?" Then I truly hope you don't create fictional worlds or even make video games as a whole.

The lore is completely disregarded; The Brotherhood of Steel goes against their core values, with super mutants only being brain-dead killers compared to the ones in previous entries that have super mutants that are actually smart and are retaining their humanity. The only thing that feels sort of retained from the older games is the Enclave, and even then they feel cartoonishly evil. (Especially goddamn Colonel Autumn.)

This game also has no original factions; despite the fact that this game takes place on the other side of the country, Bethesda got extremely lazy here. And all the factions that are present in this game are just the ones from the original games, but they are poorly implemented and thought out, as I stated above. If you're going to copy and paste stuff from the original games, at least actually follow the damn lore.

There is a lot more I find completely stupid with this game (Megaton, for one). This game has more going against it than going for it. I would say give it a shot, but don't expect too much in the way of role-playing and world-building.
