I have mixed feelings for this game after replaying it after so many years. On one hand i have the nostalgia of me playing this around 2009/2010 and having a blast with the game and on the other hand i have my hatred of this game for playing it in 2023 because of the crashes, bugs, crashes and even more crashes.

At it's core the game is an improvement compared to the older fallout games, this being the first 3D game in the series. With this change came a lot of things that got better:
-gone are the walls of texts from when talking with a character and welcomed is the voice acting (not that i mind it but i do enjoy some voice acting)
-gone is the bad inventory system that is replaced with an easy to navigate inventory
-gone is the bad UI that is replaced with a clean and useful UI

The improvements didn't stop here, we did get a better main story plot line and better side content as side quests or locations to visit that can tell a story of what happened there even without the help of a quest in that region.
The majority of the items are common items that you can encounter on people from the wasteland or in the inventory of merchants, but some are unique items and i loved hunting them down. Some were in unique locations where the previous holder met a gruesome ending while some of the unique items are rewards or you find them on the enemies you kill.

I loved the karma system and wish more games implemented the morality system this way and not just the annoying and boring 'X will remember that'.

The main quest line was fun, but a bit cliche to be fair. I did enjoy going through it.
The side content was more interesting for me compared to the main quest line. There were so many small side quests that impressed me way more that any of the quests in the main plot line.

The companions are brain dead. Their AI was written by interns and you can't convince me otherwise. The companions always stop in corridors and won't let you pass, yell random voice lines during fights, get in front of you shooting at an enemy and eat your bullets. I played solo most of the game and only got a companion (Fawkes) while doing the last quests from the main plot line.

The dlcs were a let down, yep all of them disappointed me with how shallow they were. It was a balance from what i saw, some either had a new map but only one quest and others didn't have a new map but had a bit more quests.
-Operation: Anchorage was boring and annoying to play just so you have the cliche ending where the people you were there to help wanted to kill you while some were on your side.
-The Pitt basically made you choose between 2 evils and let you decide who is the lesser evil. I liked that they did this, but that the only good thing about it everything else was a sad excuse of a dlc. Would have regretted my purchase if i payed full price at release for this.
-Broken Steel was awesome. Loved that they continued the story and let you see the outcome of the decision you made in the main quest line. Had some nice side quests too so i'm glad i played this one.
-Point Lookout was trash. Main quest introduced an annoying rich asshole and his 'enemy'. Ended up killing both of them just because i was sick and tired of them. There were some nice side quests, one comes to mind is the evil book that you had to destroy.
-Mothership Zeta was trash just because all you had to do is run around the ship all game. The map system from this game doesn't help out when there are multiple layers (like floor 1, floor 2, etc.) and you had to hunt for that stair case most of the time.

The bugs and crashes were horrendous. I encountered everything from textures floating to random crashes in some places that made it impossible to continue.
Yeah i get it, the game is from 2008 it's normal to have some out of the place textures. But, and it's a big but, TES 4 Oblivion came out in 2006 and had less textures floating and random crashes.

The random crashes were so annoying to deal with. Literally did every fix possible and it was still not enough, let me enumerate them:
-tried using the unofficial path, but that wasn't any good because i got crashes still and some doors were forever locked (talking about the general shop in megaton)
-tried to put the game in compatibility mode with admin privileges, did nothing and still had crashes
-disabled steam overlay, did nothing and still had crashes
-disabled the auto saves on travel, wait and the third one i can't remember, did nothing and still had crashes

At this point i kept getting crashes, but pulled through and finished the game even tho i still got random crashes just starring at a wall or a floor. Had no mods installed so the crashes couldn't be caused from them.
For a game that has this many issues it baffles me that you can buy it even tho it's not working 100%.

As a conclusion i loved this game playing it for the first time back in the day and mostly enjoyed my time with it replaying it. I cannot recommend this because it's not working properly, even if you jump through hoops to find a fix for the game it will still crash out of the blue.
Buy it if you want fun gun play, good quests and interesting locations to visit, but be prepared to have a lot of crashes and save often.

Fallout 3 is an atmospheric and immersive blues adventure in a world devastated by nuclear destruction 
Rating: 8/10
TL;DR:
You may have played Fallout New Vegas, Skyrim or Fallout 4. This is very similar. It's an open-world sandbox RPG where you explore, complete quests & unalive your enemies. Fallout 3 is a reboot of the Fallout series under a new developer and manages to capture the atmosphere perfectly as it recreates it in 3D.

[H1]Setting[/h1]
Fallout 3 takes place in the Capital Wasteland, a post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. in 2277, the capital of the United States. This is around 36 years after Fallout 2. In 2077, the world was destroyed in a thermonuclear exchange known as the Great War; it only lasted a few hours but left the world in ruins. Fallout 3, 200 years after atomic annihilation depicts the ruined capital of the US, once a seat of power in the world, now a wasteland of mutated creatures, raider and the last remaining few trying to survive.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2950383224

[h1]World Design[/h1]
The world design of Fallout 3 is fantastic. Understandably, the graphics themselves are a bit dated, but the design is beautiful. Bethesda are masters of world design, as many know. The Capital Wasteland features fantastic locations such as the Washington Monument, the Lincoln Memorial, The White House, United States Capitol Building & Bethesda itself!
In the Capital Wasteland, there lives only a few bastions of civilisation; notably the town of Megaton, Tenpenny Tower, Rivet City along with a few smaller locations such as Big Town, Little Lamplight & Oasis. 

The urban environments are very well done, featuring makeshift homes and buildings, barely functional infrastructure and creative defences. These settlements are a reminder that there's hope for humanity to rebuild, and that the world outside is dangerous and unforgiving. 

Between these cradles of civilisation is a desolate wasteland where near everything is a threat. Raiders want to kill you, animals want to eat you & radroaches want to... i'm not sure, better shoot them anyway. As it's designed to be a wasteland, most of the landscape is rocky, barren and notably devoid of life, almost. The beauty in the game design of Fallout 3 is the pacing between discovering something new. You will often come across ruins occupied by raiders, animals and settlements to take refuge; all of these things remind you that the world is not as empty as it seems, life is there if you look close enough, and with life, there's hope for the world.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2950895548

[h1]Story[/h1]
The main story is the weakest point of Fallout 3. It mostly serves as a narrative tool to entice the player to keep going and experience the rest of the game. It also serves as justification for being in the world and going to key areas. Still, it's not terrible and the main characters are done really well. Your father, a scientist desperate to bring clean water to the wasteland, wonderfully voiced by Liam Neeson. Elder Owyn Lyons of the Brotherhood of Steel, a recurring faction of the Fallout series that returns here in a different way. Madison li, a colleague of your father working on Project Purity. These are just some of the fantastic characters in this game.
You grow up in a vault, one of many underground bunkers designed to preserve humanity from the nuclear bombs. One day your father leaves and you follow shortly after him. Now shut out of your home and everyone you know, along in the wasteland, with your only objective to find your dad. 
Where did he go?

The side content of Fallout 3 is far better both in it's design and narrative. Your choices may have consequences and your options may not always be so clear. They often involve you picking a side in a conflict, with different ways to achieve your goal. Interact with the characters, listen to them, understand them and make your choice, just be prepared to live with your consequence.
Fallout 3 features various companions you can encounter and take with you on your adventures. Some of these characters are locked behind a karma level, something that will change depending on your choices throughout your experience playing. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2949488171

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This is an RPG that allows you to create and build your character throughout your experience with the game. As you play you'll gain XP from killing enemies and completing quests. Upon levelling up you can allocate skill points of your choosing into thirteen different skills such as bartering, small guns, lockpicking and speech. These skills will make you better at each of these things and may even unlock new dialogue options and quest choice opportunities.

The game itself is a sandbox. You will freely explore at your leisure, going where you want, when you want. You start in the centre of the map and are free to go wherever as soon as you leave the vault. It controls like other Bethesda games, you move around in an open 3D space, have an inventory system and are able to use whichever clothing, armour and weapons you want. You take damage from enemies but also take radiation from irradiated food, water or nuclear waste.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2955323936

[hr][/hr]

Overall, Fallout 3 is a beautifully melancholic experience that puts you in a sad and ruined world with only a few remaining iconic features of the old world long gone. There's hope that humanity can keep going, rebuild and perhaps one day thrive, but first it has to survive.
Even if the world rebuilt back to normal, would it only destroy itself again? War never changes, after all.

Fallout 3 the game that taught me that radiation can be both deadly and hilarious. From the giant scorpions to the ghoul-infested subways, this game has it all. But you know what really sets it apart? The DLCs.

The DLCs in Fallout 3 are like little slices of heaven. There's Operation: Anchorage, which is like a military simulator on steroids. Then there's The Pitt, which takes you to a post-apocalyptic version of Pittsburgh that's just dripping with atmosphere. And let's not forget about Point Lookout, where you get to explore the swamps of Maryland and fight hillbilly zombies. It's like a redneck rave, but with more blood.

The best part about the DLCs is that they're all so different. Each one has its own unique story, characters, and challenges. It's like getting four different games for the price of one. And let's face it, who doesn't love a good bargain?

The graphics in Fallout 3 are a bit dated, but that just adds to the game's charm. It's like playing a classic movie that's been remastered in HD. And the music? It's like a trip down memory lane, with classic tunes from the 40s and 50s.

All in all, Fallout 3 is a game that will suck you in and never let go. And if you haven't played the DLCs yet, then you're missing out on some of the best content this game has to offer. So grab your Pip-Boy, stock up on stimpacks, and get ready for an adventure you'll never forget.

Fallout 3 is an open-world action role-playing game set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland in Washington D.C. after a nuclear war.

The game begins with the player character growing up in Vault 101, a self-contained underground bunker designed to protect its inhabitants from the dangers of the outside world. However, when the player's father mysteriously disappears, the player is forced to leave the vault and venture out into the wasteland to find him.

One of the standout features of Fallout 3 is its world-building. The game creates a rich and detailed post-apocalyptic world that is both fascinating and terrifying to explore. The world is full of interesting characters, dangerous creatures, and hidden secrets waiting to be discovered.

The game also features a robust character creation system that allows players to customize their character's appearance and choose from a variety of skills and perks. This allows for a high degree of player agency in how they choose to approach the game's challenges.

Players can use a variety of weapons, from guns to melee weapons, to take on enemies. The game also features a V.A.T.S. (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) system that allows players to pause the game and target specific body parts on enemies, adding a tactical element to the combat.

This is a classic of the RPG genre and a must-play for fans of post-apocalyptic settings and immersive world-building.

Nostalgia aside, there are a few problems with this game that Bethesda really needs to look at:

Had to use a mod just to make the game work, this is after multiple weeks of attempting to find work-arounds that did not involve actively installing a third-party. If a third-party is needed to make a game work, the game seriously needs to be looked at.

The game is also very laggy, even when the settings are all turned down, they still do not help with the lag. This is strange for my computer, which can run most games, including Fallout New Vegas, in a far better and much more stable manner.

Game crashes or bugs out when tabbing out, forcing it to be forcefully "stopped" in steam or ended by task manager. This includes the game turning into a single white bar with the name running across the screen and being unable to tab out of the game with it crashing, forcing me to go to an entirely different screen and end it with task manager there.

When pausing the game with a controller, options like "vibrations" turn back on, and there is no permanent way to turn it off as of writing this. I don't like mouse and keyboard controls and I wish to feel nostalgic, but playing with a constantly vibrating controller that cannot be permanently turned off is very annoying.

15 years hence, and the most notable drawbacks to FO3 remain its clunky controls and buggy execution. And it is absolutely riven with bugs, which are luckily (mostly) benign. Optimization for use with a controller remains wanting.

Coming back to this title after playing it upon its debut in 2008 reminds one more clearly of its strengths: more focused quests and environments (albeit less charitable to the player), enemies that continue to frighten well into the upper levels of your player-character,  and an underlying approach to the whole thing which feels less designed to offer compromise to the player; you must adapt more to it, than it has been adapted to you (which is truer of most games the further back you go). 

As it would turn out, the dialogue and NPC interaction of its successors—FO:NV, and FO4, primarily—are not categorical improvements, but merely different. They don't necessarily feel much more or less 'organic' than this, which is a point in FO3's favour, here. Now-typical of Bethesda, you do hear the same lines repeated from about 5 different voice actors over and over again (or so it seems), even delivered in the same intonation. It seems something inescapable to Bethesda's developmental approach at this point, being a problem that is common to most of their titles. 

Graphics are what they are, ie products of 2008, but still manage to impress at surprising instances. Many vistas are downright gorgeous, and the various locales all just 'look right'. More importantly, the art & visual direction which go into crafting the 'feel' of the game is tightly-coordinated and nearly always achieves what it sets out to do (the feeling of the rust-ridden, abandoned Vault 87; the desolate emptiness of a super duper mart which nevertheless still hides raiders; the high-camp, saccharine pleasantry of the Tranquility Lane 'experience' come to mind, or the familiar dread that comes with probing into dark environments). This is a relatively consistent strength among the Bethesda titles. 

Technically, its sound design is impeccable. However, the overuse of a number of stock sounds which are deployed very frequently can give it a mechanical (ie repetitive, automated/cyclic) feeling. Between this and the issue already mentioned with dialogue, which continues to plague their series, it's practically to be expected. The benefit here, however, is that as of 2008, Bethesda hadn't overgrown their britches just yet, and so you don't get quite the same smug self-satisfaction of a developer proud of including 28million more lines of dialogue . . . from the same 5 voice actors. (I know there is more variation than this—I am being facetiously simplistic—but it's a clear problem of theirs'. "I used to be an adventurer like you. . . " come to mind?) 

TL;DR Verdict?

"Mostly excellent, with some deserved critique"—but a AAA title nonetheless. Ironically, it's less the technological limitations to its development hampering the experience, than it is the many elective choices they made which paved such a road to this destination. 

Forever-tailing the illustrious trajectory of this series, however, remains the inescapable reality of the fact that Fallout 3, in contrast to FO1 & 2, is now condemned to forever remain an "Elder Scrolls: Morrowind" game grafted into the diagetic 'world' of the Fallout series, departing only from its design and narrative logic as much as is necessary to 'pass', for a while, as an original iteration of the seminal series. The threads, so to speak, cease to self-weave and are now part of the same, impressively-lucrative tapestry. 

Overly-reductive numerical assessment: 85/100

The main story line is simple and straight forward and is a presentation of the whole game. Most areas or side quests just lack any depth or feel generic. The people that you talk to barely give you any information for starters, I explored all the dialogue options but it was lacking or samey things that you already know. I searched across the wasteland to explore as well but it was a shallow world to me. None of the characters want to talk to you and everyone would rather kill you instead. As for gameplay wise its decent but in need of balancing or because I was playing in legendary. I kept my game as vanilla as possible with mods and fixes, but many weapons fall off into the late game as enemies scale with you and the lack of perks or building don't allow you to bridge the gap. I found myself only realistically using 3 weapons to dispatch of enemies as the other weapons in the game were unreliable. Overall I wished the game was as good as its cousin New Vegas, but the characters are the drive of the story and they were all one dimensional to say the least.

My first Fallout game...

Yes it says I only have 11 hours playing this game and I have reviews several years old of the previous main Fallout games on here.  But this game was my first experience with Fallout when I purchased it in 2009 on my Xbox 360, because my parents wouldn't let me purchase GTA 4 as I was only 13 at the time.  I have to say what I couldn't have imagined saying back then: Thank you mom and dad for not letting me get GTA, as I probably wouldn't have gotten into this series as soon, or ever.

Fallout 3 is a massive RPG where you can explore a post apocalyptic wasteland where there is absolutely no shortage of things to do.  Fight mutants, talk to morally questionable characters, enslave people, be Nicolas Cage and steal the Declaration of Independence, the works!  The way to accomplish this is all up to you as well as you can customize your character in multiple manners that offer several unique ways to experience the game.  Whether you want to be a brute that clubs enemies to death, or a finesse assassin that takes out targets via stealth, or a smooth talker that uses words to get his way, or even some combination of all of them!  There is great variety in weapons and enemies to fight.  You can use melee weapons, firearms, explosives etc. to deal with bloodthirsty raiders, freakish zombie ghouls and the rest of irradiated abominations that you will encounter in the wasteland.

The amount of quests is also very abundant as you can easily log 100+ hours doing activities in the wasteland without even focusing on the main story questline.  Many of them are unique and interesting.  Others are relatively "meh" at best, but will normally reward you quite generously with Exp, and item or even possibly a Perk that upgrades your character.

There are few negatives to this game I can provide, one being that it does take approximately 20-40 minutes to get to the true freedom that you are normally provided within the first 5 minutes of the other games in the series due to this games intro.  Also the shooting aspect of the game can be a little wonky even once fully upgraded as the game does try to put the RPG aspect first and want you to rely on the VATS system to properly shoot.  And something that is not this games fault, but New Vegas to me is definitely a superior experience in almost every facet and it is hard to not compare the games due to how similar they are, but this game will offer unique experiences you won't find in New Vegas.

Overall I cannot recommend this game enough and the series is legendary for a reason.  I would highly recommend this game to anyone that would love to get into Fallout or even to just enjoy a great RPG.

Data Log: February 12 2023.
It has been 10 years since I have seen the Capital Wasteland. Ten years since I have visited the foggy swamps of Point Lookout. Ten years since I have fought my way through the grim of The Pit. Ten years since I have regretted buying Mothership Zeta. Like many others, my first Fallout experience was Fallout 3, a game which I still have the physical disc. A game which stole hundreds of hours from my life and Games For Windows Live holding my achievements and records until the day that it died like an ember falling to the ground. The official walkthrough with map has long been buried under dust and forgotten about. Ten years...

It was time. It was time to dust the walkthrough off and drag out the map. It was time to return to Point Lookout and taste the fruit. It was time to cause an uprising in The Pitt. It was time to go and take the tower for the Ghouls. It was time to rewrite the Wasteland Survival guide again. It was time, to say goodbye to a childhood friend again. All this and more, a time before the Zone of STALKER, there was the Capital Wasteland it was time to return. Setting foot outside 101 once again, the burning rays of sun wash over me and the jet powered gate of Megaton lifts. Before the Zone there was here, and I have returned. Returned home.

[h1]General[/h1]
A seminal part of my gaming history, Fallout 3 will likely always be my favorite of the series. From growing up playing the first with my dad to the modern day iterations, Fallout 3 still has the most engaging, heartfelt, and enjoyable storyline and gameplay for me. Though 4 is a marvel and the settlement system certainly stole my heart, I still love 3 above all. Far from a perfect first person shooter (this ain't a shooter, no matter what they want you to believe), Fallout 3 is more about the absurd fun you can have, the emotional connection to your father, and the people you help (or destroy) along the way. 

[b][u]Character Customization[/u][/b]
Still a game from 2008, so don't expect too much. The game still had quite a few options for it's age and more than many modern releases, so it's certainly still a good example of character customization! Just don't expect Fallout 4 levels of customization. There's plenty of clothing and weapon options for you to customize your outfits and load-out, so there's plenty to use to express yourself. 

[b][u]Open World[/u][/b]
Large open world map for it's time that still holds up in 2023. This is a open world map circa 2008 so there will be large swaths of open space with nothing but a few enemies. Still plenty of fun things to stumble across that aren't on the map though, so keep exploring. I swear I find something new every time I replay the game.

[b][u]FPS[/u][/b]
The game was never originally designed to be a true shooter, so don't expect perfect shooting mechanics. No inherent cover based system, so be prepared to spray and pray. 

[b][u]Mini Games[/u][/b]
A constant feature, but you'll figure out your own way around those if you don't enjoy them or learn to game the system however works best for you. Lock picking can be finicky on PC (or maybe it's just mine?) and I much preferred it on both PS3 and PS4. Computer password cracking is always my least favorite part, but the rules are fairly simple once you know em. 

[b][u]Replayability[/u][/b]
I've probably played through this game a dozen a time and still find something new to explore or experience each time. Story can change pretty drastically depending on your choices, so try to replay with different karma levels or choices. It'll keep it pretty fresh. I've conservatively put more than 100 hours into multiple playthroughs, so this is a game that keeps on giving.

[b]Graphics and story[/b] 10/10

[i]Fallout 3[/i] is an action role-playing game. The story is simple and interesting: the plot takes place in the year 2277, in the ruins of Washington D.C. mainly. The cities were devastated caused by the nuclear holocaust after strong tensions between countries due to the scarcity of resources. Some people were called to take refuge in the shelter sponsored by Vault-tec. Over the years, people began a life inside the vault. Our character, a role to play (he/she), shelter 101 is born. [i]It grows, it was formed, and it reaches youth[/i]. One day its father, Dr. James, leaves the shelter and the most important quote in the game: the biblical passage [i]Revelation 21:6[/i]. As soon as our character and all the vault staff find out, we decide to leave before the security lockdown. The adventure begins when we explore the wasteland with the only clue in hand: visit the city of Megaton. With all the means to find the father, we will find him at the Jefferson Memorial. He is working on the purity project, a project that aims to provide clean water to all of Washington. For that we will need a Garden of Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.). A type of war technology and, in turn, it will allow the activation of the purifier. We will deal with the Enclave and decide the fate of the wasteland.

It is difficult to summarize the content seen in this game. The way of describing it is generally considered two strong elements of the game. The artistic design and the narrative. The art of the game has two important aspects: the aspect of desolation (the wasteland) and what remains of the big cities. In the first case we will immerse ourselves in places similar to a wasteland with ruins of buildings, bridges and roads. The game is an open world. We will see what remains after the great wars: ruins and that feeling of desolation and hostility. In the second case, at the same time the appearance of the colourful past of cities is included. It draws on 1950s US culture, albeit with a steampunk twist. Well, it is a world parallel to ours, a universe with different technological progress but, up to a certain point, similar. The drab and warm colours of the landscape blend with the rust tone of the metal, while the festive or cheerful tones, for example Nuka Cola, create a good aesthetic-visual balance.

Visual art maintains the balance between past and present. This is reinforced with the game's narration. The story unfolds and takes place in a world parallel to ours. Each moment of the story plunges us into a different world, hostile but also well known. The most important [i]incipit[/i] of the game as well as the sequels is pronounced like this, "War.....War Never Changes". We will see how people look for a way to survive. Each character speaks and tells the story of his life in the city, or what is left of it. They will talk about their experiences in the new world. But they will also talk about their past before the war. This makes the role-playing game immersive, rich in narrative, interactive with the different characters. There are different characters with personalities from charismatic to evil. It contains a wide variety of well-crafted dialogue lines. We will constantly make decisions until we reach the outcome of the story. Fallout is a new world.

[b]Playability[/b] 10/10

The game consists of the role-playing game. We can build our character according to our way of playing. We choose, the importance of freedom and determination in this game, our appearance as well as the path how we will walk it for what is basic at all times. The look is selectable, aspect and gender. At the beginning of the game, more choices will appear, in the prologue, such as the adoption of certain essential skills for the character in the so-called S.P.E.C.I.A.L. With that we can decide and prefer whether to be charismatic to have good conversations or resistant to survive the fierce battles. It also includes an additional test to award points for such skills that we will prefer throughout our tour. It's called G.O.A.T., it is the set of skills with which we will specialize. As we progress through the game, we will acquire experience points to improve our character. We can improve our ability to be medics, handling weapons, melee, opening locks, stealth and among others. Added to this is the karma system. Depending on our decisions and actions, we will get good or bad karma that will affect our path in the wasteland as the interaction with other characters, with which it will affect our ending in the game.

The game is not necessarily about shooting. Not even fps. The type of camera can be adjusted and configured. It depends on the gameplay and the choice of gameplay through the selected skills, we can have a lot of possibilities how to play it. To this is added, once exposed to the elements of the wasteland, the need to obtain resources. This game depends on the levelling system and looting. This way we will get the wasteland coins, the bottle caps, to exchange them for services and products. Looting we will find the essential resources: from water and medicines to weapons and components and scrap metal. We will have the support of an ally, as well as the support of some communities, we do help them with their needs. We will be able to take a companion, like [i]Dogmeat[/i], a dog that we will find in the junkyard or Star Paladin Cross, among other characters and some depending on our type of karma. There are many things to describe and what the game offers in an almost free, kind of creative sandbox. Perhaps the negatives are the classic funny mistakes. But nothing that affects the gameplay and its features.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 10/10

The music is an interesting and well done work. We can consider it in two ways as they are in the game. The soundtrack as background, ambient music and music from the radio. For the first case, the music is linked to the story of the game. It consists of a mixture of tones such as military marches with classical and dark ambient. Like the soundtrack to some war movies, but with a post-nuclear and leading-a-battle feel. While other times, music is present in our battles, or ambient music on our journey. Sometimes it sounds pompous and energetic. Other times we hear mysterious, sinister or desolate. They certainly managed to find the sensation after the catastrophe with those ambient music tracks.

The other part of the soundtrack is found in the music on the radio. By activating the Pip-Boy, we can see the radio stations. Some only speak (Enclave Radio), but others broadcast music from the 40-50s. Well we can choose the radio station with the voice Three Dog, that is, in Galaxy News Radio (news more music). Or, help Agatha get the Soil Stradivarius violin so she will pass on unique violin pieces in which she interprets pieces by Bach, Dvořák and Sarasate. We can enjoy classical music as well as what remains of the radio. Styles like swing, jazz, rhythm & blues, rock n' roll or dixieland are among those. Some artists that we will find, Roy Brown, Cole Porter, The Ink Spots or Billie Holiday. Music that will accompany us in the wilderness.

[b]Duration[/b] 10/10

This is a vast game with many locations and sites to explore. In addition to having the freedom to do different activities within the game. It contains quite interesting missions and side quests. Without forgetting the diversity of characters and discoveries within the wasteland capital. We can re-play it in different ways, with a wide possibility of combinations. It is worth mentioning the presence of the DLCs. Each contains an interesting story that allows us to understand the context of the world of Fallout. Or, explore other places with unusual stories, after our exploration we will have a reward such as new weapons. With a vast content, Fallout 3 offers a different world, rich in history, a universe parallel to ours.

If you enjoyed any of the previous Fallout games, then this experience is probably not for you. Most likely, it will leave you wanting more from the game mechanically... however, if you're looking for a game to get lost in, you've come to the right place. Like with Skyrim, Bethesda hit the nail on the head of compelling free roaming. It's unfortunate that that nail was in the original Fallout's coffin as far as interesting game play mechanics goes. This game is very bare bones compared to the original games.

Fallout 3 is a fantastic game that immerses players in a post-apocalyptic world filled with danger and adventure. The open-world gameplay allows for endless exploration and the ability to make choices that truly affect the story. The character development and companion system add depth to the game, making it easy to get lost in the world for hours on end. The graphics and sound design are top-notch and the attention to detail is impressive. Overall, Fallout 3 is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone looking for a thrilling RPG experience.

Even excluding DLC, this game has by far the best and most creative side quests of the Bethesda era games, and it's not even close. DLC only amplifies that. It's truly a phenomenal game.

Well well well, 130 hours spent in this game under 3 weeks, talk about dedication!

To put it bluntly, I've already played and finished Fallout 3 'vanilla', without any DLC, back in 2008. Really loved the game and once I wanted to fire up the DLC, my saves were corrupted somehow. Didn't had the will to restart the whole thing back then so kept the game on hold ever since...

Until lately, had the immense urge to really play it again... with the marvelous help of Fallout 3 WIKIA though! Could save lots of time that way!

What can I say about this game? Perfect blend of First Person Shooter and Role Playing Game, in a post-apocalypse setting. I had already played, quite briefly, F1, F2 long long ago and even if the Turn Base was appealing at that time, I still prefer this new formula, where you can explore the world in full 3D!

[h1]POSITIVES:[/h1]
[b]+HUGE world to explore, with lots and lots of locations.

+Fantastic quests that can be completed in a variety of satisfying ways.
+VATS combat system results in all sorts of tense and gruesome encounters.
+Outstanding art design makes for a desolate Capital Wasteland.   
+Rewarding mixture of excitement and atmospheric exploration.
+FIVE awesome DLC additions on the game which add lots of content and about 15-20 hours of additional playtime.[/b]

I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series so I admit my strong bias when reviewing this game. I'd recommend this game because (like many Bethesda games) the world design is top tier and exploration is simply amazing. There are so many unmarked locations and cool places to explore not to mention unique weapons/loot. The game's story is also top notch and builds perfectly upon the previous installments. The DLC is also great and adds even more interesting exploration and story to the base game with The Pitt being one of my all-time favorite DLCs in the series. The freedom of choice the player has in Fallout 3 is excellent via character customization (through leveling) as well as in-game choices. The combat system certainly shows its age and is not as good as Fallout 4's but is still pretty decent. The game does have its fair amount of bugs and glitches (like many Bethesda games do) but they don't significantly impact game play. One major issue is that the game is not optimized to run on newer computers and crashes a fair amount in my experience although there may be ways to remedy this. I'd give this game a personal 8.5/10.

As someone who spent several years living in the DMV it brings me great schadenfreude to know that the metro works about the same after a nuclear apocalypse as it did while I was living there.

Should you buy and play this game? Yes. If you like FPS games, you'll like this game. If you like turn-based RPGs, you'll like this game. If you like 3D action/adventure games, you'll like this game.

The stories are great, the DLCs are hit and miss (but when they hit, they hit exceptionally well) and the combat works pretty well regardless of whether you use V.A.T.S. or just run-n-gun.

A con of this game is that the bugs are catastrophically bad. I mean they are so bad that you can glitch to the point where your save file becomes worthless because restarting the game and reloading the save file do not help you get unstuck from the environment.

You really need to install all the community patches and updates before you start a campaign because unless you do, the game will crash. A lot.

There is easily over a hundred hours of content in this game (not counting replays where you pick different choices). The choices matter and really affect play through, and the decisions made by you and others permanently alter the state of the game.

The other thing that annoys me is that traversing through DC is pretty tedious because you must use the metro system since so many parts of the city are obstructed by rubble, and often in ways that don't make sense geographically. Sometimes the map can help you figure out which metro you can use but a lot of your navigation will come from trial and error and you'll  have to revisit the same metro stations over and over trying to reach your destination. The metro maps provided in game don't provide a comprehensive list of all the stations accessible nor do they give you a detailed architecture of the tunnels, you'll have to make your way through it yourself and they are quite dangerous. Save often.

I'm 81 hours into it and while I took the trouble of visiting every single explorable location on the map, I think I've only actually entered and interacted with maybe 40% of them. I really wish I had installed all the community patches and mods before launching the campaign because the time I would have saved from not dealing with bugs would have allowed me to progress through the game much more quickly.

Final score: 8.5/10 with a point deducted for how bad the bugs are and half a point deducted for the tediousness of navigating the metro. To be fair, the mutants inhabiting it in this game aren't much more hostile than the people you'll encounter on the train in real life, but the navigation could be more clear in terms of which stops are connected.

Definite buy.

Backstory: I played this game sometime in 2009, when I was a very young kid who should NOT have been playing this game, but I digress....this was my first Fallout game, and my first Bethesda RPG title, and I was hooked from the start. I spent many hours on this game on my Xbox (and later PS3) and loved just about every second I spent on this. 13 years later, and I'm still convinced this is my favorite Fallout title, possibly a contender for my favorite video game of all time.

Pros
-Fun bits of storytelling and writing across many instances in the game, mostly in side quests, but sprinkled into the main plot too
-Radio system is revolutionary to the series, and creates not just a tone modifier for the game's feel, but also reinforces you with a station that has a personality that provides you with feedback on your decisions and actions (basically, does he think what you did in this town was good or bad); It makes you feel like your actions have impact and consequences
-The game is very subtle in it's willingness to guide the player, but it succeeds, and very actively encourages the player to explore, which is great because there are so many dungeons scattered all over the wasteland
-Fun, adventurous DLC

Cons
-It's basically a huge pain to even get to work properly on devices with Windows 8 and newer
-Even if you get it to run properly on a newer device, it's still an old Bethesda game, so bugs galore
-Linear plot-line, very easy to be discouraged when you know it only leads to the same ending (side quests are still very fun)
-Level scaling gets too easy at a certain point in the game; even on Very Hard difficulty, once you reach a certain level, only a handful of enemies will give you any challenge. It can make progression and achievement very boring very fast
-Metro tunnels are not properly introduced and are thus very confusing to many players, even veterans. I didn't even learn how it worked until I watched a youtuber replay Fallout 3 and when he actively explained how the metro system actually worked (this is about 14 years after I had ever picked up the game in the first place)

Overall, this is easily hands down my favorite Fallout game, and favorite Bethesda RPG to date, and I strongly encourage this game to anybody who's even remotely interested in any of Bethesda's other RPGs, including any other Fallout title, or Elder Scrolls.

The Tesla Cannon weapon added by Broken Steel is too powerful, with enough ammo you can destroy any enemy in the game.

The quests were fun if a little boring, however you can easily just save before every speech check in order to bypass the games speech checks. Speech being one of the most important skills to invest points into of course. The side quests and main quest are some of the high points of the game and pretty much the reason for playing it in the first place. Still, the voice acting is terrible and all of the characters are forgettable and one dimensional.

The Deathclaws and Super Mutants were never strong enough. By level 15 the Deathclaws are like puppies and the super mutants are incredibly easy to take down with the sniper rifle or Chinese Assault Rifle. They could have made the game more difficult by making stimpacks rarer and more pricey to buy from merchants. Its insanely easy to become rich in the Capital Wasteland as well.

You could hypothetically just wait endlessly and then return to locations where there’s raiders to get infinite amounts of experience points. Another problem with the game is that energy weapons are not available to the player until they progress significantly in the game. This is not true to how a Fallout game is supposed to be designed. Energy weapons such as the laser and plasma pistols are supposed to be found very early in the game for a player that wants to make an energy weapons oriented protagonist. There's some pointless npcs in the game. Also the Brotherhood of Steel is not supposed to be helping the people in the wasteland if you know about Fallout's lore.

The Karma System always made sense to me. To people who haven't gotten around to playing Fallout 3, the game will occasionally reward the player for not doing things that are unlawful. An npc in Megaton will occasionally give you stimpacks and ammo if you disarm the bomb and have very good karma. If you choose to be sadistic and kill people indiscriminately, you can join the slavers who will reward you for enslaving innocent people. This will give you very evil karma and also I'll never understand people who just kill the games non hostile npc's for no real reason.

Another point to add is that in the original Fallout's, there were casinos. There's enough space in The Capital Wasteland to have included casinos for the hell of it. But for some reason the developers never found the time to put them in the game.

Fallout: New Vegas is undeniably a better game than this. That fact Doesn't stop this from being my favourite Fallout game. 

The world is amazing, I love having an adventure in the barren, almost horrifying at times Capital Wasteland scavenging ruins and struggling to survive encounters (during the early game at least), and the fact that most unique weapons and bobbleheads can be found in the wild rather than from doing quests is a great way to make exploring feel fun. 

Although I prefer the New Vegas soundtrack, the soundtrack here, both ambient and radio, does an excellent job thematically, even if Bethesda just followed what Black Isle did using "I Don't Want to Set the World on Fire" during the Fallout 1 intro. 

The plot, although not the strongest, replicated a classic Fallout story well enough, although the real fun is in the side quests. Superhuman Gambit, Oasis, Wasteland Survival Guide and Big Trouble in Big Town for example are all really fun, well created quests.

Although the gun-play is kind of weak (no ADS) this doesn't stop it from still being fun. Weapons like the Combat Shotgun, Lincoln's Repeater, the Sniper Rifle and more feel amazing to fire in part due to the sound design and how corpses rag doll and explode in the Gamebryo engine (oh, how I miss you.).

The enemy design is so unique despite how much is carried over from previous entries in the series. Mirelurks fit the 50's monster design so well, and it's a shame that Fallout 4 redesigned the ghouls considering how well made they were in this generation.

There is so much more I could write about here, but I think I've illustrated what I think well enough. I love Fallout 3, and if you haven't played it, give it a chance. Just because it's outclassed by New Vegas doesn't mean Fallout 3 isn't also a great game in of its own right.

A spit in the face of two of the greatest CRPGs of all time. This piss poor excuse for a role playing game will forever be the dried and crusty brown skid mark on the Fallout franchise. The game is too bright and happy, too clean in so many ways and they did almost nothing to respect the classic games which came before it. Bethesda bought the rights to an amazing and iconic franchise, riding the wave of classic CRPG nostalgia sparked by Dragon Age: Origins, and attempted to cash out with little effort or care beyond their marketing campaign.

Gameplay issues such as enemy levels scaling to match the player and being given unique or powerful weapons with too low of a durability rating to make them viable alternatives to your starting gear are a slap in the face to the history of this amazing series. 

By the time the events of Fallout 2 had rolled around, The wasteland was becoming a somewhat progressive place (relatively speaking), with intelligent deathclaws roaming about and Super Mutants like Marcus working together with humans, towards a future of mutual understanding and equality. Both have now been relegated to mindless enemies for you to blow apart in amazing, detailed 3D! Speaking of which, how is it possible that the original Fallout games had more satisfying death animations than this over-budgeted AAA title?

Game of the Year??? Yeah, maybe before Gamer Gate and with every gaming magazine plastered with another ad for whatever mediocre gaming experience that Bethesda was going to squeeze out from betwixt their hairy butt cheeks that quarter. Seriously, and this irks me to no end, the year that Skyrim came out was the year that Dark Souls debuted. Game Informer awarded Skyrim Game of the Year and Dark Souls was relegated to an honorable mention for the Capra Demon. Did any self respecting gamer who spent any length of time on both titles actually come away thinking that Skyrim was the better, more memorable experience? Much of the same can be said for Fallout 3.

I remember asking buddies at the time what they thought of the game and the general consensus was that the game was interesting and fun to explore, but that it was forgettable with a bad ending. Personally, having been a massive fan of both Fallout 1 and 2 and having played Arena, Daggerfall, and Morrowind, I was appalled and genuinely sick at the idea of Bethesda getting their hands on such a huge piece of my childhood and I knew from the beginning what an absolute bore this game was going to turn out to be. I was right. I was completely right. 

So, I suppose the best that can be said for this game is that it definitely delivered on what anyone experienced with Bethesda trash could or would expect and it certainly takes a degree of talent to take the polished gems that were Fallout 1 and 2 and distill them into reeking, steaming piles of Brahmin dung which are somehow more forgettable and boring than any Elder Scrolls game they've shat out before.

1/10

It's a cool game. I have attempted to play Fallout 1, but never really got into it. So, Fallout 3 is the first real Fallout game I've played, and I'm very interesting in this series's story and lore.

Most of my gameplay was similar to my Skyrim gameplay; I sneaked all the time and sniped enemies from afar. If this got up close and personal, my shotgun did the talking. It's quite nice.

The rest everything else depended on skills. Speech to haggle better rewards and persuade people. Lockpicking to gain access to pre- nuclear holocaust containers and doors. Science to hack computers and manipulate turrets to go rogue. Repair to disarm traps and improve weapons and armor. There's all sorts of fun stuff. In addition to all, there's quite a few unique perks that have an interesting effect on your gameplay.

Not much in the way of modding. I did play the game with "essential" mods; the kind of mods that improve performance and fix bugs. Despite them, my game did crash a couple of times. But *only* a couple of times total, so I'd say that's pretty darn good from a Bethesda game.

Do give it a try. Capital Wasteland can be a depressing place at times, but there's plenty of adventure to be had. And you can listen to in-game radio while at it!

Don't fool yourself. It's a vintage game complete with vintage software, and sometimes old programs have issues running on software and hardware built afterward. However, a vintage game still playing well over its lifespan is far better quality than anything Bethesda made after 2011, even if its structure is considered fundamental in today's terms. 

The atmosphere played in pure vanilla is relatively stale, and mods will help breathe some more life back into Fallout 3. Some modifications even combine Fallout 3 and New Vegas to utilize the engine Obsidian used to run New Vegas. It can still be enjoyed with or without mods, but the game's outstanding title has been slowly fading away.

So if you find a sale and Fallout 3 is only a few dollars, grab it, start fighting the good fight, and prepare yourself to be astounded, bedazzled, and otherwise stupefied.

This game is far superior to Fallout 4 and Fallout 76, and with Godd Howard constantly re-releasing TES:Skyrim with updated graphics and new stuff to do, I'm surprised he or someone high up at Bethesda hasn't decided to remaster this game at least once, to optimise it for later released OS's like Windows 10... It took Bethesda 10 years just to remove Games for Windows Live (GfWL), just to make it a tad bit more playable. Those guys needs to get their priority's straight. 

Anyways, on to the subject at hand, although graphically dated, this game is my favourite Fallout, for multiple reasons.
For starters, it was the first Fallout game I ever played, which got me into the series of Fallout games in general, so it has the nostalgia effect.
Secondly, the writing and setting, is far superior to Fallout 4 & 76, making it a proper RPG with multiple good / bad dialogue options & positive / negative Karma.
It also provides you with a decent reason to start fighting the "bad guys" other than just a single-minded purpose, (Something that is lacking in other 3D Fallout games aside from Fallout: New Vegas) - To provide clean water to the Capital Wasteland.

Fallout 3 boasts a decent sized map, which provides an enjoyable exploration of a unique location, Washington D.C. With many landmarks to find, like the Washington Monument, the Capitol Building, Abraham Lincoln Memorial just to name a few.

Probably the best parts though, are the varying DLC's... Each one is something completely different and very enjoyable
Unfortunately, there's no achievements, any sense of achievement hunting was removed in the update that got rid of GfWL. Hopefully in the future they'll add steam achievements to the game but I doubt it.

Aside from the lack of achievements, the matter of it not being optimised for WIN10 OS resulting in more than a few crashes and the fact that it's graphically dated, this is still an amazing game, worth adding to your library at least.

Side Note: I had a disk copy of Fallout 3 GOTY, before owning it on Steam, so the amount of hours I've put into this game are probably triple the amount shown.

Fallout 3 was a classic in its day and is still worth purchasing to see an important stage in the evolution of the classic “Bethesda RPG” style. However, this particular game has aged worse than its peers, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/22380/Fallout_New_Vegas/]Fallout New Vegas[/url] and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/22330/The_Elder_Scrolls_IV_Oblivion_Game_of_the_Year_Edition/]Elder Scrolls Oblivion[/url]. FO3 lacks the narrative brilliance of FNV (FO3's main ending is particularly notoriously bad), and the vibrant, exciting world of Oblivion. The game's palette is too grey, the textures are bad, and it suffers from excessive instancing, especially around the DC Ruins, which compare very unfavourably to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/377160/Fallout_4/]Fallout 4[/url]'s Boston. Yet this is still a game that you can enjoy for dozens of hours, just through the simple beauty of the gameplay loop: shoot; loot; go back to town to trade and to hand in quests; repeat. For that reason I can still recommend Fallout 3 despite the caveats.

After playing all the Fallout games, I can say that this one is the best for the atmosphere and the exploration but falls a little short in it's quests. The main story is pretty bad and way too short, but when you focus more on just exploring through the capital wasteland then you'll find there are so many unique places to find and items to loot. I had a lot of fun taking my science/speech build through it and hacking systems, digging up files and solving puzzles; never knowing what was gonna be around the corner. And the mod support for this game is amazing and there are some really unique mods out there that added to my experience as well

New Vegas has better dlcs but the ones here were good too, just very short and not really fulfilling like New Vegas's were. The weapons and armor you get from them are probably the best thing about them since the stories are a little basic, with Point Lookout being the exception. The Pitt seemed promising, but again it was way too short!

And like all Bethesda games, the mods are all great. I especially liked the Alton, IL mod that added new quests and a new area twice as big as Point Lookout. Then there was a mansion mod which was cool, landscape mods, game play changes, audio overhauls and bug fixes which ensured I was able to run at a smooth 60 fps with very minimal crashes in my play through. All in all I would give it a 7/10, 2nd favorite Fallout game

So far, so good after a bit of Troubleshooting. The game would not initially load past the Launcher screen in Windows 10/11 with a decent PC. The following solution worked from MiloTheGamingFox's video "Fallout 3 GOTY (How to Fix) 1.7.0.4"

1) Windows Search -> type "Graphics Settings"
2) Under Custom options for apps ->  select the "Browse" button
3) Navigate to your Games Location* -> find the executable file "FalloutLauncherSteam" and select "Add"
4) Repeat #2  but select another file -> find the executable file "Fallout3" and select "Add"
5) Still in the Graphics Settings -> click on the newly created "Fallout 3 Launcher" icon from the list below the browse button; select "Options"; select "High Performance"
6) Still in the Graphics Settings -> click on the newly created "Fallout3" icon from the list below the browse button; select "Options"; select "High Performance"
7) Start Fallout 3 from Steam like normal -> Success!

*To do all of this, you need to find your Steam games folder. Example: .../Steam/Steamapps/Common/Fallout 3 goty/ to locate the two files in steps #3 and #4 above. Most likely the initial folder for Steam will be on your Drive (like C:/, D:/, etc.) under ".../Program Files (x86)". If you setup a custom Steam folder location like me, your file path may vary. I hope this helps someone, who can't start this older game on a newer PC...

My fucking favorite. Amazing game. Bethesda does an incredible job of creating a hyper-immersive world that feels beyond neglected and totally haunted. Feels like real nuclear annihilation. The soundtrack has some truly awesome jazz hits ('Butcher Pete' - Roy Brown) that will stick with you for years after playing. I feel that Bethesda's writing talent really shows in this game - not particularly the main quest - but all the side narratives that you stumble upon randomly are all so fascinating and add so much depth to the world. The gunplay kinda sucks ass, but VATS makes up for it with these theatrical, dramatic and cinematic kills that are beyond satisfying. The gore is cheesy but super fun to watch (Bloody mess perk). FO3 is an unforgettable experience once you get properly immersed. I recommend playing it when you're not in a hurry, and have time to stop and smell the flowers. It's also creepy asf!!!!!!!! I would tag this game as Horror for sure. Play it!!!!! Lots of unsung praises from this classic gem.

**Did you notice the little box above that says "not optimized for windows 7 or later"? 

This game *still* will not work on Windows 11, 10, or 8. Steam is selling games that don't work. Seems like a big "fuck you" to the customer to me. 

As for the game itself, it has some minor rough edges here and there, but it's still rated above Fallout 4......New Vegas is probably the best so far, but Fallout 3 is a great game. A classic, at this point I suppose you'd say. I could wish the first-person shooter aspects were a bit more clean and smooth, but it's not a game breaker even if you never use VATS mode. I've played and replayed through this big apocalyptic sandbox world I don't know how many times now, it's still fun. The choices you make actually change things!! Not fake "role-play" where you get three dialog choices and all get the same end result. You can seduce, smooth talk and bribe your way through problems, you can murder your way through problems, sneak past, or whatever you want to do. 


**The Verdict:  Absolutely worth the buy!....Just not on steam. Get a disc and run it in compatability mode, wait for it to be on GOG where they actually support what they sell, just don't buy a nonworking game from steam, even on sale. I have to say no, to recommending products that are inoperable. I highly recommend the game, I just cannot recommend steam.

It's story is crap, writing is crap, gameplay is crap, most weapons are crap, most items are crap, most quests are crap. This game spews crap. This game has some of the weakest writing I have ever seen in a major release. The world makes absolutely no sense, both by itself and within the series as a whole. Yeah it's atmospheric and whatnot, but once you question anything about this world, it all falls apart in both logic and consistency. There's a water crisis that no one besides like 5 people care about, there's no food anywhere, none of the major settlements grow anything, and the major factions are all rehashes from the classic games and just appear on the other side of the continent for the most bizzare reasons. I've read before that this game tried way to hard to be a Fallout game that it ended up feeling like poorly written fanfiction, and I have to agree completely.

There is however, moments of greatness. The world is very detailed and you can tell a lot of work went into the overall art style. Exploration is decent but I would say a tad-bit overrated since there's many spots that feel too much the same and the loot variety is lacking. But there's still some nice secrets to find. The random encounter system is also decent but the game relies too heavily on it to show it's world building. Almost nothing in the world changes on your actions even with Broken Steel.   All of these things are nice but overall doesn't change the fact that this game's praise is fueled primarily by fan's rose-tinted nostalgia. 

Although the base game alone is a solid 4/10, the GOTY makes up for it as some of the DLCs are great, most notably The Pitt and Point Lookout. Fallout 3 is a game with many flaws and some good things too.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
What a lazy one. The biggest problem in the game, first of all, in all main quest seems your father is the game protagonist and you are a minor character in your own story. The story was poorly written with an unbelievable ending, a lot of plotholes, boring, and so much wasted potential, like the first Enclave encounter, speaking of Enclave, they're so weak and pathetic in this game. The secondary quests are good as usual in Bethesda games.
Almost DLCs are boring, The Pitt is the best one.
Broken Steel boring
Operation Anchorage:  ok
Point Lookout: boring af
Mothership Zeta: starts well but becomes boring

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The best part of the game. A morbid and dark atmosphere, probably the best in the franchise, exploring the wasteland is always good, the caverns, buildings, and of course, the vaults, except for the metro stations, the first time you explore might be good, but after a while, it's just unbearable.

[h1]Bugs/technical issues:[/h1]
You didn't think you'd not suffer with them, did you? It's Bugthesda after all.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Good gameplay and secondary missions, but a bad main story. I only recommend it to those who want to know and play the other fallout games beyond 4/New Vegas.

Fallout 3 is a post apocalyptic role playing game it has a very good story, great dlc, great characters, a lot of choices, and an immersive post apocalyptic open world. However, Unlike many games that offer the level of freedom and choice found here, Fallout 3 has an exciting, top-notch main story. It all comes together for a spectacular climax that is just flat out awesome. Rather than spoil the story, I'll simply say that it does not disappoint. What left me most impressed was how many different ways you can progress through the game. Lying, stealing, hacking, fighting; they're all open for you to use to solve problems. If you play your cards right you can even talk your way into, or luck upon, situations that offer massive shortcuts. The system is so flexible that the possible permutations are almost mind boggling. And yet it all ties back together in the end. And there is a true end to this game. Once you finish Fallout 3 and view the ending, you're booted back to the main menu. You'll have to load up a prior save if you want to continue exploring with that character. Fallout 3 is one of my favourite games of all time I highly recommend this game. 10/10

Let's start off with what most of us know.

Fallout 3 treats modern PC's (modern being anything past the original OS' it was designed for) as the true post apocolyptic wasteland.

The plus side is, we are PC gamer's, meaning we know a Nexus way to download a very helpful Mod from smart people to trick our PC's into believing we in 2008 and quite easily for a full 60+ FPS experience on Windows 11.

My hour count doesn't represent the years I have spent in the Wasteland because I played on consoles and even off disk for PC for a while.

It does what the modern Fallout games has gone and at this point that doesn't really need a review because the style of RPG is either for you or it's not but this game has one key aspect. Picking stuff up not to just add to your inventory but wave it around in the physical world.

There is something rather gratifying with say, grabbing the disembodied head of Mister Burke and waving it around like a medieval guard looking for a pike to stick it on saying to yourself "Look! Without me you people of Megaton would be atomised!" That is the sort of "extra" freedom I really appreciate.

That and skeletons. Credit where credit is due to being able to walk into houses and see the old skeleton remains of unlucky residents who didn't have a vault for protection. 

I guess that is my summary. Don't keep this game in a vault like the protagonists early years. Go back, dig it out and explore like it was 2008. Your PC will enjoy the trip back in time. It will make it feel young and overpowered again.

A few years later, you haven't been to the restaurant that you went to prior in a while. You make your way there and see that there's a grand reopening for the restaurant and supposedly its under new management. This is exciting! You make your way in and the interior looks entirely different and the place has renamed itself into "Bethesda" instead of "Black Isle". That's a name that's familiar, they have a pizza place down the road with their famous "Oblivion" pizza. You sit down and look at the menu, which there is a menu now, its not just the special of the day anymore. There still is a special, "Fallout 3": spaghetti with eyeball meatballs. Sounds familiar enough, you had eyeballs at this place before and they were starting to grow on you. You ask the waiter for the special and they scoff at you and spit on your table. After a couple hours of waiting the spaghetti finally gets to you. Cold. The eyeballs have gone hard, the noodles are wet and everyone else in the restaurant is eating it up like there's no tomorrow. Its super packed where it wasn't before. You decide to try it, nothing bad can happen surely. Its a bad flavor. The eyeballs exist but they don't have the same seasoning the noodles just aren't doing it for you and you're pretty sure the sauce is made of piss and spit. Its new, its a change of pace with a little familiarity, its not for you. The waiter comes to your table afterward and you decide its time to ask a few questions.
"Why don't these eyeballs taste the same? Why is it so different if it's the same restaurant?"
He says
"What are you talking about you moron. I hate you, there was never another restaurant here. It's only ever been us. We made this place and its ours. Desert is on the way."
Desert? You never ordered desert.
The desert comes and it looks heavy. Chocolate flowing everywhere and the cake its on its full of choco chips. Its good, tasty, you can't finish it all. It's too much. You pay your bill and are punched on the way to your car. 
By the waiter.

The game:
Story: 4.5/5 Whatever you want it to be. It's great.
Graphics: 3.5/5 Good enough, but it's PS3 so it's not as good as Fallout 4. Also the 3rd person doesn't have sideways and backwards walking animations so it's a bit like Vice City. Is that a bad thing though? Play in 1st person mode rather, or perhaps there's a mod to change it. Also when you aim the gun in fps mode the gun doesn't move to the middle like in Fallout 4 or any FPS shooter game so you still gonna be using the cursor to aim not your sights. Maybe there's a mod?
Audio: 4/5 Dreary, therefore perfect. Gun sounds aren't bad either.
Gameplay: 4/5 Combat is kinda scuffed but there is a lot to do besides. That being said, this game has real bullets like Fallout New Vegas. It's better than Fallout 4's bullet teleport system. You can actually have a shootout. On normal mode the game is rather challenging especially when you lack guns, stats and equipment. You might have to use the baseball bat and VATS for a while.

Note: Fallout 3 and Fallout 3 GOTY are notoriously unplayable without fixing them. It depends on the system, for me it just required running the system as administrator on Windows Vista but it depends. Also, if you do play this game TURN AUTO SAVE OFF. For whatever reason, saving a game file over a previous save slowly corrupts your game. This also happened to my ps3 version of the game, and when I downloaded the game on a new computer and didn't do that the game stays so smooth. Also, in case you can't tell, it does not save playtime properly. Unless you think I beat the whole game and its DLC in 118 minutes. 

Fallout 3 has recieved a lot of backlash in the past while, I guess as a result of New Vegas blowing up. As a Fallout game it doesn't offer anywhere near the customisation or RPG dialogue the other games do. The thing is though, I don't judge games on if they fill up to expectations. But if you've only played New Vegas, this game will disappoint - play Fallout 2 instead, which for my money IS the best Fallout game.

If however, you're an avid Bethesda fan, this game will probably exceed your expectations. Bethesda doesn't really care about creating your character - you simply are the Lone Wanderer, you can't really change much other than your very black and white morality. The dialogue is extremely cheesy, and not as rich with options as the other ones. The gameplay is pretty standard, not frustrating but not terribly engaging, only aided by the V.A.T.S. Systems. What Bethesda games always strive with is there worldbuilding, their quests, and their atmosphere and Fallout 3 really exceeds.

Some people don't like how grey and muddy the Capital Wasteland is, but I really like how committed Bethesda is to the post apocalypse. Unlike 1,2 and New Vegas which use the post apocalypse more to create a sense of lawlessness, the ruins and buildings reiterate this feeling of sadness, that you're almost part of a graveyard. There's a ton of content that explains all these little details about the apocalypse, and I love the expansion of details about pre-war America, that was only hinted at in the first two games. The music is great, giving that same atmosphere that was in the first two games. And the radio station - there's something about the way the songs are mixed that despite how different they are all establish this feel that's really hard to explain, but I guess it's just this idea that everything you're encountering has disappeared. 

The dialogue also works for me - it's almost like everyone speaks like they're in the 50s, there's this weird uncanny way of both the words they speak and how they speak. I've played Oblivion which I love, and so I will admit this weird dialogue is kind of endearing to me. In a more serious toned game I guess people don't think it works but for me it adds to this world in a way that makes Fallout more unique. I can understand why people want this to be up to the other game's standards, but I appreciate how strange it all sounds. 

The gameplay is, as I said, kinda standard. The VATS system is awesome, but you don't use it that much. There aren't many weapon varieties, and some weapons are pretty useless. That being said, it isn't boring because the game is fairly difficult at points. It's not hard or anything, but resources are thin, much more than other games, which means that you need to be careful about going into fights. Unlike other Bethesda games where you're just fast travelling for 50% of the game I often am going around finding weapons knowing that the next big quest will require a lot, naturally making me explore. This is great open world design that a lot of the best open world games have - giving you good reasons to explore, but not forcing you to explore.

And at the end of the day, what you play the game for is the quests and they deliver. This hands down has some of the best quests in any game, each side quest with its own unique objectives and themes. There are few simple fetch quests, and the ones that are normally require you to go to somewhere you haven't been, and finding the items themselves are often quite easy. To stopping a super hero showdown, to finding a runaway cyborg, to blowing up a city - these are all quests which are completely optional but all up to main story quest quality. 

It's in the moments where you're exploring the world where the game really shines. It's not a good looking game, but something about the colours, the sound, the designs, the world is just sad but in an interesting way. There's a lot of personality to this world which makes you want to discover everything about it. There are few games where you just want to go back and play multiple times of this length to discover more things, and I think because of how well they've designed this world and how interesting everything is, I've gone back to this game multiple times and I don't leave until I've finished. 

It has flaws, as all things do, but none of them bother me in the slightest, and I just love this game so much, it's a masterpiece in my mind. And, it contains five DLCs, all of them substantial, Point Lookout being maybe my favourite DLC of all time.

Update: Latest updates removed windows live dependency and fixed compatibility issues, but Fallout 3 still didn't run. The solution that finally worked for me was recommended by a contributor on Youtube (thanks Ian Harvel): 
The problem seems to come from Nvidia Graphics settings which are automatically selected when opening Fallout 3. Fixed by going in Settings>System>Display>Graphics then scroll down to "Fallout 3" and select "options". Instead of choosing "Let windows decide" choose power saving and the GPU associated with it (in my case GPU:  AMD Radeon instead of NVIDIA Geforce). Hope this works for others as well.

Game crashes upon launch? Go to C:\Users\Username\Documents\My Games\Fallout3 and delete all the files from this folder and re-run the game, should work after doing this. This is because the game was updated November 2021 and the previous config files you had became incompatible.

Fallout 3 is still a good game, if somewhat flawed and dated. I just wrapped up my fourth or fifth playthrough, and I've enjoyed it every time. If you aren't interested in rambling, the TL;DR is that Fallout 3 has a lot of jank, but it's still got lots of good stuff in it if you can look past it.

It might be my pea brain, but I always thought the story was fine. Not great, not bad. I didn't mind many of the more notorious parts either, though [spoiler]the ending still calling you a yellow-belly coward pussy for not offing yourself is exceptionally dumb after the Broken Steel DLC enabled the ability to make logical choices[/spoiler].

Though I still really enjoy the gameplay, it's always been very rough and somewhat demanding to acclimate to. I'm fine with many of the condition-/skill-related things (e.g. lower means worse aim or slower swings), but the skill-indpendent issue of inconsistent fire rate on weapons is agonizing. You will never be sure if the click of a trigger will produce a shot or not, even if it should. The Pip-Boy is similar in that the game is very persnickety about when it'll let you bring it up. You will grow to loathe explosives fast. Now, on the brighter side, V.A.T.S. and how it's executed, allowing strategizing I probably wouldn't have considered otherwise, like crippling/disarming enemies, which becomes vital on higher difficulties. Speaking of which, I did my recent playthrough on Very Hard difficulty, and the early parts of the game were some of the most intense fun I'd ever had in all my runs, scrounging for ammo and [i]any[/i] healing I could find, limping to a doctor I could barely afford, only to go back out and face seemingly insurmountable encounters, only to survive by the skin of my teeth each time. It was exhausting, but incredibly rewarding and satisfying.

There's a lot to explore in the game, even if you ignore most of the subways. I spent dozens of hours mapping and exploring newly discovered locations, before I'd really touched any quests. The quests themselves took me dozens more, then there's the DLC content, which adds a bunch of good stuff. I didn't track it exactly, but I spent approximately 210-220 hours on my most recent game. The last save I made said 199 hours, but I spent a few days going on "non-canon" escapades around The Capital Wasteland that weren't tracked.

Skip this segment if you want, it talks about stability/performance, but it's one of the big YMMV elements of Bethesda games. Anyway, from the things I've heard, I may have been lucky to not have too many major stability issues. It did have crashes any time an NPC would warn you not to steal owned things, or if they commented on you kicking/manipulating physics objects. A mod to remove theft-related warnings somehow fixed both issues, despite not removing the other reactions. For the rest of the 200+ hours, there were only about 20 random CTD moments, and the rest of the crashes were almost exclusively from alt-tabbing, which I started countering with a quicksave, so it wasn't a big issue (seemed to happen more often if I'd used the Pip-Boy radio). Things ran fine otherwise, with the exception of Point Lookout, where the frame rate would often drop below 60, regardless of quality settings.

It's become a sort of tradition for me to bookend my reviews with summaries, so I'll repeat that Fallout 3 is definitely worth checking out if you are able to forgive its clunkier parts.
