I understand that maybe you are annoyed that the game won't start by itself and you need to apply external solutions but, cute brother, give it a try, you can probably still get benefits from this adventure by latam, sorry I meant the wasteland. The game is from 2008, and although I personally have no qualms about playing games of all levels of graphic quality, it may look a bit old. I'm playing the entire fallout saga. This is the first. Arguably it's fine. The story is not the best but it does get me hooked and continue until the end because it can move you. Characters and varied situations from charismatic to breaking balls. As it is a role-playing game, it will depend on you the reaction you have and your respective decisions. There are many places to discover. Many of them are not that easy to get to, especially in the urban ruins. The external area is very vast. Enemies and creatures of great variety, from mutated fauna through robots and typical groups of criminals to heavily armed organizations and some antagonistic ones. Variety of weapons from pre-war junk to deadly lasers. The gameplay, especially the gunplay is not good. This is something that the developers themselves admitted at the time and served with experience to improve successive products, namely fallout new vegas and 4. Being an RPG, it will depend on the skills that you decide to prioritize the style of play that implement to achieve your goals. Personally, since I like shooters, I played it prioritizing firearms and energy skills and extras that compensate for the "defects" of gunplay, that is, the exaggerated dispersion of certain weapons for example. It can happen that you have a thief with an iron who comes to kill you to loot everything at a very short distance and you could miss several shots at close range despite being aimed correctly. Im gonna start this review by being honest, this review is aimed for people who didnt have the chance to play fallout 3 yet, as a lot people who probably have played this old game by now, I feel that also that there is a lot of people who got into the series with the latest games and missed the third game, I will to start by saying that you shouldn’t play this game right now, instead wait for the upcoming mod that is remaking this game on fallout 4 is going to be a much more viable and satisfying experience, fallout 3 is a good game and I had fun with it but its not a great game enough to be considered a must-play classic, theres a lot of technical issues and the game has aged a lot, its gameplay feels very rough to play today, even modded, I modded the hell out of this game and I have tolerance for older games and still had a lot of moments where I wanted to rip my hairs out, the biggest issues are the crashes even without mods they are present, its not worth to endure all of that for this game so like I said wait for the mod that is remaking it.

Fallout 3 had a chance to show itself and become a famous game because back then when It released it surely was a unique game to play, today a lot of games have copied its format and being a game from 2008 it shows its age in a lot of way, the gunplay simply sucks even with mods, controls and movement feels stiff and there are a lot of jank in the game, stuff like seeing a part of the map floating in the air, falling through the terrain, continuous crashes when entering a new map, npcs behaving weirdly due to some mistake scripting, repetitive quest design, immersion breaking moments and more. The story here starts pretty interesting, Im not going to deep dive into this game’s plot because its widely known by now but while its start is promising I feel like the more I played the less interesting it has become, the story feels very linear and the player agency sometimes feels lacky, plus the game pretty much became a call of duty of sorts in the final missions, the game also lacks a good antagonist and there isnt many memorable characters in the main quest either to make it stand out, the worldbuilding and lore are all well-done but I felt like the main quest lacked good moments or twists that could capture my attention to make it something that could classify this game into a must play, the story here serviceable with a few good moments and is not something that I would say its great.

When it comes to graphics and such the game is old, there is nothing much to be said about that except that it could have used more colors in its art design, the game’s soundtrack is simply great, sound effects arent that good but I used mods to improve it, gameplay-wise the game has issues with balancing and certain design decisions that I cant swallow, like the annoying karma system which can be abused very badly, combat feels very archaic even by 2008 standards, I modded the game to make the gunplay feel a little better, even adding an aim down sights mod and a sprint button because the character is too slow and the world is too big making traversing through the world a bore, plus mixing rpg with fps is not always a good idea because it can lead into frustrating combat scenarios where a normal, almost naked enemy, feeling like a crappy bullet sponge where a shot in the face with a shotgun is not going to even take half of its life bar away. The quest design can be a bit repetitive but its fun to explore at least, getting on the max level is fast, I managed to hit max level and finish the game alongside 4 of its 5 dlcs around 35 hours, I got pretty strong by the end of the game and there wasnt much incentive left to explore when I had a lot of icons left on the map because the game had nothing of significance to show me anymore, apart of a few interesting sidequest stories at least.

Overall your mileage may vary, it took 35 hours like I said to finish the game and 4 of its dlcs, as for dlcs which come with the GOTY edition, none of them felt like a must-do to me, they are just more content for people who want more from the game, I even skipped one of them (mothership zeta) because I was already getting tired of the game and the dlc didnt look like It was worth doing anyway, the only dlc that I would recommend playing is broken steel because its integrated into the game’s main quest altho its inclusion felt very tacked-on, the post-ending main quests are just forced, lacking any sort of caracterization or villain for the enclave, the enemy faction our protagonist is dealing with most of the game, so overall I would say for you to skip the dlcs if you value your time.

To close this review I am going to repeat what I said early in a tl;dr format, its better to wait for the remade version that is being worked on fallout 4 right now, fallout 3 is a good game that is not worth playing today due to its aged gameplay and technical issues, even with mods it just doenst offer something that can elevate this game into a classic must-play level because you will have a hard time trying to get into it and by the end of the day its just not worth it.

I've been making attempts to return to the Bethesda Fallout games with a more open mind towards the series, so this way I can explore the games with a little less bias towards the leftism-embracing Fallout games that were made by Black Isle and Obsidian. I played through Fallout 4 and found myself really enjoying the game for its mechanics and side quest lore. Even if I didn't really enjoy Fallout 4 on "Fallout" standards, I felt like it still sometimes resembled what I liked about the Fallout games. I planned to go into Fallout 3 with the same mindset, and I honestly quite liked Fallout 3 to some extent when I was a kid; moreso than I did enjoy Fallout 4. It's a bit unfortunate my thumbs down will spoil how this review will go down, but I promise I won't have only negative things to say about this game. 

I will say this: I quite like the atmosphere of this game at times. It does a relatively decent job in some areas at capturing the original games' desolate, hopeless atmosphere. Areas like [spoiler]Vault 106[/spoiler] really display the depth and foreshadowing that makes me sometimes forget how much I don't generally prefer Bethesda's stories. I think at times too the side quests can be a bit interesting, and there is certainly quite a bit more depth to your decisions and outcomes than Fallout 4 has. It does somewhat resemble a Fallout game in that merit. There was issues with the game having minimal choices in the game regarding the ending, which made people mad. This was addressed with the Broken Steel DLC. Quite nice, but Broken Steel gets major flak for something else I will gloss upon later. 

Unfortunately that's just about the only positive things I really enjoy about this game. The rest of it really shows its age, and not really in a way that a game like Zelda: Ocarina of Time does. Games like Ocarina of Time have so much love and charm to them, that the flaws I can overlook. Fallout 3 is not like this. It's quite devoid of charm aside from its atmosophere and the rare instances of good writing. The intro is not awful persay, but it definitely is extremely tedious after your 2nd or 3rd playthrough. The main quest in general is just really boring. It feels very dry and linear, and not in a good way.  The choices you have all seem pretty bad, and they drastically change the lore and original tropes that factions had. The Brotherhood of Steel went from techno-fascist hermits in the original series, to bullish neoliberals in this game. Just the stereotypical "good guys" you see in most games that AAA developers make. It makes no reasonable sense why the Brotherhood would've been retconned this way, and I still don't really understand it. The Enclave are the only faction that was brought over that still seems well rooted in their goals. The Raiders went from a vast band of different subgangs with different goals and problems, to just a universal "bad guy". Many enemies in this game have suffered this fate. They don't have much nuance to who they are. It's displayed in full with super mutants. There are only 2 good Super Mutants in this game. Only those two are even remotely intelligent. 

It's not just the lore changes that are poor; the gameplay is pitiful too. Depending on if you have Broken Steel; the gameplay is either  ridiculously easy or annoyingly difficult. In the original; there was very bad difficulty pacing. Quite a few enemies just would die to anything remotely powerful in one/two shots. There were only a few areas in the game that I think were able to be considered difficult, and even at close to max level were not too much of a challenge. With the addition of Broken Steel though; this changes to be even worse than the game just being extremely easy. Broken Steel introduces several enemies once you reach a high enough level. These enemies are extreme bullet sponges that are utterly ridiculous with how much damage they deal. I found myself healing after nearly every fight, and needing to repair armor fast once I ran into these enemies. This is utterly ridiculous game design, and just made a problem even worse. None of the enemies are even really that satisfying to fight. Weapons don't have iron sights, and VATS just feels like a poor compensation for how bad the gunplay is. Even New Vegas fixed a lot of these issues, and I don't mind the gunplay so much on it. This game I just find it frustrating. (I feel necessary to mention I played this on Very easy, and was still having this much trouble late-game. Power armor and all). 

The only real thing I can be thankful for is that this game was successful for its time. It allowed Fallout to achieve a lot more appeal, and gave Bethesda the confidence to let former-Black Isle employees to make their own game out of the scraps of the cancelled Fallout 3 they were planning. It also allowed Fallout 4 to right many of the wrongs  that Fallout 3 made. As I played this more and more, I realized I enjoyed this as a kid because i was not fully aware of what Fallout was, and how much better the writing and gameplay was on those other games. I had more fun not taking the game seriously, which is not really what Fallout is supposed to be. I only did Operation Anchorage so far, and I do think that I will update this at the end to see if those DLC's redeem things in some way, but I am unsure. 

For now; I don't think this game is worth purchasing. Buy Fallout: New Vegas or Fallout 4, and live with the fact that you don't have to experience this game, as it allowed much better games to be made.

Great game.  Works on Win 10 and 11.  I had problems running the game initially, but was able to fix it by removing old video and audio codecs from obsolete software that was installed way back when on my old, but updated, rig.  Running nvidia 1650 gpu with 8 gigs of ram on an ancient motherboard.  Wife's new Win 11 rig had no issues.  Incredibly ancient Win 10 laptop using horrible on-board gpu had no issues.  So if u are having issues installing and running this game, its probably something particular to your rig, and not Bethesda's fault.  That said, I havent played the Steam versions of Fallout 3 and Fallout NV for more than a few hours each, but since cleaning my codecs, there have been no issues for me.

As for rating the game:  It has held up great over the years.  I love hearing Malcolm McDowell and Liam Neeson's voiceovers.  Simply awesome.

The game didn't start for me at first because it didn't see my Nvidia card and couldn't use the Intel one. Fixed with this:
https://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/17209/

The game is nice, though, if you are not looking particularly for the Capital Wasteland and just want some nice Fallout game, I would rather opt for the New Vegas.
The Capital Wasteland feels much emptier than the Mojave, the world is big, but there isn't really much to do in it. By finishing the main quest you'll have almost two thirds of the map undiscovered. There are not many side quests or activities, and many of which are there are not quite entertaining.
 After the New Vegas it really lacks a hardcore mode, SPECIAL checks in dialogs, better craft system, good economy model (if you didn't cheat in casinos of NV of course), factions, disguise by using faction clothes, interesting small quests and dialog options here and there, and many more. Some of that can be added with mods, but still not everything.

As per DLCs, since I can't evaluate them separately:
1. Operation Anchorage - the Alaska scenery is awesome, and the plot isn't bad, but it feels more like Call of Duty rather than Fallout.
Not sure if I'd like to play it again.
I'm not a big fan of that kind of games, so might do it again only for a Gauss Rifle or the sword.
2. Point Lookout - the location itself is great and the inhabitants are quite interesting, but I was quite disappointed with the main quest. I wish there was something more about the location history and the inhabitants, I wish to learn how they changed into what they are.
The main quest is not that bad itself, but feels like a lost opportunity to me.
3. The Pitt - I liked this one. They've made a great job with the city and the story.
Recommended.
4. Mothership Zeta - is a real fun, especially liked the NPCs stories and collecting the audiologs of kidnapped.
I'd definitely play it again.
5. Broken Steel - well, you've got to have it to go on after the main quest.
Is a bit rushy, but not bad, shows the Enclave main base and the side quests are fine.

In general the only things I found better here comparing to the NV are the start of the game, which is more quick and interesting, minimum crashes and better DLCs.

I'll just wait for FOSE to update or I'll try looking into A Tale Of Two Wastelands which combines both Vegas and 3 into one game, but these days I can't be bothered trying to install that.

Despite the fact that I enjoy the fallout games, it pains me to give one a negative review. Fallout 3 was the first game developed by Bethesda in 2008 and honestly they got the formula for a 'good' Fallout game completely wrong.

Fallout 1, 2 and New Vegas are all incredibly well made and are examples of what Fallout games should look like. Almost nothing in Fallout 3 makes any sense whatsoever, the enemies, factions and even the currency just don't make sense. The repair system is all wrong, the writing is terrible and the story is utter garbage, just to name a few. 

However, this doesn't make Fallout 3 a 'bad' game, in fact the environment was very well done and some of the side quests were indeed interesting. Unfortunately, Fallout 3 suffers from one final thing, map design. There are a lot of very interesting quests that are well done, you just can't get to them because of their location. One of the best in the game is found on the far east of the map, but the only way to know to go to this seemingly boring town is via a terminal in the far south of the map. See the problem? this quest isn't the only one and there are certainly more that are like this. 

It is because of this that I cannot recommend Fallout 3, I have been meaning to revisit the game and will definitely update this review when I do if my opinion has changed.

I awoke in the night to a sound... No, it was not an ordinary sound like a cat or the wind, but to the sound of an enthusiastic man on the radio. Not just any radio station, mind you! This man was broadcasting from the legendary Galaxy News Radio itself! So, this got me thinking, am I having one of those episodes again where I think I'm still playing a Fallout game even though I'm clearly not? Despite being sure that I was not near my computer, I could not be sure, so I began walking around as if I was in the game. My mother sees me and asks why I'm sneaking around in my own house, and I replied that there were raiders about. However, after thinking about it, I couldn't be sure she wasn't a raider herself. So, I grabbed a pan and wacked her on the head for good measure, since my current playthrough uses melee weapons.

Now that I had escaped my home, I quickly found that I was indeed in the middle of a psychotic episode, yet I still felt as though something was wrong. Then it hit me: My father is missing. It all makes sense now! He left years ago to get some milk and never returned, just like the protagonist's father in the hit Bethesda game, Fallout 3! With this, I knew I wasn't dreaming, and journeyed to find the nearest metro station so I could spend the next 40 hours in there. Why, you ask? Because war... war never changes... also because literally half the game is in the fucking subway. As I traverse the tunnels listening to the extravagant man on the radio while killing countless ghouls, I can feel myself falling away, as though my memories were leaves on an autumn tree. When I finally reach the door to the surface, I am no longer who I was. I am a vault dweller, a former citizen of Vault 101 who is in search of their father James. Will I ever find him? Will I ever be rid of subway tunnels? Will Three Dog finally stop playing the song "Let's Go Sunning" by the artist Jack Shaindlin? The world may never know, but I do know one thing, and it's that war... war is fucking stupid. But laser guns are awesome, so it's a small price to pay for the devastation of humanity!

Some minor gameplay things that bothered me and may bother you too:
--No skipping the intro/tutorial (makes replayability difficult. that is, if there weren't game-crashing bugs, making playability difficult in the first place)
--Movement feels slow for an open world game. Walking is excruciatingly slow
--Shooting over/around objects is difficult because they don't end where they appear to
--Invisible walls are abundant within the map. You'll be climbing over a pile of rubble (as you do), and then you can't go further. You'll have to find a way around. It's immersion-breaking 

Bugs:
--The game crashes sometimes. This is why I stopped playing it initially and how I learned that it's "not supported on windows 10". Like, did you really just sell me this game... for windows 10... that might not work... on windows 10?
--If you quick-save while running, you'll keep running in that direction until you press that key again. 
--Alt-tabbing will crash the game, almost like it's not supported on the operating system that I'm using...
--Other minor and open-world bugs that I've noticed, are not nearly as frustrating, (like creatures being in the walls or ground. They show up on my map and I can hear them, but they are pretty certainly not intractable)

Despite these problems, this is still Fallout, which I really enjoy. I'm still trying to power(armor) through it and it does have redeeming qualities, for sure. This post just helps me feel better, as I recently crashed out after shooting a guy, because, you know, bugs...

This review will be for people who have not yet delved into Bethesda's world of Fallout.

This RPG was my 2nd Bethesda game and my first Fallout game, and I very much love it.  I have played it 3 times. The game has a create your own character aspect that truly matters during playtime. You have a karma level that affects the way NPCs react to you, you have a very vast skill tree with extra assets, and you get to pick up pretty much anything in the wasteland that you come across. There is a bartering system. There are tons of side tasks along with the main quest line. Your choices matter and will change the outcome of the game. You can choose your weapon of choice (guns, melee, unarmed) but melee is very wonky. You have companion options as well. If you have played Skyrim or Oblivion, it is very similar. The storyline is immersive and intriguing, as well as all the characters you meet and the DLCs.

That being said, CHECK YOUR COMPUTER FOR SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS BEFORE YOU BUY. Many people have issues starting the game (I haven't, but I have had it crash on me). Bethesda's early games crash so frequently, and that is a huge drawback to this game.

Anyways I played this game 5 times ever since 2010. Though I just started another playthrough to try the DLC. I will only talk about the DLC since everyone who reads this must've played Falllout3 sometime in their life.

[h1]Point Lookout[/h1]

In my opinion, the best DLC for Fallout 3. Taking place southern part of Maryland in a swampy area, you enter an area untouched by the nuclear bombs. As you explore, you befriend a ghoul named Desmond, who is fighting his long-time rival.  You can either help him or help his rival, but of course, there is a plot twist in the end that I will end here. There are new enemies such as swamp folk, tribals, and swamp ghouls. New weapons: Axe, double-barreled shotgun, lever-action rifle. And new characters. The map has more locations than all the other DLCs. The story is actually interesting to me too and I would also say this was the longest DLC in Fallout 3, so that's a plus.

[h1]The Pitt[/h1]

This was good, I liked the overall story and atmosphere of Pittsburgh. Basically, it starts off when you respond to a distress signal from a runaway slave that escaped the raider city of the Pitt or basically Pittsburgh. He tasks you to help him free the slaves and find a cure to help the people of the town. The area of the Pitt is laid out to where there's a steelyard (kind of like the "playground" of the DLC), there's an arena, and the downtown area that consists of the slaves and the slavers. And introducing into the enemy field are trogs. Honestly, they're the scariest enemies of the DLC and a bitch to fight if you are doing a VATS-less run. I would also say the "cure" at the end, really did change my choices to help each character, which I can appreciate a lot in this DLC.

[h1]Broken Steel[/h1]

Okay, I would say this should've been part of the main game. It's basically the alternative end-game of fallout 3. [spoiler]Basically after you "die" from activating the purifier in the end game, you wake up 2 weeks later and are tasked with eliminating the last remaining Enclave.[/spoiler] As this allows you to continue playing the game after the ending too. This DLC also adds three new enemies that are encountered in the main fallout 3 game. Super mutant overlord, albino rad scorpion, and feral ghoul reaver (who is a bitch to fight every time). Also comes with new weapons (tesla cannon like on liberty prime) and a few new pieces of armor. Honestly, this DLC is just for when you want to continue playing after the ending.

[h1]Operation Anchorage[/h1]

Now this DLC is pretty short and its completely skippable. Basically, you get message from Brother hood outcasts, you meet them, they can't get armory open unless you complete simulation of Chinese invasion in Alaska before the bombs dropped. Get Chinese stealth armor, the end. This DLC is completely linear, you need to complete said objective like blow up anti-air turret, raid bunker, then raid final boss building and done. You don't get to use your weapons from the main game, you have to use guns they provide you only in the simulation. All this for stealth armor and gauss rifle? It's your choice if you want to play 2 hours' worth of awkward combat and a useless story for that.

[h1]Mothership Zeta[/h1]

I would definitely skip this DLC if I was you. At first, I thought this would be a favorite, but no it's the worst DLC of the other 4. Super linear story with bullet sponge aliens that are even more a bitch to fight on higher levels for some reason and the characters are just not likable at all. I would bring in at least 100 stimpacks before you start DLC too. I guess what I liked most was the weapons? Even though I never used them ever again after completing said DLC. The combat though is literally all corridor shooting too almost the whole way. It almost felt like the developers wanted a more creepy atmosphere and story for this DLC, but it just fell off. Too bad I thought the Point Lookout was excellent bringing in the foggy swampy dark tone of the atmosphere. Also, kill the samurai companion right away if you want to get his sword and armor as he is useless in combat. Sorry for my rant on this DLC.

When I first played Fallout 3, its atmosphere and open world was a nice, comforting world to escape into. For some people, they already have this from some newer, fancier game. But for me, it's still the one I go back to. I probably haven't tried enough of the newer games yet, so for me, it's still a must-have experience.

A lot of the DLC are just chores, long paths of forced combat and fetching--like a bad FPS. I regret trying them all and recommend not enabling them. They give you busted items, the best in the game--but is that a good thing?

Play the real game. Out of all the DLC, maybe only the Pitt is worth a play through or two, and only Point Lookout I would really say has the replay value of Fallout 3 itself.

Yes, it is buggy on steam in 2022. Yes, the main story-line was less satisfying than most of the side quest. But this game is fantastic. After this last play through, I remembered why Bethesda was unmatched at its time. A few things to address when reviewing:

Others seem to be overly-critical of the bleak-colored environment of this game. For me, it is quite suiting. The Wasteland isn't supposed to be some hospitable paradise. You are immersed in the grim reality of the then-modern world; there is no comparable moments to stepping outside of the vault for the first time and letting your eyes adjust to the sun. You can immediately tune into a radio station and try to figure out the world you've been shunned away from for the entirety of your character's youth. 

As many other games are today, Fallout 3 was very ambitious. But Fallout 3 managed to pull it off. The world around you feels so adaptive. The Wasteland is filled with random encounters and interesting environments. With the quests, you are given the choice of how you want to accomplish them and for many, you can alter the outcome. This makes a good RPG, you truly feel you are able to shape your story. The choices can be overwhelming to the point that I feel the need to save and see where the other choices would take me. 

I enjoyed the leveling system; in my opinion it was ahead of its time. Every level, you are awarded a perk, plenty of which are unique and quite interesting and rewarding, as apposed to a simple stat increase. However, at some point you may feel that you are not truly threatened by enemies and that is when the game can finally begin to taper. 

The gun-play is not spectacular but I do enjoy it. I see most people opted for VATS but that doesn't interest me so much. Of course, others may love it, and I see how they could. Usually in games like these, I choose a rogue-like character and prioritize stealth and accommodating skills, but this play-through I chose to be loud and messy, and it was great. 

I could go on and on about Fallout 3, but I will just suggest that for the current sale price of $6 with all DLC included, you give this game a revisit, or even play this game for the first time.

Arrive there and find the article titled 'What do I do if Fallout 3 is crashing on Steam on Windows 10?'.  How worthless was this help?  Let's count the ways:

1)  Doesn't reflect the current best methodology for fixing the problem.  That can be found pinned on the Discussion page on Steam.
2)  Could easily lead you to thinking that your perfectly decent little gaming machine isn't up to snuff to run a game... from '08.  And the reality is that you're still milking the cow, but you're not taking care of her any longer.
3)  Can't even downvote the worthlessness without creating a user account with Bethesda's website (yeah, I'll get right on that for the opportunity to let others know the poopshow at Bethesda never stops, with a simple downvote that should be available to the unregistered public).

I'm still working on a solution and hoping I'll get there in a day or two.  But this is really bad support for a franchise being promoted right now as part of a Summer event.  Here's a suggestion, Bethesda:  get off your asses and fix the installer so it properly detects the hardware I'm running and adjusts the pre-sets accordingly, auto-implementing the Intel Bypass Package for me.  While you're at it, get off your asses and release an Official patch that does everything the Unofficial patch does that is currently the best recommended fix for a common issue.  I'm really not happy right now with my purchase and I won't be buying any more Bethesda products, on Steam or anywhere, any time soon. But put all that aside, Fallout 3 is better without mods in my opinion (so apart from cheating to get a few handy perks early or toggle max carrying capacity to get out of a few buildings with a hoard of stuff to sell, my play-style hasn't been affected), it captures everything you want from a post apocalyptic world & delivers it so damn brilliantly Fallout 4 or 76 fail to come even close to how good this game is.

The latest update finally, (FINALLY) stopped the check for Games For Windows Live which ruined the experience for many as time's gone by, myself included & has polished up a lot of performance, visual & environmental bugs from textures to collisions & even the overall loading speed is a lot faster.

The "classic" Fallout experience that brought many into it's world is right here & if you can get over the fact that this has to be played as intended (finally Bethesda, took you long enough, 13-14 years too late for many) you're in for hours if not months of endless replayability from one of the greatest RPGs to ever break out into the 3D world.

I've only had to reinstall this once & that was down to trying to downgrade it back to an older patch to enable mods/console commands so no fault from the game itself. This game is one of the less popular fallout games, but after playing through every quest and going to every location at least once, I think that is unwarranted. The environment has landmarks that can be used for navigation and the accursed subway tunnels have maps that can assist in navigation. There are unique rewards for exploration and they are usually placed such that they stand out to a degree. The binary morality system is criticized a lot but I think it is implemented alright except for a couple decisions. There are cartoonishly evil options but there are also a good amount of practical evil options or callous options which have the same negative effect.

The gunplay is terrible but VATS allows you to target guns and make enemies drop them in this game, which is missing from some of the later titles. Every skill can be boosted by 10 points and every stat by 1 with the bobbleheads. You can max out nearly every skill in the game by the level cap, which is 30, and you can max out every stat for sure. The biggest problem with repairs is to do your own repairs you need duplicate equipment, which incentivizes using common enemy equipment instead of any of the unique gear you find.

Dungeons can be samey and dull but the loot you can find is very good and the environmental storytelling you expect from bethesda's world design is present here. The story is supposed to have this big narrative arc but most people don't seem to appreciate it; since this includes Broken Steel the game will continue and ruin the narrative arc anyway unless you intentionally fulfill it.

The environment is really the star here. I'd say include an hd texture pack and the unofficial patch to fully appreciate it. The world looks like a shelled-out wasteland, and it's so much more believable and grounded than the later games. There's less immediately interesting stuff, but that makes the special stuff stand out more. It's a good time; there are a lot of hidden variables that affect your choices that the game won't tell you about so if you feel like there are no options available (a common complaint) that is not usually true. Try it out but explore a lot; if you can't get into it just drop it and try New Vegas instead which has better shooting and a more immediately interesting environment.

I played Fallout 4 first, and loved it. I heard this was supposed to be even better, so I went ahead and got it. It's not better. It didn't even start for me at first. Looked it up and it's a nine year old bug. The community came up with a fix - not Bethesda nor Steam. 

Speaking of bugs - there are bugs everywhere in this game. Characters gliding instead of walking, VATs not doing anything but slowing down time, VATs not exiting, VATs not letting me get a single hit in, random crashes, and nothing loads. Like half this game is walking around a wasteland and then - oh shoot wall right in front of me why didn't that load in before. 

Possibly the most annoying thing about this game is the fact that none of the buttons like to respond in time. So fighting is AWFUL. I'm trying to open my Pipboy to use a stimpak and it takes five seconds, in which I'm already dead. I'm trying to open VATs to get some extra hits in and oh would you look at that? I've killed the guy with my fists and it loads afterwards. Every single time I enter VATs I have to wiggle my mouse to get the hit options to show up. I'm not even exaggerating. 

The actual content is mid. SPOILERS AHEAD. There's not as much here as in FO4, and what is here just isn't very fun in my opinion. There are some okay storylines - such as the cannibals, and Little Lamplight, but even those are lacking in depth, or overshadowed by how annoying the NPCs are. Pretty much every character in this game is a jerk who makes weird decisions, and they're all very annoying. I considered committing genocide several times, and I did not care about them at all. 

The first half of the story is alright. The vault section took a little too long, only for the end of it to be rushed (which seems to be a common theme here). But that was forgivable imo. After that, you have a sense of urgency to find your father. That's good. You have a settlement right outside the vault, so that you can really start playing this game - that's also good. But every character wants something huge in return for a few words of "yeah your dad went that way idk good luck kid lmao". That tradeoff of going out and fighting some difficult enemies for 30+ irl minutes, for a few words, from every character, is extremely unsatisfying, and makes me hate those characters and this game. 

The second half of the story feels rushed and sucks butt. Long story short, your dad dies abruptly, from these guys you've heard about once, with no build up at all. And then you take the fight to them alongside the BOS, who have a deus ex machina robot. Awful. The writing in this game took me back to middle school, when I read Wattpad fanfictions. Some of which I vividly remember having a more coherent build-up and story. 

And, I'm not quite sure how to articulate this, but the combat does not feel like combat at all. It feels like pushing a few buttons and it does something sometimes. Also, leveling up does not give me a discernible difference in gameplay. And the level up popup can be very annoying mid-combat. The beginning was kind of fun, but overall I did not have enough fun playing this to recommend it. I have no interest in even finishing this game all the way, let alone re-playing it. Disappointing.

I first played Fallout: New Vegas a few months ago. It quickly became my favourite game of all time and it is now my most played game on steam. I then played Fallout 1 and 2, which were both some of the best games I have ever played. Then I decided to play Fallout 3. I bought the Game of the Year Edition. I regret that now. 

Frankly, Fallout 3 is utter shit. Here is why.

[h1]1) Choices: [/h1]

The game presents you with many "choices" that are really just clear cut black and white dichotomies. They aren't interesting at all. For instance, the first settlement most players meet is Megaton, a town built around a live nuclear bomb with a religion around it. There are 2 opposing quests to do with the bomb. In one, you defuse it and make sure the town never gets blown up. In another, you blow up the town. There is nothing interesting or thought provoking about that choice. Either kill a bunch of innocent people or save them. Ironically, the game does such a poor job of making you care about anything that's happening that the choice doesn't really seem that meaningful. That's why I blew up the town in my playthrough. I legitimately did not care about the town or anyone in it. In New Vegas, the first mission and Ghost Town Gunfight really humanise Goodsprings. Doc Mitchell helping you and Sunny Smiles teaching you how to survive make you care about the town and its fate. This makes the choice of whether or not to help the town out so much more meaningful. As well as that, the game doesn't just say "oooooh bad karma naughty boy" if you don't help Goodsprings out. It also kills off Chet and Doc Mitchell, 2 characters who are really useful throughout the playthrough. Fallout 3 punishes morally bad choices by just saying that you're a bad person. I never felt like there were any repercussions for destroying Megaton. Not once did I say, "I wish I hadn't blown it up". The game is filled with these moments where you make choices but they feel like they barely matter. [spoiler]When you make the decision to sacrifice yourself at the end, it doesn't matter if you have Broken Steel installed because you just wake up from this apparently super deadly thing.[/spoiler]

TL;DR: The choices are black and white and very boring and you never feel like your choices ever have any consequences.

[h1]2) The Enclave[/h1]

I'm a big fan of the Enclave. I just think they're really cool and interesting. However, I hate how they're handled in Fallout 3. [spoiler] My main issue is that you can do Eden's bidding while also having to oppose him and the Enclave. Your conversation with Eden has 3 or 4 options if I remember correctly and only 1 agrees with him. Then you get the vial of FEV and you go to the Brotherhood. You cannot lie about the Enclave's intentions to take Project Purity. The only way you can help the Enclave in that conversation is by saying that you don't have the vial. You cannot publicly help the Enclave. In New Vegas, you can help any of the factions publicly to the anger of all the others. Fallout 3 forces you onto a set path against the Enclave. Then there's Autumn who doesn't want the FEV being in the water but also wants to take Project Purity anyway even though the Enclave only wanted it to kill off the mutants. It honestly doesn't make any sense. And you can make him straight up just leave with a few sentences, just like how you can get Eden to kill himself with a single sentence. 

AND THEN YOU CAN PUT THE FEV VIAL INTO PROJECT PURITY ANYWAY. AND EDEN WILL NEVER SEE IT. WITH BROKEN STEEL, YOU JUST WAKE UP TO FIND THAT EDEN AND ALL THE OTHER ENCLAVE BASES NEARBY WERE DESTROYED. What is the point in inserting the vial if the Enclave dies anyway? The Enclave sees themselves and only themselves as pure, true humans, which is why they want to kill all the mutants. They want to repopulate the wasteland with "real" humans-themselves. There is no point to inserting the vial if they are going to be destroyed anyway. And the only reason they were destroyed is because you weren't allowed to go against the Brotherhood and directly help the Enclave. Then, in Broken Steel, you have to fight more of the Enclave and help the Brotherhood take over their main base. EVEN IF YOU TRIED TO HELP THE ENCLAVE BY INSERTING THE VIAL. You are forced to go against them. But at the end you can chose to bomb the Brotherhood, which is pretty much the only thing you can do against the Brotherhood. But to do that, you have to kill a fuck ton of Enclave soldiers. [/spoiler]

TL;DR: Again, you don't have a choice. You have to do what the game wants you to do and you are occasionally given a choice that is completely defeated by the stuff the game forces you to do. The game likes to pretend that the Enclave are another joinable faction, but really, it forces you to go against them no matter what.

[h1]3) Boredom[/h1]

Fallout 3 is just really boring. Nothing was too hard or too easy. It felt like drifting in a world without challenge or really anything too interesting. By the end of my playthrough, I had visited barely any settlements because I didn't feel compelled to explore. Nothing seemed to really matter. I played Operation Anchorage only to find a linear shooter. I played Broken Steel only to find a linear shooter. I then started Mothership Zeta and then found another linear shooter and I stopped playing because I was just too bored. I'm not sure about the experiences of others but I personally found it really boring.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Just get Fallout: New Vegas. Honestly. It is the best game I have ever played and it is definitely far better than Fallout 3.
